ResponsesInList.Title: Stack for test for convergence and divergence
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear All, The stack is really a brilliant plugin. I like it very much.  Now I am trying to construct some exercises for testing the convergence of improper integrals and infinite series. The problem is can I make maxima return to stack  a value or a string  "true" if the improper integral ( or infinite series )  is convergent and "false" if it is divergent.  Thank you very much.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stack for test for convergence and divergence
ResponsesInList.Text:
Thanks for your kind comments about STACK . I think this is a Maxima question, rather than a STACK one, but I'll do my best. In Maxima the following happens 
```text
integrate(1/x,x,1,inf);


defint: integral is divergent.
```
 So the problem is that you want to catch an error. What we need is a function like the following in this file: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/stack/maxima/stackmaxima.mac 
```text
integrablep(ex,v,a,b):=block([res], 


  res:errcatch(integrate(ex,v,a,b)),


  print("STACK: ignore previous error."),


  if is(res=[]) then return(false),


  return(true)


)$
```
 However, this relies on Maxima's integrate function.  I don't know how reliable this would be. Lastly, when I come up against this kind of issue, I generally solve the problem by very careful randomisation rather than leaving this to chance.  Is there a reason why you can't start with known integrable/non-integrable things? Also, do you have a list of more specific test cases? Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stack for test for convergence and divergence
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Christopher Sangwin, I really appreciate you very much. I expect my students can use comparison and limit comparison test to test the convergence or divergence for some nontrivial  problems, but I find that  Maxima  is not good at  not solving such kind of problem, for example, why I type "integrate(1/(1+log(x), x, 0,1);" Maxima does not seem to know it diverges. Now, I shall consider your suggestion. Thank you very much again. Best Wishes C. T. Shieh

In the next generation of my quiz questions I would like to ask my students to type in vector equations (e.g equation of force equilibrium). These equations can contain scalars and vectors, too. For example: \( $$ {\bf{F}} = m \cdot {\bf{a}}$$ \) I've read the documentation of Matrix.md and Numbers.md and I'm able to format the vectors in the question text and feedback fields, but still unable to get it right in the validation field, which is generated by the plugin. ResponsesInList.Title: Stack Question > Grading criteria
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello, I am new to stack and this is a basic question. Suppose we ask the student to give
the coordinates of any point that lies on the graph fx = 2*x+1, how do we
check the answer in Stack? I know how to do it using Formulas-type
questions with grading criteria, but not with Stack. I have tried to manipulate the student's input [x1,y1] in the feedback variables by putting sa: 2*ans1[0]+1 -ans1[1] ( and also sa: subst (x=ans1[0], fx) - ans1[1]) and setting the teacher's answer as 0, but it does not work. Can anyone help me with that?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stack Question > Grading criteria
ResponsesInList.Text: Both of your approaches should work, and I think you're simply using the wrong index: Maxima lists start at 1, not at 0. Using ans1[1] and ans1[2] should fix it, see the attached minimal working example. (If I try using ans1[0] I get a "no such list element" error though, so maybe it's not that after all?)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stack Question > Grading criteria
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you very much, Andreas!

ResponsesInList.Title: STACK 3.2,  moodle 2.7, tex filter
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I installed locally STACK 3.2 correctly in moodle 2.7. The healthcheck script works correctly. MathJax does not correctly display the expressions (only in STACK). You need to install the filter tex but then MathJax not working anywhere. What is the correct configuration?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK 3.2,  moodle 2.7, tex filter
ResponsesInList.Text: Are you using the MathJaxloader filter that is supplied with Moodle 2.7?  STACK is written to work with MathJax included in the page header.  There are instructions for doing this in the healthcheck. MathJaxloader is new in 2.7, and it is not necessarily designed to work with STACK.  It has some idiosyncracies when working with interactive features, and may require some extra code to get it to work. If you do want to use MathJaxloader, you can enable it on the rest of the site and make TeX notation filter "Off, but available" in the filter admin settings.  In a quiz using STACK, MathJaxloader can be disabled and Tex notation enabled in the Course administration settings for just that activity.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK 3.2,  moodle 2.7, tex filter
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, I included code in t he page header. Mathjax work fine, but STACK should use Mathjaxloader filter with moodle 2.7+ in the future. Do not you think?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK 3.2,  moodle 2.7, tex filter
ResponsesInList.Text: Daniel, Pablo, I've just been looking at STACK in Moodle 2.7, and I'm not at all familiar with the MathJaxloader.  Putting the mathjx scripts into the additional HTML was a bit lazy, and I'll certainly try to make sure STACK conforms with default settings in Moodle.  The whole point of using MathJax was not to have to worry about displaying maths myself, and I'll try to ensure the future design of STACK has the minimum number of differences or extra settings. So, yes, I will look at the loader and use it if STACK can be modified to do so. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK 3.2,  moodle 2.7, tex filter
ResponsesInList.Text: I looked at some of the mathematics display code in STACK, and the second method I suggested above may not work.  STACK seems to check that the TeX filter is enabled on the system level.  It does not check the local context . STACK requires custom code for each Moodle filter to set some of the filter configuration. Since  mathjaxloader is new it will require some support code to work. Mathjaxloader does some formatting with PHP (removes $$) before it loads the javascript so it will need to be treated like a PHP. It also requires signal to typeset every time content is loaded by AJAX (yui/input.js).

ResponsesInList.Title: Math problems in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text:
I am mathematics teacher at high school., what problems
encountered in moodle in personalized mathematics teaching?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Math problems in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Yasar, welcome! What are the problems you encounter in your work? I can imagine that they are broader problems, not things that'll vanish with the flip of a switch. That is why it is worth to discuss them with others.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Math problems in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: I found three problems, first, personalizing became time too consuming to set up and maintain. I stepped back to more generic groups, that was far more successful. Two, testing results became messy in general comparisons, also time consuming, so again used more generic tests for different learning groups. Three, student attitudes were somewhat negative, initially, to this approach. We are on a national curriculum so I had to be very careful to remain within that format and learning structure. When I started using videos, in a flipped learning manner, students became far more responsive. Added to that, the more obviously work related mathematics I pitched to them were quickly accepted and became successful. For example, I understand diesel mechanics use trigonometry, so I pitched a couple of problems to each group about calculating the stroke of a piston, using trig to solve the length of a stroke. Then I stepped back and showed them the trig theory behind it. None of this would have been possible, let alone successful, without the resources being easily available within the Moodle. In some parts I used Groups, in others I used meta courses, took a bit of work to set it up, but I had one former student complain to me recently about him still remembering trig! And btw , more recent investigations have revealed that a lot of education psychology is essentially a dud, that it still comes down to classroom management and engagement. (Don't hate me, I'm just a messenger!)

ResponsesInList.Title: Bugs in TeX
ResponsesInList.Text: I met TeX while working on an old 286 with 2 floppy's and i still use fragments of the old files i wrote in those days. And still faithfull after all these years.... Moodle is new to me, but what an excitement to see TeX-possibilities in Moodle. I used it with my students (17 years) and after 1,5 hours of instruction and excercising, they make beautiful formula's (including matrices, integrals and so on) on there forums. Here are some bugs I want to report: 1. It's impossible to use < or > symbols. Propably a conflict with the html-tags? 2. When you want to correct an array-environment, the double backslashes  (to separate multiple rows)  are replaced by single ones. 3. It's impossible to separate the input of a formula over multiple lines. That's a problem for novices to TeX while writing matrices, etc. friendly yours Hugo Troch Belgium

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bugs in TeX
ResponsesInList.Text:
First of all you must understand that mimeTeX which we use to typeset TeX expressions is not a full implementation of TeX.  You certainly would not want to use it to publish your mathematics Ph.D. thesis on the web.  Please visit the mimeTeX home page at http://www.forkosh.com/mimetex.html for some idea about what it can or can not do. As to inequalities, I don't see any problem in typing them within HTML Editor. Enter $$$ x<2 $$$ to get $$x<2$$ and $$$ x>2 $$$ to get $$x>2$$ .  If you are entering inequalities without HTML Editor or in source mode within HTML Editor, you have to encode them like this < for < and > for >. As to arrays, double backslashes, and multiline inputs and so on, you need to enter them in source mode within HTML Editor.  Otherwise HTML Editor inserts unwanted html tags like

and

inside the TeX expression. Here's an example of an array entered in source mode: $$A=\(\array{3,c.cccBCCC$ &1&2&3\\\hdash~1&a_{11}&a_{12}&a_{13}\\ 2&a_{21}&a_{22}&a_{23}\\ 3&a_{31}&a_{32}&a_{33}}\)$$ I had some discussion with Janne about making HTML Editor more compatible with math. expressions here: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=4921

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bugs in TeX
ResponsesInList.Text: Quite right about inequalities. But i have still problems while correcting expressions like: $$\left|\begin{array}{cc}2&3\\4&5\end{array}\right| = 2.5 - 3.4$$ you lose one backslash every time you edit the formula.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bugs in TeX
ResponsesInList.Text: Unfortunately, due to compatibility problems with HTML Editor mentioned in my previous post, editting complicated TeX expressions within this Editor is quite inconvenient.  Currently it is best to use some more TeX friendly editor to perfect the TeX, and then copy and paste the finished product in source mode into HTML Editor. Janne is working on improving this situation, but probably not in time for the Moodle 1.2 release.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bugs in TeX
ResponsesInList.Text: I am attaching a mimeTeX previewer script, which you might find helpful with editting TeX.  Put it into your filter/tex directory.  Then open up an extra window and type in the url: http://yoursitename/moodle/filter/tex/texed.php

ResponsesInList.Title: Great Windows Latex Editor for Moodle's TeX filter
ResponsesInList.Text: If you are a high school math teacher like I am, then you'll want something to quickly draw complex equations.  Typing pure LaTeX format is no fun. I've tried a bunch of Windows editors, however the best one I've found is Texaide . http://www.dessci.com/en/products/texaide/ Once you have it installed: Go to EDIT->TRANSLATORS and turn off both check boxes. Go to FORMAT->INLINE EQUATION. When you make your formula, copy and paste it into moodle.  When you copy it, it will paste it as pure TeX. You'll have to add one more dollar sign to the beginning and end for moodle to see it. Works great! I hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: I cannot draw geometric shapes with Latex
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi I use Moodle 2.7. The MathJax filter is On for default. It works fine for math formulas such as fractions, integrals, various symbols. But it doesn't work with commands for drawing geometric shapes (lines, circles,..) or to set fontsize or fontcolor, I tryed some command read on https://docs.moodle.org/30/en/Using_TeX_Notation $$circle(150)$$ $$ \blue x \ = \ \frac{\sqrt{144}}{2} \ \times \ (y \ + \ 12) $$ Any idea? Thanks Enrico Zogli

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I cannot draw geometric shapes with Latex
ResponsesInList.Text: I know that when you read those Using_Tex_Notation pages, it seems to imply they should all work right out of the box, as the saying goes. But in my experience, those things do not work by default, but must be setup on your system by modifying your LaTex preamble or your MathJax configuration so that they include the packages needed for drawing shapes and adding color. In fact some stuff, such as \line and \mbox, are blacklisted in Moodle, and to get them to work, you have to go and remove them from the  $tex_blacklist in yourmoodle\filter\tex\lib.php down around line 73 in most Moodle versions. These may or may not, work for you, especially the MathJax as I have it installed on my server with some additions. Here is my current LaTeX preamble: \usepackage[latin1]{inputenc} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{amsfonts} And here is what I have in my MathJax configuration: MathJax.Hub.Config({ config: ["MMLorHTML.js", "Safe.js"], jax: ["input/TeX","input/MathML","output/HTML- CSS ","output/NativeMML"], extensions: ["tex2jax.js","mml2jax.js","MathMenu.js","MathZoom.js"], TeX: { extensions: ["xypic.js","mhchem.js","color.js","AMSmath.js","AMSsymbols.js","noErrors.js","noUndefined.js"], }, menuSettings: { zoom: "Double-Click", mpContext: true, mpMouse: true }, errorSettings: { message: ["!"] }, skipStartupTypeset: true, messageStyle: "none" });

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I cannot draw geometric shapes with Latex
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok, Thanks a lot. I'll try your suggestion.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I cannot draw geometric shapes with Latex
ResponsesInList.Text: The Using TeX Notation document uses a lot of functionality that is present in the mimetex binary. This was originally the only way that TeX was rendered, but now works as a fall back. Currently, the included binary does not work on 64bit systems. A native binary or compatibility lib need to be installed and configured. If you want to use that functionality, make sure mimetex is working in TeX notation filter and turn off MathJax.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I cannot draw geometric shapes with Latex
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the reminder, Daniel. Since I don't regularly use that stuff I tend to forget that. Most of my renders are just for reference displays so I have stuff to show when trying to explain to teachers who haven't used Moodle, just what can done with it. The last couple of years, I just keep the filters for MathJax, LaTeX and Algebra all on and set the filter for the particular Moodle item according to what it needs to be to get the output I want.

ResponsesInList.Title: Which question behaviour to use for STACK questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Is "adaptive mode" the best mode to use for a quiz with STACK questions or "interactive with multiple tries"? What actually is the difference?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Which question behaviour to use for STACK questions
ResponsesInList.Text: If you use the question preview feature in the question bank, you can easily try a question with different behaviours. The main differences is that with "interactive with multiple tries" you have to click "Try again" after reading the feedback, before you change your response. Also, with Adaptive the number of tries is unlimited. In Interactive it is number of hints + 1 (so you need to add hints to your question.) For multi-part (technically multi-PRT) questions, the difference is bigger. With interactive, you have to answer all parts of the question at the same time. With Adaptive you can answer one part at a time. So, I think they both have their different strengths and weaknesses, and you have to think about what will be best for your students and your teaching style. (I think the OU mostly uses Interactive, and Chris Sangwin uses Adaptive.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Which question behaviour to use for STACK questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you Tim, that was very clear. I will definitely use Adaptive.

ResponsesInList.Title: MathJax version in Moodle 4.5 filter settings
ResponsesInList.Text: It appears that, in the filter settings, Moodle 4.5 still recommends using MathJax version 2.7.9, even though the current MathJax version is 3.2. Could you kindly clarify the reason for this?

ResponsesInList.Title: MathJax version in Moodle 4.5 filter settings
ResponsesInList.Text: I have the same question. In our case, we’re loading MathJax locally by pointing to /lib/mathjax/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js. To do this, we downloaded the code from https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax.git (tag 3.2.2) and are using only the es5 directory. MathJax 3.2.2 appears to work, but it throws a browser console error: first.js:4584 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'Queue'). This seems to be caused by the call to MathJax.Hub.Queue() in moodle/filter/mathjaxloader/amd/src/loader.js, a method that existed in MathJax v2 but was removed in v3: https://docs.mathjax.org/en/v3.2-latest/upgrading/v2.html What I don’t quite understand is why the Moodle mathjaxloader filter hasn’t been fully upgraded to support MathJax version 3. Are there any plans to update the loader for full compatibility with MathJax v3?

ResponsesInList.Title: MathJax version in Moodle 4.5 filter settings
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle version 5.0.1 and MathJax 3.2.2 as the default.

ResponsesInList.Title: MathJax version in Moodle 4.5 filter settings
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your input Daniel. However, we’re currently using Moodle 4.5, which is an LTS version with security updates until October 2027. Wouldn’t it make sense to consider backporting the MathJax v3 support (or at least the necessary changes in the mathjaxloader filter) to 4.5 as well? Is this something that could be considered by the Moodle team? Best!

ResponsesInList.Title: MathJax version in Moodle 4.5 filter settings
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Susana, According to the integration policy a LTS branch only gets bug fixes for a year and only security fixes after that. Upgrading MathJax would potentially change the behavior of and may LTS sites want to avoid that. Normally the site admin could make the change in the settings. However, in this case there seems to be more coding required to handle language configuration see MDL-75486 .

ResponsesInList.Title: MathJax version in Moodle 4.5 filter settings
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you Daniel for your reply, and especially for sharing the link to MDL‑75486 , which is really helpful. Just to double-check: Moodle 4.5 (LTS) was released in October 2024, so according to the official release policy , at the time of this post, it is still within its bug-fix support period, which lasts for 12 months - until October 2025. Security-only support continues until October 2027. Given that, it seems we’re still within the window where fixes and updates (like improving compatibility with MathJax v3) could still be considered for the 4.5 branch. To be honest, it feels like Moodle 4.5 may have been unintentionally overlooked when MathJax v3 support was added in 5.0, despite 4.5 being an active LTS release still within its bug-fix support window. Given its widespread use, I believe it would be worth reconsidering support for MathJax v3 in 4.5 as well. Thanks again for your input!

ResponsesInList.Title: MathJax version in Moodle 4.5 filter settings
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle 4.5 was released October 24 so the last bug fix release was October 2025. It is now security only (and this is considered a new feature). The MathJax 3.2 update was integrated into Moodle 5.1 released in April 2025. Admittedly it would be better if the MathJax support was updated more frequently (5 years since last updated). Moodle HQ does not have a mathematics department and probably does not use MathJax on a regular basis. They caught is in a general library review. Universities use it frequently. It would be helpful if an update is needed to post a message here or add an issue in the tracker prior to an LTS release.

ResponsesInList.Title: MathJax version in Moodle 4.5 filter settings
ResponsesInList.Text: Just a quick clarification: since Moodle 4.5 was released in October 2024 , it's still within its bug-fix support period until October 2025 (because we are still on July 2025, am I getting this right?). So technically, improvements like this could still be addressed. That said, I understand your point about MathJax not being a core focus for Moodle HQ. However, continuing to ship MathJax v2.7.9, which is deprecated and no longer maintained, raises a serious security and maintainability concern, not just for LTS users, but for any Moodle supported version site relying on it (4.1, 4.4, 4.5). I absolutely agree that the community should engage earlier in the release cycle. Still, in this case, I believe the MathJax update should have been included in all " current stable " branches at the time, which included both Moodle 5.0 and 4.5 . On Moodle 4.1 MathJax 2.7.9 was already outdated... Frankly, I consider this an oversight and I think MDL-75486 should be backported to 4.5. Thanks again!

ResponsesInList.Title: MathJax version in Moodle 4.5 filter settings
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, you are correct it is July 2025 now and 5.1 has not been released yet. I am apparently six months ahead of schedule.

ResponsesInList.Title: MathJax version in Moodle 4.5 filter settings
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Susanna, If you want to try to fix this locally in 4.5, you could replace the amd directory in filter/mathjaxloader in 4.5 with the same directory found in the 5.0 version. After that clear the JavaScript cache. There is also a CSS change if you are using ddwtos or ddimageortext. Those are the only essential code differences. Daniel

ResponsesInList.Title: MathJax version in Moodle 4.5 filter settings
ResponsesInList.Text: For stability and compatibility, Moodle 4.5 maintains MathJax 2.7.9; however, administrators can switch to v3.2 if their configuration permits it.

ResponsesInList.Title: STACK question type > Function to compute score?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, We're using STACK question to assess the students' ability to perform measures of some variables in an electronic circuit (voltages, frequencies, etc.). These magnitudes are analog in nature and perhaps affected by noise and other factors, so there are not an exact "true value" of the response. Instead of programming a single correct value (with some relative or absolute acceptable margin), we would like to give the student a score based on how much his/her response deviates from the teacher's value. I am aware that it can be achieved by defining a rich PRT with many levels, each one expanding a bit more the acceptable margin and lowering the score accordingly, but this is a bit cumbersome and time-consuming if you have a lot of questions of that kind. As it seems that there's no answer test that outputs a "fuzzy" truth value between 0 and 1, I tried to use a formula/variable in the "score" field of the PRT, but this doesn't work. It accepts only numerical values. Therefore I'm asking if there is a way to make a PRT node to yeld a variable score based on a formula or algorithm involving the student's and teacher's answers. Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK question type > Function to compute score?
ResponsesInList.Text: Honestly, that's not a use-case I thought of! Newer versions of STACK support this, but only recently (this summer) in Version 4.4.0. Released July 2022. See https://docs.stack-assessment.org/en/Developer/Development_history/ You can check your own STACK version at the bottom of the documentation home page on your server , e.g. the demo server version is at the bottom of https://stack-demo.maths.ed.ac.uk/demo/question/type/stack/doc/doc.php/ If you have a simple question with a formula, I'd be happy to add this as an example to our unit tests to maintain the functionality.  Please jut email me at Edinburgh with a question you're happy to end up in github.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dragmath Java Applet Failed
ResponsesInList.Text:
I read the documentation and followed the directions posted below. I also downloaded dragmath from there. I am using Firefox 3, but I have also tried in 2. I am running MOODLE 1.9 on a shared server , not sure what version of Java. The demo does seem to work at: http://mydomain.com/lib.editor/htmlarea/popups/Dragmath/demo.html . Installing DragMath From the Moodle CVS - Recommended! This could not be easier. If you are running verion 1.9.+ click here or if you are running Moodle version 1.8.4 or greater but not 1.9.x click here and you will start the download of the zip file (at present there are no differences between the two versions. At this point you can unzip on your workstation and then you can upload the included files to their appropriate locations. This version retains the smileys and includes all integration files and all DragMath files (demos, docs, and all export formats) Warning: At present the zip file includes a version of adminlib.php that should NOT be used with Moodle 1.8.2 If you are using 1.8 DO NOT over write your adminlib.php. Install the rest of the files (other than adminlib.php) and DragMath will work without a problem. Apparently the Moodle automagically creates the zip with a parent directory of "dragmath". Should you wish you can unzip the files and then rezip with the top level directory being /lib, and this will allow you to simply upload the zip you just created to your moodle root and unzip there, and the files will be placed in their appropriate locations. However, please make sure all files are backed up, and in as much as there are only a few files you may want to manually install even if a zip with /lib as top directory were provided here just to ensure each file is backed up before installation. Upload the zip file to your Moodle root and unzip. Installing DragMath Integration and DragMath Applet Separately - Not Recommended! You install DragMath in two steps Install the DragMath package Install the DragMath integration package =====Step 1 - Install the DragMath package ===== Download the latest DragMath package from sourceforge and unzip it in the 
```text
$CFG->
dirroot
/lib/editor/htmlarea/popups
```
 directory (where `$CFG->dirroot` is your "moodle" directory as defined in `config.php` . NOTE there is also a `popups` directory directly in the editor directory. Don't use that one!). This will create a new directory under `popups` called `DragMath` containing all the necessary DragMath components. =====Step 2 - Install the DragMath integration package ===== Important Note: These instructions will REPLACE the smiley button on the HTML editor toolbar with the DragMath editor button. This was done to keep the installation instructions simple. If you want to keep your smiley button, see the section at the end of this article. Download the latest DragMath integration package from the modules and plugins database . In the zip archive, you will find two files. `dlg_ins_smile.php` -- Copy this file to your `$CFG->dirroot/lib/editor/htmlarea/popups` directory, overwriting the existing file (you may want to make a copy of the original file before overwriting it) `em.icon.smile.gif` -- Copy this file to your `$CFG->dirroot/lib/editor/htmlarea/images` directory, overwriting the existing file (you may want to make a copy of the original file before overwriting it) You must also change two lines in the file `$CFG->dirroot/lib/editor/htmlarea/dialog.js` around line 34 you will see the line: `case "dlg_ins_smile": x = 330; y = 320; break;` Change this line to `case "dlg_ins_smile": x = 540; y = 340; break;` around line 47, you will see a line that begins `var dlg = window.open(url, "ha_dialog", "toolbar=no, menubar=no, ...` Modify this line, changing `resizable=no` to `resizable=yes` You might also want to change the mouse over popup from "Insert Smiley" to "Insert Equation". to do this you need to edit the file `$CFG->dirroot/lib/editor/htmlarea/htmlarea.php` around line 275 you will see the line: `case "insertsmile: ["Insert Smiley", "em.icon.smile.gif", false, ...` Change this line to `case "insertsmile: ["Insert Equation", "em.icon.smile.gif", false, ...` Finally, make sure that the new files and directories you create in the above steps are readable by the Web server. For example, make sure that the em.icon.smile.gif file has the same permissions as other gif files in the images directory.

ResponsesInList.Title: Mathematics Assessment with AIM
ResponsesInList.Text: I am planning to develop a module for mathematics assessment using AIM ( http://sourceforge.net/projects/aimmath/ ). AIM solves two problems that arise when trying to automatically mark mathematics homework: Checking the correctness of the answer to a mathematics problem is hard because there is often not a unique way of expressing the answer. AIM solves this problem by feeding the student's answer to MAPLE, a computer algebra package. Students may be tempted to copy the answer off each other. AIM solves this problem by allowing the problem to contain random parameters, so that every student has a different problem to solve. Thus AIM has the same purpose as WeBWorK that Zbigniew Fiedorowicz has already integrated with Moodle ( http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=798 ). However unlike WeBWork, AIM does not require programming abilities to design the questions. We have a grant to roll out AIM across all large modules in the Department of Mathematics at the University of York. As part of this project I am planning to employ Moodle in our Department at the same time to provide a comfortable front end.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mathematics Assessment with AIM
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, this all sounds pretty excellent, Gustav! Keep in touch about your plans and progress. The developer is currently pretty scant (something I hope to fix in the next few weeks) so just ask if you need help with anything or feedback on something.

ResponsesInList.Title: Stack Number of Decimal Places Comparison
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I want to make a question where a student gives a value x and y, and Stack checks if x and y have the same amount of decimal places. The Answer Test, NumDecPlaces, needs that I inform the number of decimal places to check, which I don't know yet. I was thinking if there is a maxima command that returns the number of decimal places of a number to implement the test, but I couldn't find any. Does anyone know how to implement this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stack Number of Decimal Places Comparison
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi you can find it out in maxima like this: (%i1) p:24.3212; (%o1) 24.3212 (%i3) s:0; for j: 0 step 1 unless float(round(p*10^j)/10^j)=p do s:s+1; (%o2) 0 (%o3) done (%i4) s; (%o4) 4

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stack Number of Decimal Places Comparison
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for the solution. The only problem is if the input is something like p:24.000. Any tips in that case?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stack Number of Decimal Places Comparison
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Rodrigo, I'd like to draw your attention to the following documenation page: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/doc/en/CAS/Numbers.md You might want to pay special attention to the paragraphs titled "Maxima and floats with trailing zeros". I was not able to preserve trailing zeros with any input type through further operations / calculations. This might only apply to The next best thing you can do is string manipulation and evaluation. Let x,y be your students input (input type should be "String"): xdec: split(x,"."); xlen: length(split(xdec[2], "")); ydec: split(y,"."); ylen: length(split(ydec[2], "")); diff: xlen - ylen; The first line splits the input string at the delimiter "." (decimal point). The second line then takes the second part of this split operation (the right-hand side or decimal places) and takes an empty delimiter for the split operation, giving single characters. The length of the resulting array is the number of decimal places in your input. You can then simply compare whether diff equals zero. Cheers

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stack Number of Decimal Places Comparison
ResponsesInList.Text: I am just updating my moodle server for the fall and while testing the STACK plugin, I noticed there is a testsuite for the NumSigFig answer type. It should be available at https://.../question/type/stack/adminui/answertests.php?anstest=NumSigFigs on your server. Leo

ResponsesInList.Title: MathML plans for Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I would like to know, if there are any plans for MathML in future Moodle releases? I surfed the postings a bit and could not find any hints on this. Thanks Andreas Leiser

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathML plans for Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Actually there has been quite a bit of discussion, though it was likely difficult to identify in that the discussion has been over inclusion of dragmath and asciimathml as core tech in Moodle 2 and you can vote for either or both in the tracker...... so please do. http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/CONTRIB-384 http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-16279 At present Mauno has a number of options he has been working on for integrating Moodle 2 and tinyMCE with an assortment of math construction and display technologies that include asciimathml, dragmath equations editors, etc. (I have dubbed this the super equation editor intiative) and can allow use of asciimathml through themes as opposed to deploying it as a filter. I think this is the best hope at present for an easily deployable and manageable way to provide moodle wide display of MathML, and I only wish that it would be implemented at Moodle.org VOTE HERE: http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDLSITE-599 There area number of issues that have to be addressed - from avoiding what one might call balkanization of code if too many versions are extant to what questions implementing asciimathml through themes pose for Moodle's functionality generally and what would/could implementation of asciimathml mean vis-a-vis other existing filters and the decisions are not in our hands, but I think the more people who support this effort the more likely it is that it will be a go.....

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathML plans for Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: The OU has a nice Moodle filter for rendering MathML content. By default, it renders to image files, like the LaTeX filter, but if you click on an equation, it takes you to a page where you can test your browser, and if it works, choose to get MathML served directly. This relies on a separate Java servlet to do the MathML -> image rendering. It also serves the MathML is a way that works with both Firefox and IE + mathplayer. I don't know if that filter is in the modules and plugins database yet.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathML plans for Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: hi Andreas, the equation editor included in Moodle through WIRIS math plugin is based on MathML. If you are editing a formula and press Control+Shift+X you will be able to edit the MathML code. There is also a new integration with TinyMCE that will be usefull in Moodle 2.0. Check WIRIS Tiny MCE integration and have a look at a demo .

ResponsesInList.Title: ANN: MathTran Instant Preview web-based editor for mathematics
ResponsesInList.Text: This morning seems to be a good time to make an interesting and amusing announcement, so here goes. ResponsesInList.Title: Some TeX equations are displayed, other do not work?!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi! I am very new to using Moodle, but I have been using LateX for many years. I am using Moodle on the Server of our University, i.e. I do not have admin permissions. I have contacted our local admin about the issue that I am going to ask, but maybe he's on vacation... in any case, I am trying to prepare a course that will start soon, so it would be super helpful if I could get the TeX code to work without the admin. If I enter $$ f(x)=\Bigint_{-\infty}^x~e^{-t^2}dt $$ (f(x)=\Bigint_{-\infty}^x~e^{-t^2}dt in Dollar-operators), it works just fine, displays the equation, everything good. But if I try anything else, it never works. For example $$ f(x)=\frac{1}{x} $$ (f(x)=\frac{1}{x} in dollar operators) displays a broken image. $$ f(x)=\int_{-\infty}^x~3^{-t^2}dt $$ (f(x)=\int_{-\infty}^x~3^{-t^2}dt in dollar operators) also displays a broken image, etc. Do you have any idea what could be the reason for this weird behavior? Any help would be appreciated. I am aware of the possibility to create the equations externally and include them as gifs. It would just be so much nicer if I didn't have to go through that effort since I want to use lots of equations. Katharina

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Some TeX equations are displayed, other do not work?!
ResponsesInList.Text: This sounds like a permission issue. Most likely $$ f(x)=\Bigint_{-\infty}^x~e^{-t^2}dt $$ was created to moodledata subfolder /filter/tex when that folder still had write permissions and your site admin changed the permissions to not allow writing to this folder anymore. Tex filter checks if the old image exists in folder and if it does not Tex filter tries to create a new one. The other option is that your settings of php have changed and there might be some disabled functions in php that no more allow creating of new images or if your site is using local distribution of latex paths of executable binaries might have changed in upgrading of site (see administration menu and settings of tex filter if there are green ticks after the paths). You can set site debugging to ALL in administration menu and click one of those broken images to get some more info about possible reason. If your version of moodle is 2.X you could also add MathJax script tags to additional HTML in site administration and use MathJax instead of Tex filter to get around this kind of problems - see https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=193064

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Some TeX equations are displayed, other do not work?!
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you! This post was very helpful. Luckily, our admin returned to his office, today, and he changed the permissions for me. It's working very well, now!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Double digit exponents
ResponsesInList.Text: Two @@ around the expression and parenthesis.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Double digit exponents
ResponsesInList.Text: awesome, thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Double digit exponents in tex - use braces
ResponsesInList.Text: using double @s simply employs the algebra filter as opposed to the tex filter, and frankly I do not know why anyone would want to use both, as the algebra filter is a subset of the tex filter and having both filters running means the file has to be parsed twice..... In tex, curly braces can be used to group arguments, so for a doubel digit exponent you can do 2^{33}, which will appear as: $$2^{33}$$

ResponsesInList.Title: Getting STACK to recognise negative expressions when equating with zero
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm asking for students to show an equality with zero on one side as follows: ta1: 0 = -x + y/A + (y-z)/B Unfortunately, if a student starts with their answer "on the other side" like: 0 = x - y/A - (y-z)/B STACK won't see this as equivalent. The only solution I've found is to provide an additional PRT Node which also awards grades if students produce the negative, i.e. "-ta", which is actually interpreted as: -(0 = (y-z)/B + y/A -x); according to the question test readout. Is there a more direct way to deal with this? I appreciate it's likely the zero that's creating this issue (if I take the term out and provide appropriate equivalents "x = y/A + (y-z)/B" or "-x = -y/A - (y-z)/B", either will work). Essentially, I'm looking for a way to set the left hand side of my equation to ±0 (the positive OR the negative zero), or whatever the appropriate approach should be.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Getting STACK to recognise negative expressions when equating with zero
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok, this has revealed a lack of symmetry in the current equation answer test which I consider to be a bug. I've fixed the problem which will be in the next release. Sorry about this. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Getting STACK to recognise negative expressions when equating with zero
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the reply, Christopher. I look forward to updating

ResponsesInList.Title: Adding feedback to STACK questions after quiz has started
ResponsesInList.Text: Once students start answering a quiz, it will become clearer what kind of mistakes they are making. STACK is in principle intelligent enough so that one can detect a particular type of mistake in a student's answer and then give tailored feedback. This requires adding extra nodes to the response tree of the STACK question. Is this possible to do even after some students have already started taking the quiz?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding feedback to STACK questions after quiz has started
ResponsesInList.Text: Gustav, Good question. I'm not 100% familiar with what outcomes are cached by "quiz/question attempts", as this is a part of Moodle rather than STACK itself. I've done some experiments today. Yes, you can edit a question once it is in a quiz, and students have attempted it. They then get updated feedback. However, the marks do not change. I think you need to do a "regrade" to achieve this from the quiz review page as the teacher. I think this is a sensible protocol, and quite helpful to teachers. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding feedback to STACK questions after quiz has started
ResponsesInList.Text: Chris's experiments were good, in that they correctly determined how the code works. Grades (and question state (correct / partial / incorrect) are calculated and stored at the moment when the student submits their responses. (Exactly when that happens depends on the question behaviour.) The feedback is re-computed whenever we display the question. (Hmm, I guess that is a bit weird and inconsistent, but actually it seems to work OK.) Re-grading will re-compute the grade and question state using the latest question definition.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding feedback to STACK questions after quiz has started
ResponsesInList.Text: A similar observation which I made quite a while ago (so it can be outdated, but perhaps worth checking anyway if the need arises): If I presented a defect question to the students, somebody pointed the problem out, and I fixed the question, then the students had to start a new quiz to get the corrected version of the question. Quizzes that were started before the question was fixed still were served the old version. The question behaviour for the test is now adaptive, with new attempts not building on previous ones, but I am not 100% sure I have not changed that afterwards.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding feedback to STACK questions after quiz has started
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for these helpful answers. If I combine Tim's answer and Mikael's answer I get that question feedback is recomputed each time the question is displayed, but the question text is recomputed only when the student starts a new quiz. Is that correct?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding feedback to STACK questions after quiz has started
ResponsesInList.Text: Mikael's observation is out-of-date. The situation changed in March this year ( https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/commit/4685a355da329e8feb9e3fcf9f852b6d9e456132 ). Now, the only unique thing done when a student starts a question is to generate the random seed. Then, each time the student views the question, everything else is re-generate from that. (So, if you edit the question in a stupid way, you could break things badly.) On the other hand, it does let you fix typos in the question text. Note that this is not inefficient, because of the CAS caching. All the calculation is done in one CAS call, which will be in the cache after the first time the student starts the question - unless you edit the question in a non-trivial way, in which case it will become a cache miss, and things will get recomputed. If you want to see the details, here is the code: Starting an attempt at a question: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/3239dc60a5a15ab54cdbd0107fdeb549b1eb872e/question.php#L238 Re-visiting an existing attempt: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/3239dc60a5a15ab54cdbd0107fdeb549b1eb872e/question.php#L334

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding feedback to STACK questions after quiz has started
ResponsesInList.Text: That is perfect! Thank you Tim.

Sorry.) That is, you might need to enter you answer as: 
```text
   Cov(R_B ,R_m) = \\rho_\{B,M\} \\sigma_B \\sigma_M = 0.9 \\times 0.35 \\times 0.15 = 0.04725
```

ResponsesInList.Title: jsMath version 3.1 and new filter released
ResponsesInList.Text: The jsmath filter now uses the latest version of jsMath (3.1). This version includes a number of small bug fixes (in particular, it fixes a problem with alignment in Firefox 1.5). There are also a number of significant new features. The most important of these is that the main jsMath files have now been compressed so that they should download about twice as fast as the uncompressed versions (this doesn't affect how fast jsMath processes the mathematics on the page, only how soon it can start doing so). A second important feature is the ability for jsMath to load extensions automatically as they are needed by the mathematics on the page. Several lesser-used portions of jsMath have been moved into extension files to help reduce the initial download, and font references using the `\char` macro will load the font automatically if it is not loaded already. Additionally, you can define macros that are linked to extension files so that the use of the macro will cause the extension to load. Similarly, LaTeX environments can be autoloaded (though no examples of this are available yet). Finally, there is a new `\require{}` macro that you can use to load an extensionfrom within a TeX formula itself if it is needed for a particular piece of mathematics on the page ( without the need to insert JavaScript code in the page). See the change log for more details. Finally, the configuration section of the filter's `javascript.php` file includes settings for `loadFiles` and `loadFonts` , which allow you to specify additional files and fonts to load when jsMath is needed on a particular page. This provides a means of loading your own extensions (for example, loading a file that contains special macro definitions needed at your site). Davide

Moving moodle to another system, the math formulas render much larger
ResponsesInList.Text: We are trying to move our moodle to another system. Math formulas render significantly larger on the new system. We've tried to ensure both imagemagick and tex binaries are located in the same location (/usr/bin/latex and /usr/bin/imagemagick). We've also got the mimetex.linux, mimetex.freebsd and mimetex.darwin files within the tex filter's directory. As I understand it, our previous developer had replaced the original 32-bit versions with 64-bit versions. Our old OS is Redhat 7.5 and our new one is Centos 7.5. We are using a copy of our database so the settings in moodle are identical. Any thoughts on what might be making the size of the images much bigger on the Centos system?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moving moodle to another system, the math formulas render much larger
ResponsesInList.Text: Given that you have to change anyway, why don't you just switch to using the MathJax filter? Nicer looking equations that way.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moving moodle to another system, the math formulas render much larger
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Diane, As Tim mentions, a switch to the MathJax filter will give much nicer looking equations. Meanwhile you might want to compare a hard coded setting in the tex filter for your two systems. Look at about line 61 or ...yourmoodle/filter/tex/pix.php if you see this: $texexp = '\Large '.$texexp; in the new site, try changing the '\Large' to '\small' or any of these: \tiny \scriptsize \footnotesize - this one doesn't seem to work anymore in my setup \small \normalsize \large \Large \LARGE \huge \Huge

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moving moodle to another system, the math formulas render much larger
ResponsesInList.Text: Seems the reply to almost every forum anywhere is always "use something else" (which never actually answers the question), I'll reply to myself in case anyone in the future needs help. I'm no sysadmin, but I did a search through the system of everywhere there are tex, texlive and latex things installed. It ended up being that our /usr/share/texlive directory had discrepancies and the settings for TeX notation in moodle showed where various executables should be installed, but those were also missing. Our sysadmin figured out how to get those items installed. Installing packages can be tricky, apparently, making sure they get all the parts. I'm just glad he fixed it. The way I was able to test this was to export a course with some math formulas, then import it into the new system. That generated the image with the same hash in the filter/tex dir in the moodle filesystem. They were a different size, different bytes and the physical appearance was bigger. Once the sysadmin got the packages installed correctly, I deleted the images so they'd be regenerated and voila! It was fixed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Anyone using a pen tablet?
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm interested in hearing from people who are using pen tablets (e.g., Wacom) in their Moodle math courses, particularly in blended (vs. online) courses. How do you use your tablet, and how has it improved your course?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Anyone using a pen tablet?
ResponsesInList.Text: John, I don't use a pen tablet, but I do use a TabletPC. Here are some of the ways I use it: 1. If my class is scheduled in a room with a projection system, I hook up my TabletPC to the projector and write my notes using Microsoft Journal (which displays on the projector). I then create PDF files of my notes which I post in my Moodle installation. I hope to start audio recordings and screen videos of my lectures as well. 2. I use Camtasia and Microsoft Journal to record video of myself answering questions students have posted online. I can then upload the video for all the students to see. I don't do this for every problem, just those I feel that the video would be beneficial. A short couple minute problem usually takes me about fifteen minutes to record, edit, produce, and post. I produce it as a flash file, which usually stays less than one megabyte for short problems. Hope this helps! Scott

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Anyone using a pen tablet?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Scott, Thanks for your detailed reply. Do you have a course with guest login where I could see your notes and/or videos? It's research for a talk I'm doing on Moodle "best practices" in math. Is Microsoft Journal only for recording handwritten notes? Or can it also be used to electronically mark up a Word or PDF document? I'm not clear on the capabilities of pen tablets vs. tablet PC's, but I believe pen tablets can be used from within programs like Word (as well as for recording notes).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Anyone using a pen tablet?
ResponsesInList.Text: John, I don't allow guest access into my courses. I'll email you some information where you can get in. You can use Journal to markup any document. There's a printer driver that I can print any document to a Journal document format. I can then open up the Journal document and write away. Actually, if I need to markup Word, I can do it right in Word. In regards to differences between the pen tablets and tablet PC's, I think it's a matter of convenience. With the TabletPC, I have my computer and tablet all in one. I don't need to lug around a notebook and a separate tablet. The other thing is there are some features built into the Windows TabletPC operating system that allow OS/UI tasks to be performed with the pen. I really don't use that feature much. Scott

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Anyone using a pen tablet?
ResponsesInList.Text: Great! And thanks for the clarification. I'll look more into tablet PCs.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Anyone using a pen tablet?
ResponsesInList.Text: I use pen tablet a lot for synchronous teaching. Some of the recordings of synchronous teaching are then made available via Moodle. Using pen tablet is a bit difficult initially as while writing on the tablet one has to look at the screen. It would be much easier to write on the surface where one can see what one is writing in the same place therefore I guess TabletPC could be worth trying for a new user. However, now I am getting somewhat accustomed to pen tablet as I have been using it for long.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Anyone using a pen tablet?
ResponsesInList.Text: Manish, Which pen tablet do you use (or would you recommend)? Tablet PC's are out of my price range. I see that you're a physics teacher as well as a math teacher. I'm looking for "best practices" in science and math, and I'd value your input. Many physics Web sites have animations of physical principles. Do you use any of these, and if so, how? For example, do you link to them in Moodle? Some sites (like webphysics.davidson.edu) have downloadable java applets for creating your own animations. Have you used any of these, and if so, how? Have you experimented with SCORM ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Anyone using a pen tablet?
ResponsesInList.Text: The pen tablet I use is from iball . Actually, I think it is imported from uc-logic.com by iball. The pen is electromagnetic type and the device has not required any maintenance. I have not yet tried any other brand so I cannot recommend a particular product. I have played with animations quite a lot linking them to Moodle and have come across the site mentioned by you. However, this year with the growing bandwidth speed at the user end, rise of videos on the internet and the ease in making them etc. I am shifting somewhat towards them. Animations/videos are good to explain concept in an interesting manner. The web hosting disk space and bandwidth limits have become very high and it takes very less time to do the recording while explaining a concept and then upload it. I think flash, shock wave, java applet creation would take much more time. I have not yet explored the advantages of SCORM and would like to learn.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Anyone using a pen tablet?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi John I teach Science, Biology and theory of knowledge on the International Baccalaureate program. Our school bought 4 interactive whiteboards so I started playing with the smart board software with a cheap A4 tablet from aiptek (170 Swiss Francs approximately 120 US Dollars). Then I noticed that the license forbids the use of anything other than Smart technologies equipment. So I looked for an alternative. I found notateit for £16.95 license http://www.notateit.com/ it is a great piece of software. You can use the whiteboard screen with a beamer for free hand drawing writing etc. Annotate on top of existing documents web site applets simulations videos etc. The ouput is as manually contolled screen or (custom area) shots or each whiteboard page as an Image. I then use OpenOffice with photoalbum installer installed which collects all images in a folder into a StarImpress (Powerpoint replacement +). This can be futher edited or directly exported to flash or pdf format. I then upload them to a moodle course or combine them into an exe http://exelearning.org/ file which can be later uploaded as a website package or as a SCORM. I tried reload and gave up with its complexity once I found exe. There are still a few issues with exe but it is extemely intuitive, has a variety of idevices to embed content into web pages or SCORM or IMS e.g java applet, audio, images, flash files (even flash video with a few problems), cloze completion tests, scorm tests etc. I have started to experiment with a three tablet set up. 2 tablets are linked to my laptop via a USB hub and laid out so students can interact with the white board. I have had some of my best lessons ever solving genetics problems with student interaction. Very quickly students were collaboratively suggestion solutions and different interpretations of the available data, applying concepts learned in previous lessons. This approach seems highly applicable to math and physics problems. The notateit software is great to pre prepare half completed slides with diagrams, animations etc for student colaborative completion. I have taught a group of students how to use the software to prepare their own presentations of problems and issues. Then the moodle course area is great to archive or publish the presentaions for critical peer review. I hope some of these ramblings help. Cheers Alex

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Anyone using a pen tablet?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello John, Thank you for starting this very interesting topic! I use a "Graphire.4" tablet (8in x 4in) to produce short tutorial videos for my Math classes. I got into buying it motivated by a really great tool whose "demo" version is free in the Internet. The instructor can produce videos (with audio) in seconds and immediately give to the students a link to the video tutorial. It is so simple and fast, that I have abandonned completely the typing of long answers with MathType in word documents. Here you have a link to a tutorial video I created to answer one of my Internet student's question on how to plot a line on the x-y plane: http://www.yourotherteacher.com/demo/ysevwugfrr/index.html The student needs to have a set of speakers in order to be able to listen to the recorded audio, and of course, the instructor needs a basic "microphone" to record the words... This great tool was created by Jeff Jones ( a Computer pofessor at a California  College).  It can be accessed via: http://www.yourotherteacher.com and there by clicking on the "Try ot now for free" banner. As you would see the set up is very simple and intuitive, and you can try it just by moving your mouse. Once you get all motivated, and want to perfect your style, you will look into a pen tablet system. Jeff was kind enough to upload a couple of basic grids for me, when he learned about my interest on his tool, so you will find included two background options: one for the rectangular x-y grid and another one for polar coordinates. He is developing more and more extra features with time. For example, he has lately included the posibility of using close-caption for the hearing impared. He offers a wide variety of tools and storing features for Schools that buy a license, but there is a lot already available for the free demo users! Hope that many of instructors in this forum would find it as useful as I do. Have fun! Cristina Berisso

ResponsesInList.Title: Getting TeX and Algebra notion working under Windows and Apache
ResponsesInList.Text: As with others on this forum, I had a devil of a time getting math notation filters working under Moodle.  I run installations with Server 2003 and Windows XP running both EasyPhp and XAMPP installations from the Moodle Download site.  In all cases, there were permission problems with the mimetex.exe file. I found the easiest fix was to download a fresh copy from http://download.moodle.org/mimetex/windows/mimetex.exe and replace the copy in the moodle\filter\tex folder.  This sets up appropriate permission to be able to execute the file and now all works fine. I did not find a need to install Pearl as was mentioned elsewhere in this forum.  If you are running IIS rather than Apache under Server 2003, it seems like you may need to alter permissions on at least the cmd.exe file.  See elsewhere in this forum for help on that if needed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Getting TeX and Algebra notion working under Windows and Apache

Why would one be on CVS and the other on download.moodle.org? Any clarification you (or others) might have would be appreciated. Peace.

ResponsesInList.Title: TeX \array{} not parsing correctly
ResponsesInList.Text: I downloaded 17-latest and have been experimenting with some algebra 2 material. In an attempt to get a multiline formula into a single graphic, I wrote an \array{}{}. Ampersands are not being parsed correctly. Example: $$$ \begin{array}{cc} a & b \\ c & d \end{array} $$$ $$ \begin{array}{cc} a & b \\ c & d \end{array} $$ The parser attempts to change & to & before the TeX filter gets a hold of it. All my cells have "amp;" in them. 1. Does anyone have a workaround to get \array{}{} working?

ResponsesInList.Title: Ang: TeX \array{} not parsing correctly
ResponsesInList.Text: Perhaps this thread can give you the answer to your first question (it worked for me): http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=55861 2. The 'array' syntax should work ok then: $$$ \begin{array}{rcl} f(x) & = & \cos{x}\\ f'(x) & = & - \sin x\\ \int_{0}^{x} f({y}) dy & = & \sin{x} \end{array} $$$ $$\begin{array}{rcl} f(x) & = & \cos{x}\\ f'(x) & = & - \sin x\\ \int_{0}^{x} f({y}) dy & = & \sin{x} \end{array}$$ Best regards Morten

ResponsesInList.Title: STACK: Input as a function
ResponsesInList.Text: ,Hi all ,first, thanks a lot to Christopher, Tim and all other collaborators, STACK it is amazing tool and I enjoy write questions in it ?Now for my question there is a way that the student answer will be interpreted as function .For example, if I will ask the student to give me second degree polynomial that p(2)=1 ?How I can check that p(2)=1 Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: Input as a function
ResponsesInList.Text:
If the variable of the polynom is known then you can just evaluate it: 
```text
    ev(ans1, x=2)
```
 and do an algebraic equivalence check against 2. If not, then you first have to extract the variable name using the function listofvars(). 
```text
    ev(ans1, listofvars(p)[1]=2)
```
 Perhaps you have to check that p is an univariate expression at all: length(listofvars(ans1)) must be 1

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: Input as a function
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, Silly me, for hours I am looking for commend to do it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: easy way/tool to create graph/chart
ResponsesInList.Text: The best solution to you query (and yes it is discussed at length) is adding geonext to editor like dragmath. As the focus has been on adding all the math tools to Moodle 2 and tinyMCE we did not bother to publish patches for htmlarea. However, you can also use asciimathml's asciisvg functionality to simply add graphs using text expressions (no applet .) While I think a stable working upgrade path to moodle 2 is still sways off, the math tools available will be extensive. In the interim, you may want to change to tinyMCE in moodle 1.9 and roll out the beta of Maunos plugins If you want to add geonext to htmlarea on your own there are notes in the forum on that and on adding jsxgraph to header or meta files. The tricky bit is purporting a geonext file to the activity so that jsxgraph will parse it. Integration w htmlarea requires parallel tweaks to dragmath (editing two existing files and adding a dialog file)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problem in using Dragmath
ResponsesInList.Text: I am also facing the same problem what vijay is facing. I have installed DragMath. After installing, the dragmath icon is appearing in HTML editor but whenever I insert any equation, it is displaying some $$ symbols. Pls help in this regard and tell me that what is the possible reason for it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problem in using Dragmath
ResponsesInList.Text: Dragmath does not render any maths - it just gives you different output code like LaTeX (TeX) or asciimath and you need some renderer for that code (that changes code to images or for example to MathML) Even if you enable TeX filter from Administration menu it does not mean that moodle could automatically render your TeX notations inside double dollars as mathematical images. If you have given executable mimetex file in folder filter/tex permission to execute (there are different mimetex executable files for each operation system) moodle can usually use that file. If your server has some better distribution of LaTeX installed (TeTeX, TexLive, MikTeX, MacTeX etc) and if you have set correct paths to administration of TeX filter and get your TeX distro with ImageMagick or GhostScript functional you can use a larger variety of TeX commands - mimetex has rather limited set of commands. If you install separately JsMath or AsciiMathML scripts / filters you don't necessarely need TeX based renderer (like Tex filter or LatexRender filter) at all because those scripts use other methods to produce your maths... Dragmath button is not visible in administration of editor unless you edit adminlib.php and add that one row code that Marc has explained in Docs - usually if you want to use Dragmath plugin you won't need to hide it and don't need to edit adminlib.php at all. In moodle 2.0 DragMath will be a part of core files although it will be visible by default only if TeX filter is enabled. Please read http://docs.moodle.org/en/Mathematics and some posts from http://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?id=752

ResponsesInList.Title: [Logic] Stack and load maxima library
ResponsesInList.Text: I would like to use the library logic.mac developped by Alexey Beshenov ( https://github.com/andrejv/maxima/blob/master/share/logic/logic.mac ) and part of the maxima software (we don't need to download it) to handle logic expressions to create stack questions on Moodle. On my maxima desktop, it suffices that I put the instruction : load("logic.mac") to have access to routines of this library. However, in Moodle (where I don't have administration privileged but I can ask them), I got the following message : "load expression is not allowed" I would like to find a way to include this library for my stack questions in Moodle. It seems I would need administration privileged to load this library, can I have some explanations that I could give to my administrator to my administrator ? Likewise, the functions "eval_string" and "parse_string" are not allowed on Moodle whereas I can used them in my optimized version of Maxima proposed by stack. Why do some functions are not available ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: [Logic] Stack and load maxima library
ResponsesInList.Text: Helena, Basically STACK is executing code by students (and teachers) on the server .  It is therefore essential to check that the student's expression (and the teacher's expressions) are not damaging to the server.  For example, try the expression system("touch \"/tmp/helloworld.txt\""); on a command line maxima.  We can't have students and teachers making read/write commands to the server.  Similarly, we can't allow "eval_string" and "parse_string" which would enable people to construct such commands.  I'm guessing you wanted to create a "load" command?! Anyway, things we don't allow anyone to do are here: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/stack/cas/casstring.class.php#L92 It is for this reason what we review contributed Maxima packages before adding them to the list of things we have checked.  There are now over 650 sites running STACK, so we can't just include everything. I will review the logic package. If you want to add load("logic.mac") to your own server the normal place to add it would be around here: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/stack/maxima/stackmaxima.mac#L120 But, things might break... Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: [Logic] Stack and load maxima library
ResponsesInList.Text: Helena, I've created an issue here: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/issues/376 Note, adding in this library creates a lot of failing unit tests.  This may, or may not (!), be easy to address, but for now I recommend you do not add in a load command to your server. Chris

ResponsesInList.Text: Ok I got the restriction necessity. I will check from time to time if there will be a new version of Stack with this logic native library but for now I can prevent from using it. Thank you for your answer (and I would like to thank you for the wonderful work that you did for the Stack project). See you

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ADA comliant tex
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Eric, The TeX filters output images, and the browser zoom functions only enlarge the text size, not the images I'm afraid. At least, that's what I thought until an hour ago when I realised Internet Explorer 7 now enlarges images as well as the text (and now uses that same CTRL-+,CTRL-- keys as Firefox ). There is an inevitable loss of quality as they are enlarged ( IE uses bi-cubic interpolation to calculate the colours of the additional pixels needed). (I'm actually thinking about Maths in Moodle at the moment and hope to post something more next week) Tim

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ADA comliant tex
ResponsesInList.Text: An alternative is to use the jsMath filter rather than the TeX filter. The size of the mathematics will automatically match the size set in your browser, so if you have a very large font selected, the mathematics will match that. Moreover, if your users have the tight fonts installed, then the math will resize automatically when they scale the page (no matter what browser they are using); if they don't have the fonts installed they need to reload the page to get the size to change. In any case, I think this should help your users who need to see larger versions of the mathematics. Davide

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Input type: Matix (or rather the style of it)
ResponsesInList.Text: Chris, It is not actually that difficult to create inputs within a MathJax expression, but it has to be done with the javascript API of MathJax. It can not be done with HTML or TeX notation alone. If you want the create a matrix input type, you would just add some javascript to an algebraic input box would take the contents of the box and convert the maxima syntax to LaTeX or MathML and display that dynamically as the input box is updated (see simple example using asciimath syntax https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=331648#p1400095 ). Listeners can be added to the MathJax image to position cursor by clicking image. Daniel

ResponsesInList.Title: Accessing %rnum_list variable in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm trying to create a question with linear equation system using STACK / Maxima. My system is under-determined, so, Maxima produces variables like %r1 and %r2 in the output. I want to change their names to, for example, C1 and C2. Maxima documentation recommends to use variable %rnum_list for doing so. But when I try to use it, Stack returns an error: % found in expression xot:subst(C1,%rnum_list[1],x). So, how can I use %rnum_list in Stack. (Direct access to %r1 and %r2 returns the same error.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessing %rnum_list variable in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Elena, my workaround for cases like this is: If you have an expression like ta:[1-%r1,%r1] you can substitute C1 for listofvars(ta)[1] in ta. ta:subst(C1,listofvars(ta)[1],ta) Then you don't need to adress %rnum_list directly. Stephan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessing %rnum_list variable in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Many thanks! Your answer solved my problem.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessing %rnum_list variable in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for posting this. We have tried to solve this problem for differential equations with the function `stack_strip_percent(ex,var)` which replaces all variable names starting with `%` with those in `var` . See See https://stack2.maths.ed.ac.uk/demo2018/question/type/stack/doc/doc.php/CAS/Differential_equations.md Can you confirm this also works?  If not, please email me a minimal and specific report and I will look into this further. Chris

As minor enhancement we provide a possible solution for the well-known feature of TeX filter: when someone modify the code, every double escape ('\\') is trasformed into a singol ones ('\'): our hypotesi is that every sequence of double escape is directly followed by a space, and we substitute every ('\ ') with ('\\ ') before passing the code to the filters. ResponsesInList.Title: Subscripts in equations
ResponsesInList.Text: I keep looking, but I can't find anything about using subscripts in equations.  Is it possible?? For instance, the formula for calculating resistance with parallel resistors: $$Rtotal = \frac{1}{(1/R1)+(1/R2)+(1/R3)}$$ I would sure like to have R total , R 1 , R 2 , etc. but nothing I've tried works. Is there a way to do this? Thanks, Dan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Subscripts in equations
ResponsesInList.Text: Subscripts are rendered in TeX using the underscore character. To group several characters into a subscript use braces. $$$ R_{total}=\frac{1}{(1/R_1)+(1/R_2)+(1/R_3)} $$$ --> $$R_{total}=\frac{1}{(1/R_1)+(1/R_2)+(1/R_3)}$$

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Subscripts in equations
ResponsesInList.Text: I thought there had to be a way!! Thank you very much Dan

ResponsesInList.Title: Stack: Using answers from other questions
ResponsesInList.Text: helllo there, i wondered if it is possible to set an answer from one question as variable to use it as input in another question. for example i want my students to measure a cuboid and they also shall write down the measuring error in question 1. In question 2 they shall calculate the volume of the cuboid, so we need the values from question 1 for that. Is that possible? If yes, how? At that point i created a question where you first have to put the measurements, then you can check the results and if correct you can enter the volume and finish the test. But this doesn't feel good nor is it a fluid and intuitive process.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stack: Using answers from other questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Paul, This is perfectly possible within a single multi-part question.  Create two inputs, one for each part. Then you also need two potential response trees.  "Tree 1" will only depend on the first answer.  So, you can choose to give feedback/marks if a student only answers the first part.  "Tree 2" will depend on the first and second answer, allowing you to use both parts and create follow through marking if you choose to. STACK was designed with exactly this kind of thing in mind. There is currently no way for the question to adapt, e.g. to only show part 2 when part 1 is correct.  I've thought about this, but a general mechanism becomes very complex very quickly. Chris

ResponsesInList.Text: Is the path to Latex correct?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: mimeTeX's rendering not working
ResponsesInList.Text:
You need to know which is your host's operating system (Windows? Linux? It seems that your provider works with CENTOS, which is a Linux distribution). Then, you need to know if it has LaTeX installed. IF it was Linux, AND you have access to a shell on the host, then you can issue the command "which latex" and see if LaTeX is installed and where. Anyway, even if there was no LaTeX at all, the filter should work, by using "mimetex.exe" or "mimetex.linux", automatically (both are included in the default Moodle distribution, in .../moode/filter/tex/). I have read in this forum that in some Windows installations you should check if mimetex.exe is not corrupted and if it is executable (I do not use Windows). You could try as well this: http://<your_moodle_installation>/filtex/tex/texdebug.php I did it, on your site, and the result is: 
```text
sh: /home/centralg/public_html/teachclassesonline/filter/tex/mimetex.linux: 
Permission
 denied
The shell command
"/home/centralg/public_html/teachclassesonline/filter/tex/mimetex.linux" -e "/home/centralg/public_html/teachclassesonline/uploaddata/filter/tex/74c2b66b2d2501b77fad711fd1febcf0.gif" '\Large f(x)=\Bigint_{-\infty}^x~e^{-t^2}dt' returned status = 126
File size of mimetex executable /home/centralg/public_html/teachclassesonline/filter/tex/mimetex.linux is 491043
The file permissions are: 100644
The md5 checksum of the file is c294ab11905323bb5cb0f451241bedc1
Image not found!
```
 That means that you should change the permissions on "mimetex.linux" so that is is executable. Good luck!
