ResponsesInList.Title: STACK 2.1 release.
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear all, I'm posting a message to provide an update of our progress in developing the STACK computer aided assessment system.  I appreciate at this time of year people's attention (in the Northern hemisphere at least) is turning to priorities for the summer and upgrades in anticipation of a new academic year in September 2009. Simon and I are coming to the end of a major phase of redevelopment of STACK.  This will result in better, more reliable features and a fuller integration into Moodle.  In particular this phase of development has done the following STACK now uses Moodle's TeX filter to render the mathematics client side.  To use all the features, in particular the use of answer boxes in equations, JSMath is preferred.   (We will stop supporting TtH and TtM in the very near future.) STACK now uses a cache for increased reliability and scalability.  Details of this are online at http://stack.bham.ac.uk/wiki/index.php/Question_state_caching I believe this will address many of the load problems which users of earlier versions of STACK encountered when large classes logged in and all wanted versions of a test.   The cache will also allow better reporting and data analysis, although we have a lot of work remaining to implement all these features. STACK items now include tests for quality control.  In previous versions the teacher had to test items by hand.  This was time consuming, unreliable and difficult to do over random versions.  Now this process is semi-automated with the test items being included with the question when imported and exported.  These are similar to unit tests in software development. Because the development cache had such profound implications for the database design Simon and I have been working in a different branch of the CVS . It would be best not to attempt to install STACK at this time from the HEAD CVS branch! Our tasks are as follows Finish deployment within Moodle, to allow the teacher to undertake all processes though the Moodle interface. Merge branches of the STACK code and prepare a release candidate for STACK 2.1 Upgrade our server http://stack.bham.ac.uk/ with a demonstration. Therefore, we would ask anyone interested in using STACK to be patient for a week while we finish this round of development. Simon and I will post an announcement here as soon as we have code which we are confident others can install and use.   We will still have a large number of small bugs to fix, and also some features to add to smooth the question authoring process through Moodle.  But, we hope this will be a useful contribution in the very near future. Best regards, Chris Sangwin

ResponsesInList.Title: WirisQuizzes Release Notes
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello! Gaspar from the Wiris team here. We want to start making release notes for our Moodle plugins more visible to Moodle admins, and as part of that we will be posting them here. We will also update the plugin pages more regularly. This will be our first post of this type, so any feedback and/or questions are greatly welcome :­). WirisQuizzes Release Notes We advise upgrading your WirisQuizzes installation to the latest version (4.11). In recent product releases, in addition to bug fixes, we have introduced several new features: New features ✨ In a Graphical question with initial content, there is now an option to go back to the initial content In a Graphical question, teachers can now hide auxiliary objects from the Initial Content to prevent them from appearing in the student's graph. In a Graphical question, teachers can now choose whether the labels of the objects will be shown to students. In a Graphical question, teachers can now "lock" the initial content, preventing students from modifying the initial elements on the graph. In a Graphical question with initial content, the "correct answer" animation will now begin with the Initial Content instead of a blank plotter. New tools have been added for perpendicular lines, parallel lines, the mediatrix of a segment, and the midpoint of a segment.. A helper text feature has been added for the graphical answers, enabling tooltips to be shown to the user In a Graphical question, students can now be restricted to drawing points aligned only with the grid of the problem. In questions with “MathType in a modal window” answer type, the modal window can now be moved and resized to avoid blocking the page. Bugs 🐛 CalcMe performance for certain questions involving images in the graphical plotter has been improved. An issue where adding a matrix, deleting it, and creating it again could result in unintended wrong answer correction has been resolved. Validation of certain questions involving multiletter units has been fixed. When a polygon is built on a touchable device, a central point is no longer drawn in the center of the canvas, preventing student confusion. The Auxiliary CalcMe is working as expected again. The answer field in Moodle is showing as expected when using Wiris Quizzes in all layouts. The undo button now works as expected when using the handwriting tool to draw an object in a Graphical answer question type. Switching between Initial Content and Correct Answer is no longer breaking the content edition anymore in some cases A problem when saving the labels' visibility settings has been fixed. Incompatibility problems when using #plotter1_a_b syntax have been fixed. Browser zoom-out issues on plotter/sketch/statistics questions have been fixed improving the presentation of plot elements. Technical tasks ⚙️ Moodle 4.3 compatibility. Provide an API to work around the graphing capabilities of WirisQuizzes. Improved browser memory management for graphical questions. Generic integration for PHP files are now all encoded using UTF-8. Improved compatibility with PHP 8.1 Warning removed from info.php page in Moodle 4.2 and higher.

ResponsesInList.Text: The process.conf file (to date) is below.  Maxima is not yet optimized.  What please should the command line and process started elements be? ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ### Config for this Maxima process # As a sanity check, this must match the name of the containing folder, but not the full path. # Typically this is the name of the version number of the current STACK , e.g. 20160922001 name = 2018080600 # Whether processes of this type should be automatically made available when # the server starts. auto.start = true ### Maxima related commands and parameters # Working directory for the process working.directory = /tmp # Command-line to launch the optimised Maxima process. # This information is given at the end of the STACK healthcheck script.  It will need to be updated # to reflect the move of the optimised image to /var/lib/maxima/%%VERSION%%/ # # Do not include the "timeout" command.  The servlet deals with timeouts itself. # # This will depend on your maxima (and lisp) setup.  E.g. # /usr/lib/clisp-2.49/base/lisp.run -q -M /var/lib/maximapool/%%VERSION%%/maxima_opt_auto.mem # /var/lib/maximapool/%%VERSION%%/maxima-optimised command.line = maxima # Input the load command after this, if defined. process.started = Maxima restarted. # A file to load to maxima using load(""); set to false or empty if not needed extra.file = /shared/maximapool/2018080600/maximalocal.mac # The process has loaded when this appears. process.ready = "/shared/maximapool/2018080600/maximalocal.mac" # Environment variables may be set like this, in most cases you should not need to set them: # env.LANG = C # env.TERM = xterm ### File handling related parameters # these make the difference between shared filesystem installations and truly # separate servers # Do we handle files? file.handling = true # The command template to pass the current working and output directories to the process, use placeholders to mark the paths, depending on your system we may escape \-chars in the path. # Usable placeholders: #  %WORK-DIR% the directory that won't be transferred to the client side #  %WORK-DIR-NE% use this if you do not want \-chars escaped #  %OUTPUT-DIR% the directory that will be transferred to the client side #  %OUTPUT-DIR-NE% use this if you do not want \-chars escaped path.command = maxima_tempdir: "%WORK-DIR%/"$ IMAGE_DIR: "%OUTPUT-DIR%/"$ URL_BASE: "%PLOT- URL -BASE%"$ ### Maximum lifetimes. # This is the time that a process is allowed to take when starting up (ms). startup.timeout = 10000 # This is the time added to the lifetime of a process when it is taken to use # so that it wont be killed while in use (ms). execution.timeout = 30000 # This is the lifetime given to a process (ms). maximum.lifetime = 600000 ### Estimates used to start the pool size planning. # Estimated time to start a process of this type (ms). startup.time.estimate = 2000 # Estimated demand for these processes (number per second). demand.estimate = 0.1

CAS connection timeoutqtype_stack | castimeout Default: 10 The timout to use when trying to connect to Maxima. CAS result cachingqtype_stack | casresultscache Do not cache Cache in the database Default: Cache in the database This setting determines whether calls the to CAS are cached. This setting should be turned on unless you are doing development that involves changing the Maxima code. The current state of the cache is shown on the healthcheck page. If you change your settings, e.g. the gnuplot command, you will need to clear the cache before you can see the effects of these changes. Maxima commandqtype_stack | maximacommand For Platform type: Server, this is must be set to the URL of the Maxima Pool servlet. For other platform types, if this is blank, STACK will make an educated guess as to where to find Maxima. If that fails, this should be set to the full path of the maxima or maxima-optimised executable. Consider using the timeout command on unix based systems. E.g. timeout --kill-after=10s 10s maxima Server username:passwordqtype_stack | serveruserpass Default: Empty If you are using Platform type: Server, and if you have set up your Maxima pool server with HTTP authentication, then you can put the username and password here. That is slighly safer than putting them in the URL. The format is username:password. Plot commandqtype_stack | plotcommand Default: Empty Normally this can be left blank, but if graph plotting is not working, you may need to supply the full path to the gnuplot command here. Load optional Maxima libraries:qtype_stack | maximalibraries This is a comma separated list of Maxima library names which will be automatically loaded into Maxima. Only supported library names can be used: "stats, distrib, descriptive, simplex". These libraries will not be loaded if you have saved a maxima image to optimise performance. CAS debuggingqtype_stack | casdebugging Default: No Whether to store debugging information about the CAS connection.

ResponsesInList.Title: WIRIS breaks MathML?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I'm currently doing some testing with math content in Moodle, using MathJax for display and WIRIS as an editor. As we are using Moodle 2.8, I activated the MathJax filter and updated the settings to use: https://cdn.mathjax.org/mathjax/latest/MathJax.js Then I tried to use WIRIS as an editor for math content, installed both the filter and the Atto plugin. But somehow WIRIS seems to break the MathML. It produces something like this: «math xmlns=¨ http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML ¨»«mo»§#8712;«/mo»«/math» Did anyone experience something similar? What is the best configuration to use both MathJax (because of their accessibility features) and WIRIS? Regards, Björn

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: WIRIS breaks MathML?
ResponsesInList.Text: WIRIS plugin stores formulas in Moodle with a slightly modified MathML code that we call safeXML. SafeXML is plain MathML changing some characters: http://www.wiris.com/en/plugins/docs/resources/encoding-attributes . You can configure the plugin to store formulas as MathML instead of safeXML setting wiriseditorsavemode= xml in your plugin's configuration.ini file ( http://www.wiris.com/plugins/docs/resources/configuration-table ). In order to edit the formulas using WIRIS you need to keep both WIRIS and MathJax filters enabled, however, due to an issue with Moodle's filter order in combination with our plugin and MathJax, you need to manually uncomment the filter in /wiris/filter.php. Please note that this is a workaround until we fix the order issue in future WIRIS plugin versions.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: WIRIS breaks MathML?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for the explanation. Unfortunatly it didn't solve the issues I experienced.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: WIRIS breaks MathML?
ResponsesInList.Text: The order issue is now fixed on our latest filter/plugin release, so enabling wiriseditorsavemode=xml and ordering the filters accordingly formulas could be rendered by MathJax if you prefer.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: WIRIS - What exactly is free?
ResponsesInList.Text: The pluginwiris-package that integrates the Wiris math editor into the Moodle HTML-editor is free. For a while the math editor (which is a Java -archive that is not included in the integration package) was free as well. I had everything installed and working in Moodle 1.8. Now the math editor is not available for free anymore. At least I wasn't able to find it on the Wiris website. Wiris breaks the switch (<>-button) from WYSIWYG -mode to HTML-mode in 1.8 and 1.9.1. Once you have used the button, you cannot switch into HTML-mode for a second time. As an alternative to Wiris, you might want to try the DragMath-plugin.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: WIRIS - What exactly is free?
ResponsesInList.Text: Today we noticed a little problem with the download of a ZIP file. In a few hours (in the morning at our offices in Barcelona) the problem will be solved.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: WIRIS - What exactly is free?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Melissa, I am Ramon Eixarch from Maths for More, company responsible for WIRIS tools. WIRIS Plugin, that is the component connecting your Moodle with our tools WIRIS Editor and WIRIS CAS, is free. That components is useless without being linked to commercial components. WIRIS Editor and WIRIS CAS are commercial products. We offer them as a hosted service for reasonable prices . Those services can also be hosted in your server . It is only reasonable to host the service in your server if you are running a quite big Moodle installation. We offer a FREE DEMO service of WIRIS Editor and WIRIS CAS for everybody to easily test our tools. You can use it as long as you want to test the application. PS: In some regions the government offers free access to WIRIS CAS or WIRIS Editor. That makes it free for schools to use WIRIS Tools.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: WIRIS - What exactly is free?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: WIRIS - What exactly is free?
ResponsesInList.Text: (Next post is ENGLISH version) Hola David, en el caso de una escuela de 2000 alumnos nuestra recomendación es el uso de la versión en hosting. La versión instalada en tu servidor está pensada para universidades o grandes instalaciones de Moodle (en particular su coste). Pides poder descargar WIRIS CAS y me comentas que ya has instalado WIRIS Editor. Debes ser consciente que has descargado solo una parte del sistema de edición de fórmulas. Cada vez que se genera una fórmula se hace una llamada a un web service de imágenes residente en www.wiris.net Sobre la gratuidad. Nuestra política es que las escuelas que hacen un uso reducido del sistema no se les reclama el pago de licencia. Al ofrecer el sistema en modalidad de hosting esto nos permite controlar el del servicio en los distintos servidores.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: WIRIS - What exactly is free?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi David, In the case of a school of 2000 students our recommendation is to use the hosted version. The version installed on your server is meant for universities or large installations of Moodle (including from cost point of view). You ask about downloading WIRIS CAS to your server and tell me that you've installed WIRIS Editor. Be aware that you have downloaded only part of the editing system of formulas. Each time you create a formula there is a call to an image web service resident in www.wiris.net About FREE use of WIRIS tools. Our policy is not to request a license to schools making a reduced use of the service. We keep track of the use of the service since the web service is offered from our servers.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle 2 and the future of the Algebra Filter
ResponsesInList.Text: As has been repeatedly noted, the current Algebra filter is simply a retrofit if you will of the webworks parser and though I have sought feedback in the past, it appears that it simply affords a tex subset. The question is why it should exist as a separate filter if it simply provide a tex subset. It would seem that providing the ability to read the previously employed tokens to a replacement, that Moodle 2 can be further realigned (i.e. we can continue to parse tex using the @ without having to use the algebra filter. One option I have noted elsewhere is to replace the webworks parser with latexml (see, http://dlmf.nist.gov/LaTeXML/ ) , which is also perl and provides full tex to mathml. One could employ the @ with latexml and the $ with the tex filter and that way natively support mathml in Moodle. This would provide tex via dvi using $, tex via mathml using @ and potentially both via asciimathml if you want to be able to provide students (and teachers) with the ability to write text expressions in asciimath and use the svg features that have been incorporated there.... There are a number of obvious issues in looking at such a change: 1) does algebra filter usage actually deviate somehow from tex usage, 2) to what degree is the state of latexml potentially inadequate for Moodle usage, 3) would licensing present any issues (latexml was developed by folk at NIST, 4) would we be better off simply dropping the algebra filter and including the @ token in the tex filter as a step towards deprecation?

ResponsesInList.Title: Text Expression Syntax
ResponsesInList.Text: Based on Christina's post I searched Webworks and found these two links for using webworks text expressions (the first one is arguably replaced by the second): http://webwork.math.rochester.edu/docs/docs/pglanguage/availableFunctions.html http://webwork.maa.org/wiki/Mathematical_notation_recognized_by_WeBWorK Is this usage consistent with your experience? Are there any other specifics that anyone else wants to add? For example, I note the absence of the nth root but have found instructional material elsewhere on the web which suggests that webworks uses the same notation as mathematica (i.e. $$x^{1\over n}$$ for $$\sqrt[n]{x}$$ ). Is this a subset of a more widely known syntax? Can other systems provide competent parsing of the syntax more economically (for example, can this also be parsed by asciimathml for example)? How did the webworks system decide upon this system and to what extent will webworks remain with such syntax?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2 and the future of the Algebra Filter
ResponsesInList.Text: Though my International Baccalaureate high school students are likely unaware of how this works, they're happy to be able to enter expressions in the familiar "Texas Instruments 83/84-family calculator" format [ e.g. (x-1)/(x+1)^2 ], and have them appear as TeX-rendered expressions in Moodle. Here is "(x-1)/(x+1)^2" enclosed by double @ symbols: @@(x-1)/(x+1)^2@@ " 'Nice to not have to know the TeX (\frac{}..., etc.) for this", my students would say if asked. Several "TeX-generating" applications compete with the algebra filter, such as DragMath , Sitmo , and CodeCogs . In the majority of our actual use cases, however, Moodle's algebra filter is the easiest way for students to produce the nice TeX output. It's my hope that the algebra filter will remain in place until and unless the same behavior (i.e. proper TeX expressions from "calculator-style" expression input) is produced—at least as efficiently—by some other filter or feature of Moodle . Sincerely, Tom Mellin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2 and the future of the Algebra Filter
ResponsesInList.Text: As a newcomer to the idea of TeX and completely at sea with the various components and varieties of the Algebra and Tex filters, I cannot understand why there are two. Does the TeX filter do the job or not? Obviously not, otherwise, why have an Algebra filter? If it does not do the job required, then why include it? Is Moodle trying to be all things to all people? This is not Ford or GM, why should Moodle need to be? If I am sensing the drift of v2.0 there is a number of things that are essentially adapted from other, existing apps, TinyMCE NWiki, et al, so why not the TeX filter?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: fractions and parenthesis
ResponsesInList.Text: $$88(121)-\frac{88(120)}{44}$$ 88(121)-\frac{88(120)}{44} http://www.artofproblemsolving.com/LaTeX/AoPS_L_GuideCommands.php Notice that \ commands will take their arguments in curly braces There are things that won't work in Moodle (see below), but that is another story....

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: fractions and parenthesis
ResponsesInList.Text: hmm.. I was asking more where the numerator is 88(121)-88(120) and the denominator is just 44. How would I do that? Also, I am unable to show what you have there... If I write 88(121)-\frac{88(120)}{44} here it will show it that way... but not when I do that to my moodle site. My tex filter and algebra filter are borh enabled..

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: fractions and parenthesis
ResponsesInList.Text: Have you installed some distribution of TeX http://www.ctan.org/starter.html or given permission to execute filter/tex/Mimetex.xxx (xxx depends on your server operating system and the quality is not as good as in fully functional LaTeX) \frac{88(121)-88(120)}{44} $$\frac{88(121)-88(120)}{44}$$

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: fractions and parenthesis
ResponsesInList.Text: thats interesting... I think I do have to check up on my server. If I write \frac{88(121)-88(120)}{44} here, it doesn't show anything.. And I don't understand why I need to download tex? Inst it already in the code? Is it a program? Iv been doing it all this time without downloading anything..

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: fractions and parenthesis
ResponsesInList.Text: Well you need those double dollars around TeX: $ $ \frac{88(121)-88(120)}{44}$ $ (without spaces) gives $$\frac{88(121)-88(120)}{44}$$ Mimetex in folder filter/tex is a minimal version of TeX - it works and you can see some examples in http://www.forkosh.com/mimetex.html If you want to get better quality, different packages of TeX that are missing from Mimetex you may consider installing a larger distribution of TeX. For basic use Mimetex is ok.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: fractions and parenthesis
ResponsesInList.Text: Frank, I don't know if Jeff got his LateX to work but http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=113071 has some examples for troubleshooting. I think that the most common reason for failure is that executable file producing tex is not allowed to execute (permissions) but you can probably find it out using debugging. Read that thread.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: fractions and parenthesis
ResponsesInList.Text: ...and TeX / LaTeX may have different syntax in different TeX distributions so it's good to find documentation about your own TeX version.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathJax v2.5 released
ResponsesInList.Text: MathJax 2.5 has now been released. Has significant performance improvements. So, you may wish to update your Moodle MathJax filter configuration to the following: Site administration > Plugins > Filters > MathJax HTTP MathJax URL : http://cdn.mathjax.org/mathjax/2.5-latest/MathJax.js (specifically for MathJax 2.5) or http://cdn.mathjax.org/mathjax/latest/MathJax.js (for the latest stable MathJax version, currently 2.5) HTTPS MathJax URL: https://cdn.mathjax.org/mathjax/2.5-latest/MathJax.js or https://cdn.mathjax.org/mathjax/latest/MathJax. or you can use the protocol agnostic equivalents for both: //cdn.mathjax.org/mathjax/2.5-latest/MathJax.js //cdn.mathjax.org/mathjax/latest/MathJax. In addition to the performance improvements, MathJax 2.5 is now compatible with NodeJS ( MathJax-node ). This raises the possibility of a server -side implementation of MathJax as an alternative to the existing TeX filter. Something for Moodle 2.9? 3.0?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Piecewise functions
ResponsesInList.Text: Which renderer is it? For example in latex you can use something like f(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{lr} 1 & : x \in \mathbb{Q}\\ 0 & : x \notin \mathbb{Q} \end{array} \right. to render $$ f(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{lr} 1 & : x \in \mathbb{Q}\\ 0 & : x \notin \mathbb{Q} \end{array} \right. $$

ResponsesInList.Title: Patternmatics, a step-by-step equation solving CAS
ResponsesInList.Text: In June of 2011 Chris Sangwin told me he was interested in software that could do step-by-step equation solving. Since that time I have been working on creating an open source, JavaScript -based CAS (Computer Algebra System) that is capable of doing semi-automatic and fully-automatic step-by-step equation solving. It is being designed for use in demonstrations, exercises, and assessments. Here are some examples that show a prototype of this CAS solving equations that contain a single copy of the unknown (I had to remove the http:// from this URL , because this is my first forum post and the forum only permits one URL in an initial post): patternmatics.com/examples/expressions/stepbystep/single_unknown/ A student must have a clear understanding of the structure of mathematical expressions before they can successfully interact with a step-by-step CAS. Therefore, the first features I am implementing in the CAS are related to teaching this structure in a visual way. This is what I have working so far: http://patternmatics.com/test/expression_structure.html I am thinking about integrating this software with Moodle in some way. Is anyone in this forum interested in this idea? Ted Kosan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Patternmatics, a step-by-step equation solving CAS
ResponsesInList.Text: Ted, This is very exciting work.  I think, having some elementary CAS in javascript would be a very valuable project. This kind of functionality has been done before, although sadly some of the work is now trapped in legacy code.  It would be great to have this kind of functionality available in Moodle for our students to use. For people who've not looked into this before The software Aplusix has the kind of "reasoning by equivalence" which Ted refers to here. http://www.aplusix.com/ The authors of this software have thought a lot about editing algebraic expressions, e.g. http://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/docs/00/59/15/53/PDF/Nicaud-JeanFrancois-2008.pdf The work of Michael Beeson on MathXpert is inspirational, and should be essential reading.  See http://www.helpwithmath.com/ and his paper http://www.michaelbeeson.com/research/papers/hisc.pdf is a good place to start. The Numbas people ( http://www.ncl.ac.uk/maths/numbas/ ) are also working on a Javascript CAS.  I wonder if there is any milage in collaborating with them? Thank you very much for the reference to Patrick Thompon's interesting paper. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Patternmatics, a step-by-step equation solving CAS
ResponsesInList.Text: Chris, I would add Alan Bundy's research to the list of sources you provided. In 2011 you told me about Alan Bundy's book "The Computer Modeling of Mathematical Reasoning", and I think you became aware of this book because it is listed as a reference in Michael Beeson's paper you linked to in your post. A .pdf version of this book, along with most of Alan Bundy's research papers, can be found here: http://patternmatics.com/research/research.html Alan Bundy and his research group at the University of Edinburgh developed an AI-based step-by-step equation solving system named PRESS (PRolog Equation Solving System), and it was the focus of much of their work in the 1970s and 1980s. The final version of PRESS was the result of over 10 years of research, and it was capable of solving most of the equations that were present on A-level examinations at the time. The CAS I am building is based upon Alan Bundy's research and PRESS. I updated the PRESS source code so it would run on a modern implementation of Prolog, and I am in the process of reverse engineering it. Alan Bundy still teaches at the University of Edinburgh. He has been assisting me by providing me with additional information related to PRESS that is difficult to obtain on the Internet. Ted

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Patternmatics, a step-by-step equation solving CAS
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ted. I am "the Numbas people" Chris referred to. I've done a fair amount of work on parsing and rewriting mathematical expressions, but nothing on equation solving. The Numbas source code is online at https://github.com/numbas/Numbas . In particular, the mathematical parser/evaluator is in runtime/scripts/jme.js and the code for rewriting expressions is in runtime/scripts/jme-display.js . I think the Numbas parser is a bit more sophisticated than the Khan Academy parser you're using, so it might be worth taking a look at. In fact, I did some work for the OU a while ago supporting someone to make the parser work standalone, but that didn't end up going anywhere. Maybe it's worth having another go at that! At the moment it lives inside a rather clunky script-loading system; it should really be a single JS file that you can drop in without much setup. Anyway, you'll probably be interested in the expression rewriting system I have. It's mainly used to make randomly generated expressions look more like the way a human would write them, but it could be twisted to do step-by-step equation solving. At the bottom of jme-display.js, there's a big list of "simplification rules".These are pattern-matching rules working on trees - each rule specifies a syntax tree to match, as well as conditions on the leaves/subtrees, and then gives a new tree pattern to rewrite the expression as. Something I would like to do, and I'd be interested in collaborating with someone on, is making this pattern-matching system more powerful. I'd like to work towards a kind of regular expression algorithm for syntax trees, which could do things like match repeated groups, or account for the commutativity/associativity/distributivity of operations explicitly. For example, I'd like to be able to say "collect all constant terms together" in a single step, rather than the bubble-sort that the system currently does by repeatedly applying the rule "variables go on the left of constants".

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Patternmatics, a step-by-step equation solving CAS
ResponsesInList.Text: Christian, The parser/evaluator in jme.js is significantly more sophisticated than the parser I am currently using. The expression rewriting system in jme-display.js looks like it is very useful, and I especially like the way pattern-matching rules are defined in it. I think there is quite a bit I can use in this code. Thank you for making me aware of it. The pattern-matching system I have been using for my prototype work is the one that is in the MathPiper CAS. However, it is a fairly simple pattern matcher that does not “know” about the commutativity and associativity of addition and multiplication. PRESS has two pattern matchers. The simpler matcher (which is the one it uses by default) is aware of the commutativity and associativity of addition and multiplication. A more powerful experimental matcher was also created for PRESS, and it is described in the following paper: http://www.research.ed.ac.uk/portal/en/publications/using-matching-in-algebraic-equation-solving%28dd8c9205-12f6-4512-a79e-325c2d9d6420%29.html I am going to attempt to make a JavaScript version of the simpler PRESS pattern matcher for the CAS I am building. If I am successful, this pattern matcher might be of use in Numbas. Ted

You can then use it as you would any MathType equation -- in Word, PowerPoint, Excel, etc. We have an article on Using MathType With Moodle that discusses this. Bob

ResponsesInList.Title: Problems with implementing a jsMath filter
ResponsesInList.Text: As noted in a previous thread, I've implemented an experimental filter on my server using jsMath.  On the positive side, it seems to work pretty well with common TeX expressions, particularly when viewed with IE Here are some examples: https://webwork2.math.ohio-state.edu/moodle1_2/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=864&parent=2216&username=guest https://webwork2.math.ohio-state.edu/moodle1_2/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=839&parent=2142&username=guest https://webwork2.math.ohio-state.edu/moodle1_2/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=848&parent=2181&username=guest https://webwork2.math.ohio-state.edu/moodle1_2/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=797&parent=2050&username=guest On the other hand, there are incompatibilities with the previous TeX filter based on mimeTeX.  This is best seen by looking at Andreas' TeX glossary. Here's the original mimeTeX rendering: http://emathpool.net/mod/glossary/view.php?id=178 and here's the jsMath rendering: https://webwork2.math.ohio-state.edu/moodle1_2/mod/glossary/view.php?id=3345

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problems with implementing a jsMath filter
ResponsesInList.Text: I've now uploaded the jsMath filter into the cvs .  It is in the contrib/jstex directory and should be available via anonymous cvs soon.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problems with implementing a jsMath filter
ResponsesInList.Text: It dawned on me that an unscrupulous person might use the algebra or tex filters to slip profainity past the content-filters...not anything a student is going to do anytime soon....but the new js should prevent this. This stuff is just too cool. Zig....great work on all of this....pick out anything you like from the online moodle store...my treat. Mark

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problems with implementing a jsMath filter
ResponsesInList.Text: Davide Cervone has updated his jsMath Javascripts to provide a compatibility mode for mimeTeX. This resolves most of the above-noted difficulties. I have uploaded these modifications into the CVS and updated my Moodle server. Davide also informs me that the problems Andreas experienced with Netscape/Mozilla is due to a bug in Mozilla's font handling and that the simplest way to deal with this is to resize the browser window slightly.

ResponsesInList.Title: Entering the set of the real numbers in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, in
questions where students have to find the solution set of an
equation it would be helpful if they could also enter the set of
the real numbers, namely in a way, that Maxima also realizes it as a set. The point is, that I would like to set Check_Type to true in the input options. Then the students have to enter a set and not a list or a single solution. But next to the empty set {} and any finite set like {1,2,3} also the set of the real numbers should be accepted. I was thinking of recommending "all" as the proper answer if the solution set was the set of the real numbers, but "all" is no set in Maxima. Therefore if I then use the option Check_Type the students will not be allowed to enter a regular set and I basicly give away the solution, if I don't use the option Check_Type some will probably not type any set. Is there any solution to this? Stephan.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Entering the set of the real numbers in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Stephan, I have already started work on better support for sets of real numbers, and yes "all" is already accepted by ATAlgEquiv to mean the set of all real numbers. Could I ask you to look at the equivalence reasoning test cases, as many of these issues are documented there.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Entering the set of the real numbers in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Chris, this helped. If I understand it correctly, then, if I check the students answer type, "all" and "none" are considered to be the same type of object as an equation or inequality. Therefore these symbols can easily be used as part of an equivalence reasoning. But if the teachers answer is a set then the option of checking the students answer type will not accept "all" as a valid answer. Stephan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Entering the set of the real numbers in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Stephen, The relevant unit tests for the Algebraic Equivalence answer test are here: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/tests/fixtures/answertestfixtures.class.php#L274 So, there is no "set" as a teacher's answer which is equivalent to "all", but if the teacher has "x=x" then this is equivalent to "all". I'm very willing to discuss all this further, if you would like to propose sensible behavior if it is missing.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Entering the set of the real numbers in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Chris, this is good to know - I had seen this under the equivfixtures. My idea was, that it would be great if one could create an input where only a real set (such as checked by realsetp) was accepted. Because then anything which syntactically actually is a set could be entered but nothing else and you leave it up to the student how the set is structured. Stephan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Entering the set of the real numbers in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes Stephan, We are about to refactor the input mechanism, and I think some much more flexible "type checking" will be part of that.  There are lots of situations where we want to provide a context in interpreting the student's answer.  Matti's hard work on the new parser make this all much more achievable now. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Entering the set of the real numbers in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: This sounds good. Thanks for your hard work! Stephan

ResponsesInList.Title: Survey of STACK use
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear all, STACK is a computer aided assessment system for mathematics. ( http://stack.bham.ac.uk/wiki/ ) The current version is integrated into Moodle. I know from the volume of email I receive that STACK is being widely used, in some places by large numbers of students. E.g. up to 4000 users at a single site. However, while companies have data on customers, open source software is available for free download . To get a better idea of the extent to which STACK is being used with students I would invite you to take part in a short survey: http://www.surveymonkey.com/s/35QQVH3 I appreciate the value of your time, but it would assist me greatly in making a case for future funding to support the development of STACK if current users could provide me with some details of their usage. For colleagues who have looked at STACK but decided not to make use of it, I would very much like to know why they have chosen not to do so. In releasing the STACK computer aided assessment system we invited colleagues to join the STACK online community http://stack.bham.ac.uk/course/view.php?id=16 Those people who use, or are interested in, STACK are again invited to join and contribute to this site. If you would like to contact me directly about STACK, rather than completing the survey, then please feel free to do so. Thank you. Chris Sangwin C.J.Sangwin@bham.ac.uk

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Survey of STACK use
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear all, I'd like to thank all those who took part in the survey. STACK is clearly useful to a large number of students. Executive summary STACK is a computer aided assessment system for mathematics which makes use of the computer algebra system Maxima to generate random questions, establish the properties of answers and to provide sophisticated mathematical feedback. This document reports the results of a survey of who uses STACK and the extent of this use. Ten sites responded to the survey to report their use of STACK. The code base is sufficiently reliable for regular use with very large (> 1000) groups of students. STACK is available in English and has been translated into Finnish and Japanese. The most significant barrier to use was the difficulty in installing STACK, both for evaluation and for deployment.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Survey of STACK use
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Chris, I been very busy doing websites.  Stack is a great tool for teaching mathematics.  It integrates into Moodle. The only bad thing is the installation.  If anyone needs help send me an e-mail.  I do have it working on a $10 a month server .  No root access.

ResponsesInList.Title: Release of STACK 3.6 and STACK 4.0.
ResponsesInList.Text: It gives me great pleasure to announce the release of two new versions of STACK . ** STACK 3.6 ** STACK 3.6 represents a major new release.  The most significant feature is the new "line by line working". This enables students to solve an equation (or simple real single variable inequality) by progressively transforming their expression.  STACK accepts the entire argument, and establishes various properties such as "are all lines equivalent?", "is the last line in 'solved' form?" and so on.  I will write more about this feature in a separate email, but it represents the first significant step into full automation of students' free-form working. These features include a very large (bewildering perhaps) array of design choices.  I have released a *minimum* working product which automates line by line reasoning.  The intention is to work with students and teachers over the next year to identify the key features needed, and the most sensible ways of using this facility.  For example, is immediate feedback on each line of working actually helpful, or just a distraction?  We need to undertake some detailed research to better understand these issues, and I would very much welcome collaboration in pursing this aspect of online assessment use. ** STACK 4.0 ** STACK 4.0 represents a major new release and brings important developments in a parallel fork of STACK back into the main master branch.  These developments have been written by colleagues at Aalto in Finland, and I am very grateful for there significant contributions and ongoing collaboration.   These features have been widely tested in the parallel fork of STACK. In addition to the features in STACK 3.6, STACK 4.0 adds "question blocks".  Question blocks are conditional statements within the CAS text.  This will allow the text seen by students to adapt in highly non-trivial ways to the random variables, with whole blocks of text being revealed or hidden.  Looping structures enable the automatic generation of code which can be interpreted by Javascript which generates diagrams.  The architecture of the question blocks is very flexible and extensible.  I am only now beginning to appreciate the possibilities of this design.  Watch this space. STACK 4.0 is tagged as v4.0 and is available from the master branch.  This will be installed by default as it is the branch being supporting in the future. ** Why two separate releases? ** For the first time in many years we have changed some of the question authoring mechanism in STACK.  Instead of including CAS statements with @...@ question authors are now required to use {@...@}.  The extra curly braces enable better matching, and more reliable parsing which were essential in the question block engineering.  We have also introduced {#...#} to embed the *Maxima value* and not the *LaTeX representation.  For example, {@sin(n%pi)@}-> \sin(n\pi) whereas {#sin(n*%pi)#} -> sin(n*pi).  This is essential for communication with other software (e.g. chart generation) which needs a more formal syntax and does not accept LaTeX. Users upgrading from STACK 3.X to STACK 4.0 will find that existing questions need to be converted to the new syntax before they will function correctly.  We have developed an automatic conversion script which I have used reliably on our materials, but this is such an important step that I have decided to enforce a manual review before converted questions are saved.  Therefore, admins upgrading servers will need to work with question authors to facilitate this change! ** Future plans ** The University of Edinburgh will be using STACK 4.0 in the 2017-18 academic cycle.  I will support STACK 3.6 over the next academic cycle with bug fixes etc.  Anyone requiring support for STACK 3.X beyond June 2018 should contact me privately to discuss this further.  New features will only be added (by me) to STACK 4.X, Bug fixes etc. will be supported here: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/tree/version3.6 While the line by line features will undergo further active development over the next year (and hence may change in STACK 4.1) the other features, including the blocks, are stable and I hope existing users continue to find STACK a useful and reliable assessment tool. I'd like to thank the team of translators who have translated the language packs in the STACK plugin. I very much welcome collaboration, and contributions.  Examples of questions, research studies, contributions to the documentation (e.g. examples of how to author particular questions) are easy to contribute without having to develop code. Comments welcome. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Passing STACK variables to questions without TeX rendering: Is it possible?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I was wondering if it was possible to pass variables from STACK to the question text without rendering them as TeX. I would like to generate diagrams in SVG or canvas based on the variables used in the question, but this is impossible if the variable is passed as a chunk of code to be rendered as a graphic. For example, say I want to draw a diagram with variables aX and aY representing the endpoint of a vector \(\vec{A}=a_x\hat{\imath}+a_y\hat{\jmath}\) drawn from the origin. I would like to pass these values into a script that draws the vector without all the html surrounding it. I've thought about writing a small script that searches for where the figure is rendered and pulls the variable out, but there has to be an easier way than that. I know this is possible to pull off with the "Calculated" question types in Quizzes, but since STACK doesn't talk to other question types, I'd end up having to stick with one question type over another. Any and all help would be greatly appreciated. Thanks for reading! Cheers, Peter

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Passing STACK variables to questions without TeX rendering: Is it possible?
ResponsesInList.Text: Update: After some fiddling around, here was my best shot at a solution. Really, it's a modification of the code shown in the Geogebra tutorial by Andreas Schenkel. I had to create a work-around since "MathJax-Element-x" doesn't show up after my question is rendered, so my script is looking for elements that, as far as it could see, didn't exist. I also admit that I'm new to using jQuery (like, really new) so I may just be missing some simple solution. Anyways, here goes. I wrapped each variable whose value I want to extract with span tags and gave them an id. So, if the variable was {@a@}, I gave it the id aNum , i.e. {@a@} At the end of the question, I added a script that extracted the text from the element and then removed the curly brackets (since each value showed up like {x.xx}, where x.xx is the number I want). The code looks something like this, in case anyone is interested. From there, I have the variable to use in plots or whatever else I like. It's probably not the most elegant solution, but it seems to work at the moment. Thoughts? Cheers, Peter

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Passing STACK variables to questions without TeX rendering: Is it possible?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Peter, you can pass variables from STACK to the question text by including them in curly brackets and number signs, such as `{#a#}` . STACK is also supporting JSXGraph for dynamic graphing, which gives a quick and easy solution. Stephan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Passing STACK variables to questions without TeX rendering: Is it possible?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Stephan! I'm still learning about STACK (and now JSXGraph, too), but at least it's nice to know I don't have to use brute force on everything. Another simple question: Before I dive in, is JSXGraph set up on Moodle or will I have to contact IT at my college? Cheers, Peter

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Passing STACK variables to questions without TeX rendering: Is it possible?
ResponsesInList.Text: It's integrated in STACK, so you shouldn't need an other plugin to start. There is an extra Moodle filter though if you want to use it outside of STACK, e.g. in a text field or an other question type. Stephan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stack: validation of answer deletes zeroes
ResponsesInList.Text: Please change the input type to "numerical".  That should work. You can also use the options in this input type to require a min/max number of significant places.  Useful in other circumstances to ensure you have enough information to make a judgement. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stack: validation of answer deletes zeroes
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you. Changing the input to numerical worked well, but i'm wondering how i would use the options for significant places? Could you give me an example please?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stack: validation of answer deletes zeroes
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, Sometimes you ask the student for the answer to an applied question, and they only give two significant figures.  This (in context ) does not give you sufficient information to decide if they are correct, and actually they are marked incorrect.  So, while they have done everything correctly the student gets penalised on a technicality. Using this option allows you to reject the answer as being invalid because there are insufficient numbers of significant figures.  The student (who has the calculation in front of them...) can type in a couple of extra places and demonstrate they can do this problem.  Even if the question says "give your answer to 4 significant figures", (or the student should know from the context) people often forget.  If sig figs/dps isn't the point of the question I think this can be unfair.  But it is up to the teacher in context to decide. Not what you are looking for here, but a very useful addition to the STACK validation functionality for physics, stats and applied maths. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Blackboard bold characters with \mathbb
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Davide, I have just installed your AMSsymbols and boldsymbols plugins and they work great. Perhaps the comments in jsmath/ javascript .php should alert the user to the possibility of just adding these to the loadFiles array in the configuration section. I would have preferred if the blackboard bold characters that are supplied by the boldsymbols plugin had been assigned to the macro \mathbb as is usually the case. The \boldsymbol macro usually has a different use: it provides bold numbers, symbols and greek letters that can not be obtained via \mathbf. I was now wondering whether I can simply define the \mathbb macro myself so that it gives the blackboard bold symbols, inspite of the fact that this macro is already defined as a synonym for \mathbf in jsMath.js

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blackboard bold characters with \mathbb
ResponsesInList.Text: I would have preferred if the blackboard bold characters that are supplied by the boldsymbols plugin had been assigned to the macro \mathbb as is usually the case. The \boldsymbol macro usually has a different use: it provides bold numbers, symbols and greek letters that can not be obtained via \mathbf. The blackboard bold symbols are actually provided by the `AMSsymbols` extension, not the `boldsymbol` extension, and `AMSsymbols` defines `\Bbb` for accessing the blackboard bold symbols. They are part of the `msbm` font, and it turns out that when `msbm` is loaded, it does redefine `\mathbb` to do blackboard board. But that only occurs when the `msbm` font is actually loaded, and the `AMSsymbols` extension doesn't actually load it, it only sets things up so that it will be loaded when needed. Unfortunately, that means that `\mathbb` is left as its jsMath default, which is to act as `\mathbf` . This is a bug, and I will fix the `AMSsymbols` extension to redefine `\mathbb` initially. You can add that yourself by editing `jsMath/extensions/AMSsymbols.js` ; go to the bottom of the file and duplicate the third line from the bottom (that defines `\Bdd` ) and change ' `Bdd` ' to ' `mathbb` ' in the duplicate. That should do it. As for `\boldsymbol` , I think it does what you suggest it should: it makes bold numbers, greek letters and other symbols , and has nothing to do with blackboard bold.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blackboard bold characters with \mathbb
ResponsesInList.Text: Ah, thanks for the explanation. I don't know why I was confused about the purpose of the boldsymbol extension. And many thanks also for changing the AMSsymbols extension so that it redefines \mathbb.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blackboard bold characters with \mathbb
ResponsesInList.Text: Perhaps the comments in jsmath/javascript.php should alert the user to the possibility of just adding these to the loadFiles array in the configuration section. They would also need to download the image font definitions for these plugins and install them on the server (and users should download the TTF files for them), so it's not just a matter of adding the plugins to the javascript.php file. This process is documented in the README.txt file for the jsmath filter, so I didn't think it needed to be repeated there. Also, the contents of the javascript.php file is sent to every user as part of moodle's javascript-mod.php file, and so any extra comments there will increase the network traffic. Davide

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blackboard bold characters with \mathbb
ResponsesInList.Text:
I was now wondering whether I can simply define the \mathbb macro myself so that it gives the blackboard bold symbols, inspite of the fact that this macro is already defined as a synonym for \mathbf in jsMath.js It is certainly possible to make your own custom macro file that is loaded automatically by jsMath. One way would be to create a directory `moodle/filter/jsmath/jsMath/local` and put a file there called `local.js` that includes the definitions that you want to have performed automatically. For example, if this file contains 
```text
      jsMath.Macro('mathbb','{\\msbm #1}',1);
```
 then that would define `\mathbb` to do the blackboard bold that you were requesting. Once you create `local/local.js` add it to your `javascript.php` file in the `loadFiles` array along with `extensions/AMSsymbols.js` and `extensions/boldsymbol.js` . Of course, we are adding this to `AMSsymbols.js` itself, so there is no need for this particular definition, but this is for future reference. Davide

ResponsesInList.Title: Redefining macros
ResponsesInList.Text: Do macro definitions that I make in my local.js file overwrite definitions made in the other files or can they conflict?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Redefining macros
ResponsesInList.Text: They replace existing macros, if any. The order you load extensions can affect the results (the last one defined is the one that counts). Note that there are some macros that are autoloaded only when needed, and that some of the extension files that define these define more than one macro, so if you override one of those, it is possible that your definition will be replaced later when the file is autoloaded by one of the other macros in the extension file. If you see what I mean. Davide

ResponsesInList.Title: State of The Math Message

Thanks, Bryan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: State of The Math Message
ResponsesInList.Text: The TeX and Algebra filters provide the infrastructure to display mathematical expressions within any part of Moodle. The Algebra filter employs a simpler syntax, similar to the display format of Texas Instruments graphing calculators and should be adequate for the range of mathematical expressions encountered in secondary school and early college level mathematics and science courses. To trigger the filter, enclose the expression within double @'s: @@@expression@@@ To escape the filter enclose the expression within triple @'s: @@@@expression@@@@. Some basic examples of algebra syntax are shown here: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=5402 The TeX filter employs the TeX notation for typesetting mathematics introduced by Don Knuth in 1982, which has become the standard for mathematics publishing at the university level. Its syntax is more complex than that used by the algebra filter, but it can accomodate the full range of mathematical expressions. To trigger the filter, enclose the expression within double $'s: $$$ expression $$$ To escape the filter enclose the expression within triple $'s: $$$ $expression $$$ $.  Here are some web pages explaining some basics of TeX notation: http://www.math.uiuc.edu/~hildebr/tex/course/intro2.html http://www.math.tamu.edu/~harold.boas/courses/math696/LaTeX-in-line-equations.html http://abel.math.harvard.edu/computing/latex/manual/node21.html http://www.matheboard.de/formeleditor.php Installation of the Algebra and TeX filters is a bit more complicated than the basic Moodle installation, as they rely on an external program called mimeTeX to convert mathematics notation into inline graphics. Mimetex binaries for Windows, (most versions of) Linux, and MacOS X are included in the distribution.  Binaries for other systems are provided at http://moodle.org/download/mimetex/ . An additional complication is that certain unzip/ cvs programs on Windows handle binaries inappropriately, resulting in a corrupt installation of the mimetex binary.  Should that happen, a clean binary should be obtained from http://moodle.org/download/mimetex/ Finally the Algebra filter requires Perl to be installed on the server . This is a standard part of Linux, but most Windows servers will need to install that as well. A suitable distribution of Perl can be downloaded from: http://www.activestate.com/Products/ActivePerl/ To diagnose problems in the Algebra and TeX filter installations, debugging scripts are provided. They may be accessed via the urls: http://yourSiteName/moodle/filter/algebra/algebradebug.php http://yourSiteName/moodle/filter/tex/texdebug.php

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: State of The Math Message

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, we're developing a statistics quiz using STACK and would like students to be able to enter x-bar (symbol for the mean) into their answers. I have looked everywhere I can think of to find the syntax in maxima for this, without any luck. Can anyone help please. Many thanks in advance

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Maxima CAS in Stack - syntax for x-bar
ResponsesInList.Text: STACK discussion tends to take place in the 'Mathematical tools' forum. I will move this discussion there.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Maxima CAS in Stack - syntax for x-bar
ResponsesInList.Text: thank you

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Maxima CAS in Stack - syntax for x-bar
ResponsesInList.Text: The first question to answer would be "what does x bar mean?".  STACK tries to encourage meaning in mathematics. If it has no meaning then you could just have students type in "bar(x)".  Then define texput(bar,lambda([ex],sconcat("\\bar{", tex1(first(ex)), "}"))); to display the "bar" function (which does nothing) with a bar over the argument. Do you have "mean" in mind? Maxima has a "mean" function already.  Is that what you want? That's a little more complex, because Maxima's mean function expects a list. If you type mean(x) you will get an error.  You could put the following in the question variable. mean(ex):=texmean(ex); texput(texmean,lambda([ex],sconcat("\\bar{", tex1(first(ex)), "}"))); but then you won't have the "mean" function available elsewhere in the question! Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Feedback in formulas question type

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback in formulas question type
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi François We have recently come across this issue and after some research we found that  it could be a bug in the renderer.php file at formulas folder line 432 should be changed from $showfeedback = $options->feedback && $state == question_state::$gradedwrong; to this $showfeedback = $options->feedback; Then the part feedback is always shown, also when everything is correct. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback in formulas question type
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi bernat, Thanks for providing an example, it helps a lot ! As you guessed, the problem is in the renderer in the part_feedback function. For the adaptive behaviour no problem because we are in fact not using adaptive but using Tim's adaptive for multi part questions behaviour, so lines 434-442 $showfeedback is corrected according to the part graded state, not the question graded state. Unfortunately we can't do that for other behaviours as all we have is the question graded state. A very quick fix would be to show the feedback if the question graded state is wrong or partially correct. Of course this would not be perfect as feedback for some parts will be displayed even is that part's response is correct, but at least if all the question is correct no part feedback will be displayed (only general and combined feedback). I think this is the best we can do without too much work (we don't have enough information provided by the behaviour to know the graded state of the part). But maybe I am wrong ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback in formulas question type

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Feedback in formulas question type
ResponsesInList.Text: I think that something like $showfeedback = $options->feedback && ($state == question_state::$gradedwrong || $state == question_state::$gradedpartial); would do the job

ResponsesInList.Title: Challenge from AI
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear All: I usually rely on Moodle with STACK for online assessments. The problem is, ever since ChatGPT came along, students just use it to answer my quizzes. As a result, the whole point of the assessments is kind of lost. I tried one idea: breaking a problem down into several smaller steps so students have to work through the whole process instead of just giving the final answer. It works to some extent, but it also makes the quiz design way more complicated and time-consuming. Has anyone found better ways to structure online tests so students actually practice instead of just pasting everything into ChatGPT?

ResponsesInList.Title: Challenge from AI
ResponsesInList.Text: Students have always found ways "to cheat", weather it is copying from other students, getting parents to help or paying for other people to write essays. I don't see that AI/LLM's make a significant difference. The only way to be certain a student has done the work they submit is either controlled exam conditions or a short direct chat. To make it a little more sophisticated this could be described with the latin Viva Voce. This podcast discusses some of these issues. https://www.buzzsprout.com/2241345/episodes/17663810-assessment-in-education-to-ai-or-not-to-ai

ResponsesInList.Title: Challenge from AI
ResponsesInList.Text: I hope I didn't come accross as too negative in my response. Designing good assessments and ensuring students actually learn is an inherently demanding task well worth discussing.

ResponsesInList.Title: Challenge from AI
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Marcus, Thank you for your feedback.

ResponsesInList.Title: Challenge from AI
ResponsesInList.Text: I am thinking of using the Safe Exam Browser . I am also considering installing the SEB server and using a webcam to monitor exams.

ResponsesInList.Title: Challenge from AI
ResponsesInList.Text: One approach is to require students to explain or analyze solutions—even those generated by artificial intelligence—instead of just providing final answers.  In this manner, ChatGPT can be used to examine their thinking rather than to substitute genuine comprehension.

ResponsesInList.Title: Checking for correct mantissa value of input with units
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, before submitting a feature request, I'd like to check whether I just don't see existing options. The task is to check for correct mantissa but wrong order of magnitude for input with units. I know how to do this for numeric input. Question variables `mantissaOK(x,y,tol):= is(abs(round(log(x/y)/log(10))-log(x/y)/log(10))<tol);` PRT AlgEquiv: SAns: `mantissaOK(ans1/tans1,0.005)` Tans: `true` Feedback for true: Mantissa is correct but the value is off by at least an order of magnitude. Check your units handling. If tans and ans contain units, then this only works if the units exactly match because otherwise they don't cancel out in the log() argument and create TIMOUT rubbish in the feedback. My impression is that equivalence of units is only handled inside the Unit... answer tests. For the above order of magnitude test I need an algebraic equivalence test, which doesn't seem to cancel MPa against N/mm^2. Is there a way to simplify expressions like MPa/(N/mm^2) to 1? Being wrong by some orders of magnitude is a very common error, so I'd like to include such tests by default in formative feedback.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Checking for correct mantissa value of input with units
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Martin, I'm not sure this is the most elegant solution, but you could adapt the question variables as follows: 
```text
ra(x,y):=stack_units_nums(stack_unit_si_to_si_base(x))/stack_units_nums(stack_unit_si_to_si_base(y));
mantissaOK(x,y,tol):= is( abs(round( log(ra(x,y))/log(10))-log(ra(x,y))/log(10))
```
 Thanks for the idea – this is something I also wanted to implement in the past. Stephan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Checking for correct mantissa value of input with units
ResponsesInList.Text: Stephan, thanks for the hint to stack_unit_si_to_base(). I wasn't aware of this function. I'll give a try to the implementation. My favorite option would be to have it as an option in the UnitsRelative test, say if you specify OOM:tol, then the order of magnitude check is done automatically with the given tolerance. This would make it very easy to add this test to any numeric input with units without bloating the PRT.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Checking for correct mantissa value of input with units
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Martin, just one more note: Of course in addition one would have to check if ans1 and tans1 have the same base unit. Because something like `mantissaOk(3.2*MPa,3.2*g,0)` would also evaluate to true. Stephan

ResponsesInList.Title: Random variables in ASCIIIMaths
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Colleagues I am very new to moodle but have quite a lot of experience in using java applets and latterly javascript . Neither of these languages as far as I know readily allows the easy use of math symbols hence the need for mathml. While the various tools available seem to produce satisfactory representation for something like one half or two to the power of three is it possible using ASCIIIMaths or indeed any maths tool to produce random fractions or pwers. What I mean is that when Ben loads a page into his computer he sees 1/3 while Trudy would see 3/4 etc. The fractions written as fractions as we all know them ? Rory Barrett

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Random variables in ASCIIIMaths
ResponsesInList.Text:
While this could be done using MathML, that is not required. The jsMath filter would also work for this. You could install the jsMath filter in place of the tex filter, or even along side it, if you change the jsMath settings appropriately. Then you could do something like: 
```text
    <SCRIPT>
       var m = Math.floor(Math.random() * 5 + 2);
       var n = Math.floor(Math.random() * 4 + 2);
       document.write('
$$\\left(\\frac{1}{'+m+'}\\right)^{'+n+'}$$
');
    </SCRIPT>
```
 to display the value (1/m)^n as a fraction to a power. Note that the TeX backslashes need to be doubled since they are in JavaScript strings (the double \\ becomes a single \ in the result). I haven't actually tested the code, but it should get you started, at least. Hope that helps. Davide

ResponsesInList.Title: MathMLinHTMLforFirefoxAndIE.js, MathML, and Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text:
Greetings, I am posting as a newbie, so please forgive any failure on my part to find previous discussion of this. I have read through quite a few posts but probably not enough. There has been a tremendous amount of discussion of MathML and Moodle. First, let me describe what I am doing. I compose my documents in LaTeX and translate them to other markup languages. For example, I use tex4ht to produce XHTML with MathML. So it is natural for me to start there with Moodle. This has lead me to try Jipsen's javascript MathMLinHTMLforFirefoxAndIE.js, instead of the other flavors of his scripts that seem to be popular in this forum. I am thinking particularly of ASCIIMathML.js. MathMLinHTMLforFirefoxAndIE.js works, but the Moodle editor undermines its application. If I paste the appropriate HTML into the editor in HTML format and save immediately the all is well and everything displays correctly. However, if I return to the editor and save again. The editor makes changes to the MathML code that render it useless. Three particular changes have caused all of the problems that I have detected so far. First, any "<mspace ... />" tag gets turned into "<mspace ...> ... </mspace>" so that the closing "</mspace>" is separated from the opening "<mspace ...>" causing rendering errors. Second, any "<mo class=...>" becomes "<mo 
class=...>" Third, the "<mi>" tag gets expanded into '<mi -moz-math-font-style="italic">' These do not all occur after the first edit. I suspect that these are just examples of some more fundamental mistake or misunderstanding. Removing these changes with an ASCII editor puts things right again.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathMLinHTMLforFirefoxAndIE.js, MathML, and Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: I am just curious about your comments about why you don't want to use asciimathml. The reason I use asciimathml is that it not only provides an easier syntax for text expressions, but also parses Tex as well as anything else you want to extend it to do, while MathMLinHTML is more limited As Peter stated: Technical Note: this method of displaying MathML in Netscape/Mozilla/ Firefox does not recognize all entity names in the MathML DTD, but only those that are in the HTML DTD I sympathize with the issues over html or xhtml. One of the things we have been toying with has been the the impact of using various span tags which makes the markup more complex, but yields an arguably more powerful editor. There is by the way a google group that Peter created to address asciimath here: http://groups.google.com/group/asciimath?hl=en

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathMLinHTMLforFirefoxAndIE.js, MathML, and Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Marc, Thanks for your quick response. I tried to answer this question in my post with my explanation about working in LaTeX and wanting a single source document. So maybe I do not understand your question. An example of my understanding is probably helpful. If I were to use asciimathml, then I would need to markup my text all over again for an asciimathml version of my original LaTeX document. A translator replaces LaTex \section{} markup with HTML <h?></h?> for example. A CSS can then bridge the specifics of the formatting requirements for text and mathematics. How does that sound as an explanation? The current limitation to the HTML DTD is not very restrictive, at least for me. And in the longer run, I am expecting that we will all move out of HTML and into XHTML in any case. Cheers, Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathMLinHTMLforFirefoxAndIE.js, MathML, and Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Perhaps I should add another thought: I want to stick with the LaTeX because it is a strong standard for marking up mathematics. Moving into the simpler asciimathml syntax means dedicating some writing to a form that may prove inconvenient later. Yes, I can keep my mathematics in LaTeX for asciimathml. But as I mentioned above, that does not carry over to my text.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathMLinHTMLforFirefoxAndIE.js, MathML, and Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Closer maybe..... I get the impresson that you believe that asciimathml will not parse and display Tex. To the contrary, asciimathML (which includes a good bit of LaTexMathML) will parse and display most tex, as in \sqrt[3]{27}=3 . If your entire document is in LaTex than you may want to look at just working with LaTexMathML. There hasn't been much in the way of development on it for some time, but its available and the fellow who wrote it is always willing to chat. If you just have LaTex in a doc, then asciimathml will parse and display the tex as MathML. While this requires the server to offer xhtml, I think this is quite a bit nicer than fighting with html.... If you are doing something else entirely (i.e. some additional translation, like convertin LaTex to OOo text or vice versa) I am not getting the picture - sorry. I don't know that the war over html5 or xhtml is so simply resolved.... seems like lots of folks opposed to xhtml

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathMLinHTMLforFirefoxAndIE.js, MathML, and Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: No, I understand that asciimathml parses TeX and LaTeX. And I noticed that asciimathml presents MathML to the browser. As I said, I realize that I can keep my math in LaTeX for asciimathml, but my documents also contain text so I cannot just paste a LaTeX document into Moodle. But with a translator from LaTeX to XML with MathML, this is essentially what I can do in the XHTML world. Moreover, I can easily turn my LaTeX document into a first-class PDF document as well. One source can go to several outlets. If there is no need to write in several markup syntaxes, then it is easier to correct mistakes in one place than to trace them down in several versions of a document. And I was asking because it seems as though I could do this quite easily if the Moodle editor were not altering my code in hurtful ways when I return to it. At least that is what seems to be happening. I admit that I may be quite wrong about the directions of HTML, XHTML and XML in the future. When I saw a while back that it was easy to do wholesale translations of LaTeX into MathML, it seemed to me that it was time to move in that direction. I was not trying to work inside Moodle at the time. I was pasting XML documents directly into the courseware my institution has been supporting. I thought that the next generation of course ware would itself produce XHTML and Moodle does, right? But for reasons beyond my understanding that still does not permit direct insertion of MathML into the the editor. There we are restricted to HTML, as I understand it. Thanks for thinking about this and responding, Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathMLinHTMLforFirefoxAndIE.js, MathML, and Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: So how is it that asciimathml can create MathML code in a Moodle document and it will display correctly but the user cannot put the same MathML code directly into the document and have it display correctly?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathMLinHTMLforFirefoxAndIE.js, MathML, and Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: For those who happen to read this thread: a way to prevent the Moodle editor from changing your HTML code is to turn off the HTML editor in your profile (under advanced features). The downside is that you must do all of your entry with HTML in this configuration.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help with math_sytax errors
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, I am sure you will find help, but I am a little unclear on exactly what you are doing and what you need help with.... As you can see, if I put 2\sin^{-1}1 inside doubledollar signs the tex filter at moodle.org will display the proper tex: $$2\sin^{-1}1$$ which appears to be the expression you were trying to have displayed. You should first understand that Moodle can employ a number of different filters, and it looks like you are trying to use the algebra filter which uses I believe the double @ signs, but are expecting the tex filter to work, which uses double dollars signs.... so the first order of business is for you to understand which filters are in place and working on your moodle. Once you have checked that we can talk about the functioning of one filter at a time so that there is less likelihood of confusion. I would suggest that you disable the algebra filter in your moodle and enable the tex filter, then test the tex install to make sure it is fully operational. asciimathml and jsmath are other options for displaying math, but either of those have to be added to Moodle....

From Peter K: Hi, We're happy to announce the release of MathJax v2.4. You can get started right away using http://cdn.mathjax.org/mathjax/2.4-latest/MathJax.js or http://cdn.mathjax.org/mathjax/latest/MathJax.js . For the `latest` address, users might still have a copy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Geo Sketchpad
ResponsesInList.Text: I don;t have a great deal of time at the moment but if you search in the docs and the forums under java sketchpad you will find a good deal of prior discussion. There are several issues involved, including the fact that you have to use a work around to reference the applet if placed in moodledata (one reason many place the applet outside moodledata, which allows you much easier referencing - much the same situation facing one in the use of dragmath), confusion about applet parameters and their usage engendered in part by misinformation on the download site (the resource in which you want to reference the applet does not have to live in the same directory as the applet), and the fact that usage is not consistent across all moodle activities . So, I would suggest to make it easier on yourself that you place a java directory in your moodle file structure and reference that in your parameter. If you can tell me what type of activity you are trying to insert an applet reference in I can provide some examples as well.
