ResponsesInList.Title: Google Apps Waves Goodbye to IE6
ResponsesInList.Text: For those who hadn't heard, Google Apps is saying goodbye to support for IE6. The text of the note: Dear Google Apps admin,​ In order to continue to improve our products and deliver more sophisticated features and performance, we are harnessing some of the latest improvements in web browser technology. This includes faster JavaScript processing and new standards like HTML5. As a result, over the course of 2010, we will be phasing out support for Microsoft Internet Explorer 6.0 ​as well as other older browsers that are not supported by their own manufacturers. We plan to begin phasing out support of these older browsers on the Google Docs suite and the Google Sites editor on March 1, 2010. After that point, certain functionality within these applications may have higher latency and may not work correctly in these older browsers. Later in 2010, we will start to phase out support for these browsers for Google Mail and Google Calendar. Google Apps will continue to support Internet Explorer 7.0 and above, Firefox 3.0 and above, Google Chrome 4.0 and above, and Safari 3.0 and above. Starting this week, users on these older browsers will see a message in Google Docs and the Google Sites editor explaining this change and asking them to upgrade their browser. We will also alert you again closer to March 1 to remind you of this change. In 2009, the Google Apps team delivered more than 100 improvements to enhance your product experience. We are aiming to beat that in 2010 and continue to deliver the best and most innovative collaboration products for businesses.

ResponsesInList.Title: 1/3 as a periodic decimal fraction in stack
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello, I’m doing
some exercises with pupils at the age of 12 in stack/moodle. We are working
on fractions. Is there a way to handle periodic decimal fractions in stack and
maxima. For example,
are moddle, stack and maxima able to write numbers as 0, 3 in the question or
the student answer? Best regards, Björn

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 1/3 as a periodic decimal fraction in stack
ResponsesInList.Text:
Björn, This is an interesting and important topic. The short answer is "no" we don't have code for this situation out of the box. However, the flexibility of Maxima means you could create a function which supports this situation. E.g. a function `recurring(n,m)` which holds the non-recurring bit n and then the recurring bit m. More recent versions of STACK allow you to then deal with this with tex.

Assuming you are happy with the recurring bit as an integer you would do `texput(recurring, lambda([ex], sconcat(tex1(first(ex)),".\\bar{",tex1(second(ex)),"}") ));` Then, in the PRT you can define the function "recurring" as a rational expression, i.e. `` 
```text
recurring(n,m) := block([k], 
    k:1+floor(float(log(m)/log(10))), 
    n+m/10^k);
```
 You probably want a more flexible situation in which you can do more, so your display function becomes `` `texput(recurring, lambda([ex],if integerp(first(ex)) then sconcat(tex1(first(ex)),".\\bar{",tex1(second(ex)),"}") else sconcat(tex1(first(ex)),"\\bar{",tex1(second(ex)),"}") ));` This is, of course, all untested. I hope this gives you a pointer as to how you could define a Maxima function to represent a recurring decimal, and (a) display it, and (b) evaluate the function later in terms of the rational number it represents.

The input side of things is more difficult. We have ambitious plans to enable teachers to have much more flexible input options, to either interpret students' input or combine two boxes (start and recurring bit) into a single value to show the student "your answer is ...." For now input is somewhat fixed.

Anyway, I hope this gives you some idea of what would need to be done.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 1/3 as a periodic decimal fraction in stack
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Chris, thanks for the answer.

ResponsesInList.Title: Calculated MC with Fractions - Help Please
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm trying to write some simple calculated MC questions, but can't get the syntax for the answers down. Let's say my question looks like: What is $\frac{a}{b} + \frac{x}{y}$ ? One of my answer choices might be: {=$\frac{{{a}+{x}}}{{{b}+{y}}}$} Or one of the hundred subtle varients I've seemingly tried. My typical kick-back from the quiz engine is: Illegal formula syntax starting with '$\frac{{':$\frac{{1+1 And then I'm just lost. I've been through the math and TeX documentation and I guess since none of the examples I found used any TeX I'm a little lost. Any help would be greatly appreciated! Thanks Btw , I am writing double $ in all of my TeX, just not here to keep the TeX filter from changing it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Calculated MC with Fractions - Help Please
ResponsesInList.Text: Eric, I'm not very good at this, but I will take a stab at it. You are trying to use Tex notation in one place, where it is okay, and in another place, where it is not. In other words, you can use Tex notation to show pretty math formulas in the question, but, in the calculated answers you have to use the notation used for the calculated question type (also for calculated multichoice type). Check this doc page: http://docs.moodle.org/24/en/Calculated_question_type#Page_2._Choose_dataset_properties Instead of your answer: {=$\frac{{{a}+{x}}}{{{b}+{y}}}$} It should be something like {a+x}/{b+y} to get a fraction answer or {={a+x}/{b+y}} will give a decimal point answer. Hope this helps, AL

ResponsesInList.Title: STACK: Unicode display test failing in healthscript
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I've just updated our STACK version in our testing environment and everything seems to have gone well apart from one tiny aspect.  I'm getting a fail on the check for support of unicode, e.g. I get: Confirm if unicode is supported: ∀ ∀ should be displayed ? I'm running maxima using a separate Tomcat server with a MaximaPool setup.  For reasons I won't go in to, I've updated our STACK plugin to 4.3.11 (2022060100) rather than the version released a couple of weeks ago,  Our test server is internal only and can't be accessed off campus. For the life of me I can't remember if I was seening this issue in our test environment prior to my update today.  The test passes fine in my Production environment from which our Test environment is cloned.  Production is running STACK question version 4.3.11 (2021072200). I wonder if anyone can suggest reasons why unicode support should fail and how/if this can remedied? Thanks, Stuart

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: Unicode display test failing in healthscript
ResponsesInList.Text:
For what it's worth, and this may help others, I've solved my own problem. My colleague Niels Wallet also had issues with this in 2021 and this was discussed in a STACK bug report here: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/issues/732 I have taken over responsibility for the server form Niels. This UTF8 issue (and another more serious non-STACK issue) was solved by correctly configuring the PHP .ini settings as required for moodle. In this case, our PHP [intl] extension needed to be correctly configured as per the guidence here: https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/admin/environment/php_extension/intl The intl.default_locale value wasn't set at all and from what I can tell, it they falls back to other system settings, but this can be unreliable. I set this value as: 
```text
intl.default_locale = en_GB.utf8
```
 After doing this an recreating the maxima image, my healthcheck page ran with no errors and I was able to deploy the image to my MaximaPool setup.  All looks good and no obvious problems (so far).  Hopefully this will continue to solve this issue in future STACK upgrades too.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: Unicode display test failing in healthscript
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm back-tracking on that last post. What I'm finding is that to see what is going on, I need to ensure I clear the cache in the healthscript after changing the STACK-maxima configuration otherwise I see false positive or false negatives. The intl settings are actually having no effect at all, but what is essential is to set the maxima command as follows: LC_ALL=en_GB.UTF-8 timeout --kill-after=10s 10s /bin/maxima; (h/t to Niels Wallet for this suggestion as per his STACK bug repor t). Following adding this command, to see the correct results, I found I needed to ensure I cleared the cache.  And for the purposes of rebuilding the maximapool, ensure that I was compiling and running the healthscript the "linux" (not linux (optimised) ) setting.  It seems to flip around a bit which whilst probably for good reasons, did confuse the hell out of me.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: Unicode display test failing in healthscript
ResponsesInList.Text: "What I'm finding is that to see what is going on, I need to ensure I clear the cache in the healthscript after changing the STACK-maxima configuration" This is correct.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: First algebraic expression doesn't display
ResponsesInList.Text: What is the context in which you are inserting the LaTeX? What do you see when the page is displayed? For example, do you see the original markup $$$ \Bigsum_{i=\1}^{n-\1} $$$ or do you see a broken image link? Have you tried texdebug.php? To use it, point your browser at http:// yoursite /filter/tex/texdebug.php and follow directions. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: First algebraic expression doesn't display
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Happy new year for all of you ! To display the formula's correctly, I had to change the permissions of mimetex.exe to 755 instead of 600. As I did not know exactly which file(s) should have such a high level of permissions, I changed nearly all of the files in http://mysite/filter/tex to 755. If I copy files from my local pc to my website hosted by the provider using gftp (linux), the files always got the permissions 600. I often have to change that to a higher permissionlevel, by loging into my site using DirectAdmin, provided by my provider. So: If I have a problem, I always check the permissionlevels first. To insert tex-formula's I also started to use dragmath 0.6.2 (latest version- see plugins and discussion in mathematics tools).A nice and useful tool. As a dutch speaking teacher I apologize for my bad English. regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Strategy for editing STACK questions
ResponsesInList.Text: After repeatedly having spoiled a question by accidentally opening and saving it with a non raw text editor (Atto) I wonder how I could streamline my workflow and avoid such accidents. I find myself constantly switching between unformatted editor and Atto or TinyMCE (don't know the implications of choosing one or the other). This always takes a series of mouseclicks, just for changing a setting in the question like type checking. It seems there isn't an undo option for such accidents, is it? I see these options: - Stick with the unformatted editor and use an external html editor for visual editing (copy from Moodle, do the edit, copy back) to avoid editing raw html and enable insert of images - keep separate files with the contents of the cas regions in stack questions and paste them into moodle in case of an accident or when I create the content.  In fact that is what I do with JSXGraph content outside STACK in order to have syntax highlighting when doing edits. - make backups (export) of questions and re-import them in case of accidents. Yet I didn't find a way to export individual questions. Any of these ways generates significant amount of extra work load. Is that the way it has to go or do I miss something? Martin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Strategy for editing STACK questions
ResponsesInList.Text: This might not be the answer you want, but my plans are to create a YAML format in parallel with the Moodle forms. This will be a single text file for each question.  That way you can edit, and have complete transparency over the format.  Hidden span tags are evil, and we need a way to sort this out.  This can be frustrating, but my workflow is to use a raw textarea, with no editor to avoid them. Chris

Yet, with my weak html knowledge and resistance to the double amount of typing I can't use raw text for general moodle content. So my remaining questions are - Is there a way for backup and restore for individual questions? Would the above mentioned YAML format enable this? - Is there a recommended external editor for creating rich text and transfer by clipboard to moodle raw text regions including images, links and the like? This would allow me to stick with raw text areas. - Is there some shortcut/hotkey for change of editor? Martin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Strategy for editing STACK questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Create another user and set it's editor preference to unformatted, then login as that new user when working on quiz questions. I do this and only use Chrome when logged in as that user. My normal user I log in only from Firefox . I often have them both logged in at the same time and just switch browsers as needed. Helps to run dual monitors too, or a single 4k or larger one.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using plot2d command in STACK system
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi TIm, thanks for your reply. Actually, I am doing the project of creating questions in STACK system. It is me who is trying to use this plot2d function. However, only the one 'plot' works.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using plot2d command in STACK system
ResponsesInList.Text: STACK only allows users (teachers or students) to use *some* of the Maxima commands, but not all of them,  plot2d is a Maxima command which is not supported in STACK.  To create plots in STACK you need to use the "plot" command, which is a safer wrapper for plot2d.  Note that plot2d writes files to the server , so we have to restrict what people can do with it! Documentation for the master branch of the code is on https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/doc/en/CAS/Plots.md with examples, but you should check the local documentation on your server to see which options you have available.  There have been some recent changes. In the case of your example, x^2+y^2 is an expression with two variables.  In Maxima, plot2d(x^2+y^2, [x, -1, 1], [y, -1, 1]) does not work either.  You need to create a single variable expression, to use plot2d (or plot in STACK). It is often worth using the desktop version of Maxima to check if your code works outside STACK. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using plot2d command in STACK system

ResponsesInList.Text: Chris, The function use stack_equiv_find_step(ex, ex1) is very new, and may not yet be in the STACK system you are using! The function is documented here: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/doc/en/CAS/Equivalence_reasoning.md I've added in an example question here: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/samplequestions/equivalence_reasoning_example.xml This functionality is still under development. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK questions - finding steps
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey Chris, if you use EqualComAss as the answertest a fraction is distinguished from a floating point number. So if for example the correct answer is 0.5 then the student answer 1/2 is evaluated as wrong. Stephan.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK questions - finding steps
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Stephan, Thanks for this tip - it will be useful in other questions, but for the problem I'm developing I'm using the student's previous answers, so I don't know what the decimal will be. I'm developing a three part question where the student is asked to give the sum of their answers to the first two parts as a decimal. I can check that they are using their previous answers and that they are adding them correctly, but not whether the answer is given as a fraction or a decimal. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK questions - finding steps
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Chris, in this case you can just use EqualComAss to check if "ans3" (the student answer) is the same as float(ans3). If by chance the student answer is an integer, of course the input "1" (as an example) would not pass this test, while the input "1.0" would do so. So you might want to check on this in a separate node. Stephan.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK questions - finding steps
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes Stephen, that is the whole point of the test! But, I can see why you'd want a more subtle test between this (strict) test and algebraic equivalence. These features are all under development, so I'm happy to talk with you by email about exactly what you think is useful. I imagine there will be a lot of sensible scenarios and we should code these into the core to help avoid teachers needing to do all this on a question by question basis. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: State of STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi John Thanks for your interest in STACK. Simon and I are working hard to make the code reliable and efficient. We've been using it this term with groups of 225 students in large computer labs here in Birmingham. I'm confident now it is working well, but am also painfully aware of some minor bugs we need to fix! Yes, questions can be served remotely. We have a "minimal client", you might like to look at this here. http://matsrv3.bham.ac.uk/worksheets/ This uses the opaque protocol, (as does Moodle) but does not have any content management. This is really just to demonstrate STACK is not tied to Moodle. Also, the source code of these questions is already in the STACK CVS , so they are available for use by anyone. I've used JSMath because (i) it is a Moodle filter, and (ii) seems to work well. STACK now just leaves the LaTeX in the question. STACK could generate some MathML on the fly but the question author also needs to write some mathematics. And, we wanted to put answer boxes into equations! JSMath seems to be working well. Students very much appreciate the ability to scale the mathematics, but keep the main font size fixed. So JSMath is not a "requirement" in theory, but is the only supported mechanism currently. I'd be happy to receive contributions from other LaTeX->screen solutions, tuned for STACK. The reason you need JSMath on the STACK server itself is for the teacher to test questions with the direct interface. If you only author yourself through Moodle, then JSMath need only be on Moodle. If you have questions you are willing to share in STACK format, there are plenty of holes in our current coverage. We are working on 140 algebra questions to cover the material in http://www.mth.kcl.ac.uk/staff/ad_barnard/Pocket.pdf I had hoped these would be ready before term, but I just keep being ambushed with something else! We have some partial converters for other question formats into STACK. http://stack.bham.ac.uk/wiki/index.php/Converting_question_formats So, if you have lots of existing materials it may be possible to get STACK to load and partially convert them. Thank you for your interest, Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: STACK/MaximaPool: Time-out waiting for Maxima output at startup
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello I have set up STACK with Maxima/MaximaPool according to the instructions found in the MaximaPool GitHub project . In short, that means: Set up STACK and Maxima on the Moodle server according to the instructions in the STACK GitHub project . Run the health check in the Moodle admin interface, and have it generate the optimised Maxima image in `$MOODLEDATA/stack/` . Copy the generated image (and the `maximalocal.mac` file) to the separate system dedicated to Maxima. Set up the rest there ( `pool.conf` , `process.conf` , …), generate the Tomcat Webapp file ( `MaximaPool.war` ), and install that to `/var/lib/tomcat9/webapps/` , then start Tomcat. When pointing STACK to the separate Maxima(Pool) instance, I then notice that it just times out while the MaximaPool threads all remain stuck in the first call to `waitForOutput()` in 
```text
MaximaProcess.
java
```
 (called by the `MaximaProcess` constructor). To see what exactly is going on, I did some "println debugging" in `MaximaProcess.java` : 
```text
diff
--- a/src/fi/aalto/maximapool/MaximaProcess.java
+++ b/src/fi/aalto/maximapool/MaximaProcess.java
@@ -208,6 +208,7 @@
 	 * @param test string to look for in the output.
 	 */
 	private void waitForOutput(String test) {
+		System.out.println("Testing [" + test + "] against [" + processOutput.currentValue() + "]");
 		while (processOutput.currentValue().indexOf(test) < 0) {
 			try {
 				Thread.sleep(0, 200);
```
 The output I got from that in the system logs was the following: 
```text
Testing ["Maxima restarted."] against []
```
 So it appears that MaximaPool somehow doesn't detect any output from Maxima itself; the value returned by `processOutput.currentValue()` just remains an empty string at all time. Therefore the strings defined in `process.started` (and later `process.ready` ) are never matched, and MaximaPool remains blocked in `waitForOutput()` . As a comparison, this is what happens if Maxima is run manually: 
```text
root@moodle-maxima:/var/lib/maximapool/2020120600# sudo -u tomcat ./maxima_opt_auto -eval '(cl-user::run)'
Warning: argument a not recognized.
Maxima restarted.
(%i2) load("/var/lib/maximapool/2020120600/maximalocal.mac");

[ STACK-Maxima started, library version 2020120600 ]
(%o2) "/var/lib/maximapool/2020120600/maximalocal.mac"
(%i3)
```
 Out of curiosity, I commented out the two lines that call `waitForOutput()` , and that seems to solve it: MaximaPool now continues with the execution of Maxima itself, and at least the STACK qtype health check in the Moodle admin interface also runs successfully (as opposed to just timing out). I could now probably go on an debug the MaximaPool code further to see if there is somehow an issue with its handling of stdout of the Maxima process, but perhaps someone more involved with the project has an idea what might be wrong here? Here's some additional information about my system: Operating system: Ubuntu 20.04 Tomcat version: 9.0.31 Maxima version: 5.43.2 Please let me know if you need any more information, or if you have any hints for what else I could check to debug this further (short of just debugging the InputStream part itself).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK/MaximaPool: Time-out waiting for Maxima output at startup
ResponsesInList.Text: For completeness' sake, here's the change we're currently applying to make it work: https://github.com/adfinis-sygroup/stack_util_maximapool/commit/653a247160385b842878effdfcc11e6e238c4621

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK/MaximaPool: Time-out waiting for Maxima output at startup
ResponsesInList.Text: I would not recommend doing that. It may appear to work, but it is risky. To debug this, did you try going to the URL of your MaximaPool server directly. The URL of that will be somethign like like https://host.name:8080/MaximaPool/MaximaPool . There is a status screen there which shows you what is going on. Also, for each pool you have configured, there are links like 'Run the low-level health-check' which I created when I was trying to get this working on our servers.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK/MaximaPool: Time-out waiting for Maxima output at startup
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello Tim, thank you for the swift reply! The low-level health check gives me the following output: Executing command-line: /var/lib/maximapool/2020120600/maxima_opt_auto -eval (cl-user::run) Waiting for target text: '"Maxima restarted."' 
```text
Warning: argument a not recognized.
Maxima restarted.
```
 
```text
(%i2)
```
 Timeout!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK/MaximaPool: Time-out waiting for Maxima output at startup
ResponsesInList.Text:
Given the doubly quoted representation in the low-level healthcheck output, I tried removing the double quotes ( `"` ): 
```text
process.started = Maxima started.
```
 … and this worked! Now I also notice how Java itself did print the double quotes in the debug string; I should have noticed that mistake myself… With the double quotes removed from both values ( `process.started` and `process.ready` ), it now works as expected, with `waitForOutput()` returning correctly. Thank you very much!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK/MaximaPool: Time-out waiting for Maxima output at startup
ResponsesInList.Text: Great. Thanks for letting us know.

ResponsesInList.Title: Access to the STACK demo exercises to understand their structure
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Moodle / STACK community, my question is the following: are the STACK demo questions from https://stack-demo.maths.ed.ac.uk/demo/course/view.php?id=77 available as XML files to learn how they were constructed? I.e. can one download them for testing on a local moodle/stack server ? The reason for this question is that we are developing new STACK exercises for an entry level university physics course. There are two central issues that we encountered that seem to be solved in the demo: STACK-4.3.7-demo / Authoring features / Advanced features -> Follow through marking (question 10) . What we need is to A) make subsequent questions aware of prior answers. I.e. if a student has answered e.g. part a) incorrectly but has correctly used that wrong answer in solving part b) we wish STACK to be able to recognise that fact even if the final result for b) is incorrect. B) allow the student to "Check" parts of the questions without having to enter answers into all boxes. In the demo exercise one can insert just a) and leave b) blank, press "Check" and receive feedback on a). In our setup the system requires all answer boxes to be filled before allowing to check the results. Thank you for your time and looking forward to your suggestions. Many greetings, Alexander

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Access to the STACK demo exercises to understand their structure

ResponsesInList.Title: a strange size happens when using mimetex's array function
ResponsesInList.Text: I type $$$ A\cdot\left[\begin{array}{cc}\1\\-1\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}\1\\1\end{array}\right] $$$ but I get $$A\cdot\left[\begin{array}{cc}\1\\-1\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}\1\\1\end{array}\right]$$ In this array, the font "1" showing in the upper part is much smaller than the one in the lower part. Did I do something wrong?     p.s. I am not a Math teacher, so I am sorry for my poor ability to express some ideas about math.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: a strange size happens when using mimetex's array function
ResponsesInList.Text:
Your $$$ \begin{array}{cc}\1 $$$ should be $$$ \begin{array}{cc}1 $$$ , i.e., $$$ \1 $$$ indicates a special TeX character, not the number 1. Since standard TeX has no $$$ \1 $$$ I used it to accommodate someone else's special requirement, and you accidentally stumbled over it. You normally would have gotten a TeX error, but you got my smaller font 1 instead. Try writing $$$ A\cdot\left[\begin{array}{r}1\\-1\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{
r}1\\1\end{array}\right] $$$ and you should see $$A\cdot\left[\begin{array}{r}1\\-1\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{
r}1\\1\end{array}\right]$$ which is what I think you intended. I also took the liberty of changing your $$$ {cc} $$$ 's to $$$ {r} $$$ 's (since there's just one column, you just need one lcr letter), in case you feel that aligns better.

ResponsesInList.Title: MathJax problems with mix of TeX and MathML
ResponsesInList.Text: My site (Moodle 3.5) has several courses with TeX content, a few with MathML, and one with some of each. MathJax filter works for the TeX, but not for the MathML, with several different configs tried. Currently we're using the default config. If we load a second copy of MathJax.js via "Additional HTML", both math formats work most of the time, but some users have intermittent glitches where the TeX displays incorrectly. Suggestions? I was thinking maybe different MathJax configs for different courses might fix it, but how to do that?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathJax problems with mix of TeX and MathML
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Frank, "...maybe different MathJax configs for different courses..." - Go to the course you want to configure and click on the Editing Cog at the upper right, then click on Filters. Enable/disable the math filters you ant to use. If you so desire, you can actually edit the Filter settings for individual activities , which is what I generally do. That way I can use whatever math filter I need to for each activity to achieve the best render, especially when trying to "draw" things.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathJax problems with mix of TeX and MathML
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Al. Are you saying to install another secondary math filter? Which one? The problem I see is that there's just a single toggle for "enable MathJax / disable MathJax", when I'd like "enable MathJax setting A / enable MathJax setting B".

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathJax problems with mix of TeX and MathML
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Frank, Sorry, I was not more clear. At Site administration > Plugins > Filters > Manage filters, I have filters for Mathjax, and Algebra notation set to Active On, for Content and headings. I have Tex notation set to Off but available, for Content and headings. Anytime I have a situation like you describe where the renders seem to have "intermittent glitches" I go to the actual activity and specifically tell it which filter to use. Since I have some extra Tex packages set up, this makes it possible to mostly use Matjax, for the "better" renders, but if I want to use something from the extra packages I have for Tex, then I can specifically tell Moodle which filter to use for it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Help developing a "simple" question using STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm currently running a test for UNSW within the Faculty's of Engineering and Science to see if the STACK plugin meets our needs and if we should proceed to having our Moodle host look into installing it into our production Moodle instance. My first impressions are very positive of this tool and its features, nicely done. During our testing however an academic has come up with a question they'd like to build that I'm having issues with. The question is: A pendulum is located on {["Mercury","Earth","Mars"]} . What length should the pendulum have in order to have a period of {period}s? Than answer would be: {period}*[3.61,9.8,3.75]/(4*pow(pi(),2)) I'm stuck at the point where we'd like the question text to randomly display one of the 3 planets listed, but the value be the gravity equivalent for the planet listed in the answer. Any advice anyone could provide would be greatly appreciated. Thanks in advance

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help developing a "simple" question using STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: It is best to store the word in a variable, so in the Question variables, set planetindex: rand(3)+1 planetname: ["Mercury","Earth","Mars"][planetindex] gravity: [3.61,9.8,3.75][planetindex] Then in the Question text, you can do A pendulum is located on @planetname@. ... Note that, having used rand(), you also need to give the question a Question note, e.g. Pendulum on @planetname@

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help developing a "simple" question using STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Tim, Thank you so much for getting back to me so promptly and setting me down the right path. I was able to create the question with the following variables: planetindex: rand(3)+1 planetname: ["Mercury","Earth","Mars"][planetindex] gravity: [3.61,9.8,3.75][planetindex] s:float(rand(1000)/20); real_numbersp(pi) length: (s^2 * gravity) / (4*(pi)^2); To keep the answer to 2 decimal places I added this: decimalplaces(length,2) I've also attached the question if anyone would like to use it. STACK is proving to be a great tool within Moodle, but it does take a bit of time to learn. Cheers,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tex not working when it should
ResponsesInList.Text: After a lot of reading on the internet (Thanks to saint Google), I read somewhere that this particular LaTeX binary is, indeed, LaTeX, but it does default PDF conversion (instead of ps, because dvips goes ps->dvi and convert goes dvi->gif), that's why it's called 'pdfTeX'. One of it's parameters are 'output' - you set that output command in the latex path (/usr/bin/latex --output=ps, a red cross will appear but it will work) to ps and it will work as expected. There should be a config file to set that parameter, or you could edit some moodle source so the red cross won't appear, but it's working now. Finally. The \Bigint (default formula on texdebug.php) is not working, tho. I think it should, perhaps a missing package? Neither with mimeTeX, LaTeX, or in this forum. With mimeTeX, infty is not working either.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tex not working when it should
ResponsesInList.Text: I've encountered same problem, and has identified the cause. We're using CentOS and user "apache" didn't have the permission to create directories in it's home, which is /var/www. Erros I got when running commands as apache were: $ /usr/bin/latex --interaction=nonstopmode --output=ps /var/www/data/merlin/temp/latex/db2c39f297252dc0db1fb26bf1cb69f9.tex /usr/bin/latex: option `--output=ps' is ambiguous This is pdfeTeX, Version 3.141592-1.21a-2.2 (Web2C 7.5.4) entering extended mode ! I can't write on file `db2c39f297252dc0db1fb26bf1cb69f9.log'. Please type another transcript file name ! Emergency stop No pages of output. So, I did the following as root: # mkdir /var/www/.texmf-var # chown apache:apache /var/www/.texmf-var and that solved all my issues. It seems that TeX/LaTeX is working now like a charm!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tex Problem
ResponsesInList.Text: There is something on your system blocking the execution of the mimetex.linux binary. The file system permissions 755 seem to be correct and so are the file size and md5 checksum, but just as a check try executing mimetex.linux from the command line in a shell terminal. Try the statically linked version at http://cvs.sourceforge.net/viewcvs.py/*checkout*/moodle/contrib/mimetex/linux/mimetex If that doesn't work, you'll have to recompile it from source.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tex Problem

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tex Problem
ResponsesInList.Text: From briefly googling around, it seems that this problem is due to a security setting in your RHE system.  While I am not expert in these matters, it seems that the general gist of it is that you can set up your RHE system to refuse to run binaries unless they are compiled with a setting which does not allow executable code to be placed on the stack. The stack is an area of program memory which is used for general temporary storage.  A common technique in use by crackers is to exploit programming sloppiness to overflow the stack with malicious executable code.

ResponsesInList.Text: $$\sin \left( \alpha \right)$$ \sin \left( \alpha \right) $$\sin\left( \alpha \right)$$ \sin\left( \alpha \right) $$\sin\left(\alpha \right)$$ \sin\left(\alpha \right) $$\sin\left(\alpha\right)$$ \sin\left(\alpha\right) Notice that if the slashes do not immediately precede the keyword you get the kind of results you are seeing $$\sin\ left( \alpha \right)$$ \sin\ left( \alpha \right) Now I see what you mean.... you are not getting the benefit of any backslash as the backslash is being interpreted as universal escape (as you initially stated). This is not a dragmath error but an issue with moodle and I recall there was an issue and a resolution and I will look for it....

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dragmath - problem with backslash
ResponsesInList.Text: This appears to be a magic quotes issue. Check this and let me know if that help. http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=136248

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dragmath - problem with backslash

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ASCIIMathML on Moodle sites [redux]
ResponsesInList.Text: I have been doing some work with rewriting the TeX notation filter as a cleaner and more general mathematics script filter.  In addition to TeX notation I can render Asciimath and graphing scipts as SVG or PNG images.  The design allows easy addtion of binaries as plugins and consistent specification of delitimers. It has a more robust and configurable way of parsing scripts from HTML as well. However, I am not sure what the interest really is in something like this in the moodle community in general, and Moodle HQ in particular.  It does not seem developers  seem are really really in favor of continued support for TeX binaries now that MathJax is in 2.7. Rather, than asking whether to close MDL-599 , I would like to discuss what the future of the TeX filter should be.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ASCIIMathML on Moodle sites [redux]
ResponsesInList.Text: See my comments here. https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=259642#p1127624 Yes, I agree with your analysis (it is essentially what I argued as a basis for not rolling out the MathJax filter, especially as a default, at the present time) but it looks to me that the power on high has already made some decisions (whether they are aware of the impact of those decisions or not.) Based on what has transpired in the last few months,  I can see an argument for a TexLive filter for those with TeX needs beyond those that can be addressed via MathJax, which is a narrow band I would think of largely University level Math users relying on extensive macros or packages not supported by MathJax. The current TeX filter can serve that need, especially if it is needed to support the Algebra filter, which is still in use by lots of Moodle around the world.  But one thing that has to be resolved is whether the Algebra filter can be successfully decoupled from the TeX filter (so that the results of whatever the Algebra filter does is past agnostically to any TeX parser. And that of course is one reason why a MathJax preprocessor for ALgebra notation could be handy, as it eliminates the need for a perl distro (though arguably most linux/unix based systems will have it anyway), consolidates the tools used for most Moodle SAs and users, and frees the TeX filter to be what it needs to be without having to address the needs of those who really are not interested enough in Tech to bother.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ASCIIMathML on Moodle sites [redux]
ResponsesInList.Text: MD has apparently now expressed his willingness to turn ASCIIMathML ON via the MathJax Filter.  Please go to https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDLSITE-3077 if you are interested in this possibility and comment and VOTE.

ResponsesInList.Title: Using equations in moodle messages
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, is it possible to use the MathJax filter to display equations in moodle messages? If I type something like `\(\frac 1 2\)` into a message in the mobile app, it is nicely rendered as \(\frac 1 2\) . But if I use the same expression on the desktop-version I only get plain text. Do I have to enable the MathJax filter for the messages at some hidden point to make this work? (It did work in the past though.) Thanks, Stephan.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using equations in moodle messages
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Stephan, The message system was redone in 3.8 on the web version so that messages are available using ajax . The messages are lazy loaded meaning that they load after MathJax has already run on the page. The message handler should notify MathJax filter to process the new content, but does not. A work around for the present is to enable the TeX notation filter in system context . The mobile app was just recently fixed so that was not necessary to use it. It is great that is working now. Daniel

ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Daniel, we'll try this out. Stephan.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Одговор: Re: Одговор: DragMath is not working in Moodle.org forum
ResponsesInList.Text: You need to have a functional renderer for TeX (LaTeX) notations - usually people need to check permissions of executable mimetex.xxx file (depending on environment - usually mimetex.xxx needs to have 755 permission ) in folder filter/tex to see at least mimetex syntax. To see some more advanced LaTeX you can for example install a full distribution of Latex - for example TexLive - together with ImageMagick or GhostScript and set correct paths for these executable binaries in administration screen of Tex filter. Or you can install for example MathJax and let it render mathematical notations with theme files... see some other posts from these forums. Filters are not used inside editor content area so seeing only LaTeX syntax between tokens in editor is normal behaviour. It would be possible to create a simple plugin to tinymce to render Tex filter syntax as images (using tex filter files or some other renderer) in editor content area and again change those image tags to tex filter syntax while saving content but that option is not available in core moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problems with Maths TEX and Algebra
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Anthony, Actually, I think is indeed the "ideal" method. However, as mentioned in the Introduction section of http://www.forkosh.com/mimetex.html , "There's no inherent need to repeatedly write cumbersome tags." It goes on to illustrate a simple one-line fix for phpBB that permits inline expressions containing [ t e x ]...[ / t e x ] to render the ... expression as a mimetex image. And that could just as easily have been $$$ ... $$$ (like moodle) instead. But I'm not familiar with moodle code, nor with the mechanism for submitting changes. While it's easy for me to say the moodle fix should be just about as simple as the phpBB fix (i.e., easy for me to say "simple" when somebody else is doing the actual work), mimetex's whole design is based on the idea that such fixes should be pretty straightforward. But Martin, or somebody else familiar with moodle internals, will have to confirm this for moodle. Unfortunately for us, "Zig" seems to be busy with other things these days. To make mimetex even safer and simpler, instead of you can write which uses the public mimetex server running on my ISP. That way, you don't have to install or run mimetex (or any special math software) whatsoever. But you still do need the fix that recognizes $$$ ... $$$ and generates the corresponding img tag. John

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problems with Maths TEX and Algebra
ResponsesInList.Text: The jsMath filter does not require programs to run on your server. It works by running JavaScript on the user's browser. This is safer and easier to install on your server, but the down side is it is slower, as the page must be processed every time it is viewed. So you have to decide whether it is worth the trade-off for you. Davide

ResponsesInList.Title: STACK: 2*sqrt(2)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Does anyone have a clever way of stopping STACK (well, Maxima) replacing 2*sqrt(2) with 2^(3/2)?  [Similarly for 3*sqrt(3) etc ] A search found the suggestion of matchdeclare(n_, integerp,m_, integerp)$ tellsimp(n_*sqrt(m_), n_*sqrt(box(m_)))$ But, 1) STACK doesn't like that. 2) Even it if did, the tex output is   "3\,\sqrt{\boxed{3}}"  and in Maxima I'm failing to change the tex render of box(...) Thanks, Tim

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: 2*sqrt(2)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey Tim, have you tried declaring "simp:false;" in front of the expression? Depending on your needs, you might want to turn simplification back on with "simp:true;" afterwards or in individual cases by using "ev([ex],simp)" - where [ex] is replaced by the expression you want to simplify. Cheers Thorsten

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: 2*sqrt(2)
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Thorsten. Yes, I can do that in "question statements" but I'd really like to avoid the 2^(2/3) when Maxima calculates the answers to problems, and the intermediate steps which I show in the "general feedback". Thanks,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: 2*sqrt(2)
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Tim, have you tried setting the option "Question-level simplify" to "No"? You can also turn off simplification for each potential response tree with option "Auto-simplify". Cheers, Thorsten

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: 2*sqrt(2)
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Thorsten, Yes, Maxima "does things" to surds. I spent a while trying to get sqrt(2)/2 and not 1/sqrt(2) a week or so ago, because maxima transforms sqrt(2)/2 into "simplified" 1/sqrt(2). If someone would like to write up some notes on surds, how Maxima deals with them, and how we can use Maxima to assess surds than I'd really appreciate it and add this to the STACK docs. If this generates some gaps in STACK functionality (and careful docs often do) I'll help close them. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: 2*sqrt(2)
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Chris, thanks for your reply. Unfortunately, I'm more of an IT person than mathematically inclined, even though the subject fascinates me. As far as surds are concerned... are you referring to how surds are cancelled out by maxima (sqrt(2)/2 might be the most prominent example for this) and how different notations are prioritized (as in Tim's example: 2*sqrt(2) vs. 2^(3/2))? Upon checking out the current STACK docs for a relevant section for this topic, I stumpled upon https://stack-demo.maths.ed.ac.uk/demo/question/type/stack/doc/doc.php/Authoring/Options.md , more specifically the option "Surd for Square Root", i.e. Maxima's "sqrtdispflag". This might be an even more specific solution to Tim's problem compared to the "simplify"-approach I suggested. The mailing list with a discussion on this topic is no longer available - at least not following the link in the docs. Looks like this topic has been discussed at some point in the past. Cheers Thorsten

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: 2*sqrt(2)
ResponsesInList.Text: I know this was a few months ago but I was also struggling with trying to transform expressions like 1/(sqrt(10)+sqrt(5)) into ones with a rational denominator. It turns out with simplification on or say one just did ev(...,simp) with simplification off, then one can force 1/sqrt(2) into sqrt(2) as with the following example. simp:true; aa:sqrt(2)/2; aa:rat(aa),algebraic; /*which should return sqrt(2)/2 albeit in the form Using ?print() I can see the following aa will look like ((MEXPT SIMP) 2 ((RAT SIMP) -1 2)) after the assignment After using rat it's the more complicated ((MRAT SIMP (((MEXPT RATSIMP) 2 ((RAT) 1 2))) (#:|2^(1/2)428|)) (#:|2^(1/2)428| 1 1) . 2) with some kind of rules I don't understand at the end. Same example with simp false: simp:false; aa:sqrt(2)/2,simp; /*or aa:1/sqrt(2)*/ aa:rat(aa),algebraic; Apologies that you probably have already figured this out in the meantime. Edit: There was some other differences using ratsimp rather than rat. simp:false; aa:sqrt(2)/2,simp; aa:ratsimp(aa),algebraic; produces 2^(1/2)/2 as in ((MTIMES RATSIMP) ((RAT) 1 2) ((MEXPT) 2 ((RAT) 1 2))) where as simp:true; aa:sqrt(2)/2,simp; aa:ratsimp(aa),algebraic; doesn't seem to change anything ((MEXPT SIMP) 2 ((RAT SIMP) -1 2)) I'm using Maxima 5.42.2 as that may be important, who knows.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: 2*sqrt(2)
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Tim, I guess, this is a rather ugly solution and I'm not sure, whether it causes any problems or not. But it does work to some degree: If you replace `box(m_)` by `string(m_)` in your suggestion, this will also prevent Maxima from evaluating the radical term. Try to add something like 
```text
disp_surds: block( matchdeclare(n_, integerp,m_, integerp), tellsimp(n_*sqrt(m_), n_*sqrt(string(m_))), return(true));
```
 to your question variables. Stephan

ResponsesInList.Title: sMARTH SVG equation editor
ResponsesInList.Text: anyone tried this yet? Could it form the basis for a moodle equation editor (I know, I know tex is better, but I keep getting "What, no equation editor???)" http://smarth.sourceforge.net/ Seems to require IE , or at least doesn't seem to like NS 7.2 on XP?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: sMARTH SVG equation editor
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello to you, > Seems to require IE , or at least doesn't seem to like NS 7.2 on XP? sMArTH does not require anything other than a fully conformant SVG viewer and a Unicode Font. At this time it works best with Adobe SVG Viewer and this viewer works best with IE, but there are hacks to make it work with other browsers too. On the other hand web browser support for SVG is getting better with Opera 8.0 and the upcoming Firefox 1.1 . This may not be enough to run sMArTH yet but things will surely evolve. Also the Renesis SVG 1.2 Rendering Engine will be available this autumn for Firefox /Mozilla/Netscape, Internet Explorer and Opera. The sMArTH developer team is planning to rewrite sMArTH from scratch this summer using a new SVG widget platform ( SvgUP ) and with the goal to make it more modular, customizable and extensible. We also have the intention to make sMArTH easily embeddable into larger web applications like moodle . Would you be interested in collaborating with us? Kind Regards, Catalin Hritcu sMArTH Team

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: sMARTH SVG equation editor
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Michael, Has there been any further investigation of smarth ( http://smarth.sourceforge.net ) since your original post? I realize that the long-term goal is to have an equation editor cleanly integrated with Moodle. But to paraphrase your remark from 2005, "What, 2007 and STILL no equation editor?" As an interim solution, Smarth could be integrated with Moodle in a very loose fashion, relying on smarth's ability to output LaTeX. The student would do the work in smarth, then copy the LaTeX from smarth and paste it into a Moodle text box (in a quiz or online assignment). It's not perfect, but it's better than nothing! See this discussion .

Remember that you can adjust your tokens and you may well want to install SEE as part of your experimentation with STACK3 so that Chris gets feedback on using the new question type with the tinyMath editor and plugins. Frankly,  if you are going to the trouble of using STACK I can't imagine that you do not also want to use the plugins. If you do the plugins then you DO NOT NEED TO DECOUPLE the TeX filter.  This also gives your users the posible option of using TeX instead of MathJax, as MathJax does not do some things (yet).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dragmath with Mathjax
ResponsesInList.Text: I now tried installing SSE on my test server , which went fine. However, since I for the time being really only need Dragmath (maybe GeoGebra later), I wonder what the advantage of using SSE instead of just decoupling the TeX filter is? Is Tinymath somehow better than just TinyMCE with DragMath enabled? It's not that I have anything against SSE, I just try to understand which of the options I should use (which was also the purpose of my original post). Thanks again!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dragmath with Mathjax
ResponsesInList.Text: SEE makes a variety of aditional tools available through the plugins and themes,  for example the ability to actually see real time what your DragMath inserton will look like,  for a student to actually edit and submit a graph, to use ASCIIMathML, to have access to a graphing calculator. So, the short answer is that if all you want to do is decouple DragMath you need not bother with SEE. If, on the other hand, you want to provide your teachers and students with a set of extraordinary math tools, then install the plugins and show them to your Math teachers and see how they respond. Frankly, at some point I suppose someone will have to take some Math lesson and then demonstrate point by point how SEE could impact instruction. I have argued in the past that Math on the web needs to be transparent and universal, and I look at SEE as a vehicle that may take us in that direction, a young Maths babblefish if you will.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MaxiamaPool working but 500 error on any evaluations

Then, later, remove the older no longer needed version of the STACK/Maxima code.

ResponsesInList.Title: Install Katex for moodle Math rendering
ResponsesInList.Text: I am new to moodle . But I google out that Katex for math rendering is faster than mathjax . Katex .Comparison with mathjax with help of Speed Test So I  want to know can I use Katex with moodle. And if it is yes   then how?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Install Katex for moodle Math rendering
ResponsesInList.Text:
Speed is not everything. MathJax has some features that KaTeX does not. In particular it is more accessible. The speed test page above exaggerates the speed difference. On more practical pages the difference is not as noticeable. However, If you are interested in trying KaTeX in Moodle 2.8+, you can use the following procedure. Go to Site administration -> Appearance -> Additional HTML. In the box Within HEAD put 
```text
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/KaTeX/0.8.3/katex.min.css" integrity="sha384-B41nY7vEWuDrE9Mr+J2nBL0Liu+nl/rBXTdpQal730oTHdlrlXHzYMOhDU60cwde" crossorigin="anonymous">
```
 In Before BODY is closed include 
```text
<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/KaTeX/0.8.3/katex.min.js" integrity="sha384-L9gv4ooDLrYwW0QCM6zY3EKSSPrsuUncpx26+erN0pJX4wv1B1FzVW1SvpcJPx/8" crossorigin="anonymous"></script>


<script>


    var texpreviews = document


        .getElementsByClassName('MathJax_Preview');


    for (var i = 0; i < texpreviews.length; i++) {


        katex.render(


            texpreviews.item(i).nextSibling.textContent,


            texpreviews.item(i)


        );


    }


</script>
```
 Then enable the TeX notation filter and disable MathJax filter. TeX expressions will be filtered and displayed as images first by the TeX notation filter. KaTeX will then replace the images with its display.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Install Katex for moodle Math rendering
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Daniel, I have tried to insert your code within the head and before the BODY is closed in the Additional HTML section. It gives 'This page is not working' and 'Chrome detected unusual code on this page and blocked it to protect your personal information (for example, passwords, phone numbers, and credit cards).' I am using Moodle 3.4 on a current version of Chrome. Is there something new in Moodle that scrubs out scripts in the Additional HTML? Thanks, Dave

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Install Katex for moodle Math rendering
ResponsesInList.Text: I just ran it with the development master, and it seems to be working for me. Make sure that MathJax filter is off. Normally the additional HTML is not scrubbed. Are you using one of the standard themes or a custom one? That might interfere.

ResponsesInList.Title: Therefore symbol
ResponsesInList.Text: I seem to be struggling getting the "therefore" symbol to appear in Tex it should be three dots in a triangular formation with the point sticking up. Has anyone come accross this symbol?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Therefore symbol
ResponsesInList.Text: There is a \therefore symbol in standard (La)TeX, but it requires what's called the amssymb package. I didn't convert those extra font families for mimetex. But you can "fake it" using the -DNEWCOMMANDS="filename" switch on mimetex's compile line. See http://www.forkosh.com/mimetexmanual.html?options for a discussion. For your situation, the following line in filename seems to do the trick for me... { "\\therefore", NULL, "{\\Huge\\raisebox{-4}{.\\atop.\\,.}}" },

ResponsesInList.Title: How to show calculation steps in STACK?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everyone, I would like to set up a question in STACK that enables the student to show their workings out. This does not have to be automatically marked. I am aware that I can use the Notes input type, but then the input by the student is not translated nicely by LaTeX. Thank you in advance for your help and advice! Daisy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to show calculation steps in STACK?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Daisy, I think you could use Equivalence reasoning without grading it and with comments being allowed (use `comments` as an extra option). Stephan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to show calculation steps in STACK?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Stephan! Thank you for your suggestion. Just to make sure... 1. Under input, do I then choose Algebraic Input? But then what should I put in the Model Answer? 2. Under PRT, does it matter what I put as Teacher's Answer? The STACK plugin I'm using might be different because it requires me to not leave these fields empty.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to show calculation steps in STACK?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, 1. Equivalence reasoning is a separate input type that you can choose. The model answer could be some sort of short worked solution, such as `[x^2=1, x=1 nounor x=-1]` or just some placeholder, such as `["Your notes"]` . This depends on whether you want to use it in the potential response tree or not and what you would like to have displayed as the "correct answer". In any case the teachers answer for this input type has to be a list. Youc can find details on this input type here .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to show calculation steps in STACK?
ResponsesInList.Text: Oh I see, I think I do not have this Equivalence Reasoning input type in the STACK plugin that I have at my institute. I thought you were referring to EquivReasoning under PRT. I have to see what I can do to get the newest version. Many thanks for your help!

ResponsesInList.Title: Question import plug-in with support for Word and MathType equations
ResponsesInList.Text: I created a Moodle2Word plug-in to support importing and exporting questions to and from Microsoft Word a few years ago. I have now released an update to this plug-in with support for equations which readers of this forum may be interested in. If you use Microsoft Word, and either MathType or the native Microsoft Word Equation Editor to insert equations, you can create and import quiz questions into Moodle question banks. The equations will be converted into images when you upload the questions. Although probably not for the purists, it does at least offer the benefit that equations will render correctly inside Moodle once uploaded. Both MathType and the Microsoft Equation Editor offer a range of input facilities, including wizards, templates and direct TeX entry, so entering equations should be relatively easy for all levels of user. Further documentation is available at http://docs.moodle.org/26/en/Word_table_format .

Following is the issue: I have installed moodle2word on 2 systems. When I create a file on one of the systems, the file imports but the places where equations are there shows blank. In another system, the file does not import at all. I get the following error: XSLT transformation failed ( (XSLT: /home/tribecas/public_html/moodle/question/format/wordtable/xhtml2mqxml.xsl; XHTML : /home/tribecas/moodledata/temp/w2q-da08n1.if2) ) I am attaching the file that gives me error. Am I missing something? I have tried creating the quiz with images and it works properly, but somehow not able to make it work with equations. Thanks in advance! Priyanka

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Question import plug-in with support for Word and MathType equations
ResponsesInList.Text: I believe the reason for the XSLT error message is that you have an older version of the plugin installed. You should upgrade to version 3.4.3 to fix it. I'm not sure why the imported question fails to display on the other system. One possibility is that MathJax on the server isn't configured to display MathML. If you export the question to a file in XML format and post that here, then I can take a look. You should also specify your Moodle configuration (version and OS).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Question import plug-in with support for Word and MathType equations

I have 2 installations - one Moodle 2.7 and one Moodle 2.9, both of them hosted on siteground hosting. I have attached the exported XML file. I have also sent you a private msg giving you admin access to the Moodle 2.7 installation. I am using MS word 2016, latest version of Word. Regards, Priyanka

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Question import plug-in with support for Word and MathType equations
ResponsesInList.Text:
MathJax configuration was the issue, and this is now fixed, by adding "<math" to the setting "Additional equation delimiters" on the Site administration > Plugins > Filters > MathJax page. PS. I also just released a new plugin last week, which allows you import Word content into any page in Moodle, see https://moodle.org/plugins/view/atto_wordimport It has essentially the same features as the WordTable import facility for questions,
including embedded images, equations, tables and headings, but you can install it as an Atto
text editor plugin, and then use it on any HTML editing textbox to drag and drop Word files. It's just an initial release, and so may not be suitable for production servers, but worth a look nonetheless. If you need to insert equations in questions, then you probably need to insert them in other
elearning content as well, and if you are already familiar with the Word Equation Editor,
then this plugin would allow you edit all of your equations in Word and import them to wherever
you want in a Moodle course.

ResponsesInList.Title: Reaping old maxima processes
ResponsesInList.Text:
I have a standalone moodle server (ubuntu 18.04, moodle 2.9.1, stack v4.2.1) that I set up a few years ago and have been upgrading (via git ) at the beginning of each semester. I noticed today that the server had  long-running maxima processes that were noticeably slowing things down: 
```text
# ps auxwwf | grep maxima
```
 
```text
www-data 31947  7.6  4.1 577272 509260 ?       R    Dec01  95:52 /usr/lib/maxima/5.41.0/binary-gcl/maxima -eval (cl-user::run) -f --


www-data 19407  7.3  8.4 1100632 1033976 ?     R    Dec01  75:37 /usr/lib/maxima/5.41.0/binary-gcl/maxima -eval (cl-user::run) -f --


www-data  8451  6.7  8.3 1090240 1024968 ?     R    Dec01  52:33 /usr/lib/maxima/5.41.0/binary-gcl/maxima -eval (cl-user::run) -f --


www-data 23076  6.6  8.3 1100492 1031284 ?     R    Dec01  46:45 /usr/lib/maxima/5.41.0/binary-gcl/maxima -eval (cl-user::run) -f --


www-data 24494  6.5  4.1 577528 508256 ?       R    Dec01  46:13 /usr/lib/maxima/5.41.0/binary-gcl/maxima -eval (cl-user::run) -f --


www-data  7861  6.4  8.3 1100736 1031452 ?     R    00:36  40:10 /usr/lib/maxima/5.41.0/binary-gcl/maxima -eval (cl-user::run) -f --


www-data 10473  6.3  4.1 576908 509108 ?       R    00:48  39:13 /usr/lib/maxima/5.41.0/binary-gcl/maxima -eval (cl-user::run) -f --


www-data 17026  6.3  8.3 1100396 1032052 ?     R    01:17  37:05 /usr/lib/maxima/5.41.0/binary-gcl/maxima -eval (cl-user::run) -f --


www-data 17171  6.3  8.3 1101152 1032020 ?     R    01:18  37:02 /usr/lib/maxima/5.41.0/binary-gcl/maxima -eval (cl-user::run) -f --
```
 What I noticed is that the parent process of each of these processes is dead, but the child is still running.By contrast, there were other long-lived processes with the parent still alive: 
```text
www-data 30380  0.0  0.0   4628     0 ?        S    02:24   0:00 sh -c /usr/bin/maxima 2>&1


www-data 30381  6.2  4.1 576244 506740 ?       R    02:24  32:30  \_ /usr/lib/maxima/5.41.0/binary-gcl/maxima -eval (cl-user::run) -f --


www-data  5287  0.0  0.0   4628     0 ?        S    03:01   0:00 sh -c /usr/bin/maxima 2>&1
```
 I am a bit mystified about why those children are not being reaped. And, how can I ensure they get reaped? TIA , Leo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Reaping old maxima processes
ResponsesInList.Text:
Reply to self: I reconfigured the stack plugin to use the timeout command as explained here: https://eformation.univ-grenoble-alpes.fr/question/type/stack/doc/doc.php/CAS/Optimising_Maxima.md The ultimate source of the long-running maxima processes appears to be a bug in the php code which mangles or mis-reads syntactically-correct expressions like 
```text
e^-(k*((2*n-1)/L)^2*t)
```
 while letting 
```text
e^-(5*((2*n-1)/L)^2*t)
```
 pass. Leo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Reaping old maxima processes
ResponsesInList.Text: STACK 4.3.x has a much improved parse. I would be very surprised if this bug was still present.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Reaping old maxima processes
ResponsesInList.Text: Tim, I upgraded moodle and stack to the latest release and I am still finding the same parse errors. Can you tell me how/where to submit a bug report? Leo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Reaping old maxima processes
ResponsesInList.Text: Use the Issues tab here: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Reaping old maxima processes
ResponsesInList.Text: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/issues/664 Thanks, Leo.

ResponsesInList.Title: interface to symbolic math. problem generator available
ResponsesInList.Text: Since I don't know how many of you on this forum also read the General Developers Forum, I thought I'd post a copy of my announcement here too. I have developed an interface from Moodle to WeBWorK, a web-based system for generating and grading mathematics problems (which can also be used for physics too). The system can generate sophisticated problems which require symbolic mathematical answers, e.g. e^x sin(4x-2) + ln(5x-2) and it will analyze and grade such answers accurately. The interface I have developed allows you to link to such an assignment from within Moodle. After submitting such an assignment, you can click on a button to return back to Moodle, and your grades from the WeBWorK assignment will be automatically imported back into Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: interface to symbolic math. problem generator available
ResponsesInList.Text: I've implemented the following improvements to the Moodle-WeBWorK interface: 1) A feedback link from WeBWorK problems to a Moodle discussion forum. 2) A variant of the interface to online WeBWorK problem sets, which does NOT return a score back to Moodle. This would be an interface to optional just-for-practice WeBWorK assignments. To see this in action, please log into https://webwork.math.ohio-state.edu/moodle/ with login doe.123 as both username and password. The updated interface scripts are available for download at https://webwork.math.ohio-state.edu/moodle_scripts/ I would appreciate your reactions to this interface. Zig

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 回應: Re: Maxima Installation Error

ResponsesInList.Title: Deploying Stack-questions problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Greetings, I have exam with several stack-questions and would like to deploy variants for the questions. My problem is that the automatic deploying tool does not generate same seeds for multiple questions. For example if I have 100 variants and 10 questions to my current knowledge it would mean that I have to generate 900 variants by hand. So the question is: - How to deploy variants to multiple stack questions so that each question has same seed numbers for the variants? Yours truly, Mikko Västi

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Deploying Stack-questions problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Mikko, Very sorry but this situation is not currently supported. I've not been asked to do this before. Are you trying to share information about which random version has been created between questions? (!) If so, this might work but it it not something we have designed in and if it works (I don't know) it is probably very fragile. Perhaps you could explain why and I'll see if we can help solve the underlying problem. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Deploying Stack-questions problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Greetings Christopher, I am trying to share the random seed numbers between multiple questions in deploying variants. So the workflow that I would like is something of following: 1. Deploy variants for single question 2. Deploy variants for other questions using the variant seed numbers of question 1, which we had deployed in step 1. The current work flow is presumably following:

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Deploying Stack-questions problem
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't understand why you are collecting seeds? Why not just deploy seeds separately for each question? They are random seeds...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Deploying Stack-questions problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Sure I can deploy seeds randomly for each and every question... But then either one of these 2 options will happen: Different questions will not have the same values for variables and the exams are built on assumptions that one will have multiple questions using same values for variables. The system will pick one pre-randomized seed number for the first question in the exam and will calculate each other question with the picked pre-randomized seed number. Thus eliminating all benefits of caching. The main goal here is that I can have multiple questions using same values for variables and to cache the pre-calculated solutions. Yours truly, Mikko

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Deploying Stack-questions problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey Mikko, I'm a little bit confused about the propositions you are making. Maybe you can be so kind and help me understand... - If there are multiple variants deployed per question, how would you ensure that different questions within the same quiz actually draft the same variant (seed)? - Using the same random seed for consistent variable generation is most likely not reliable. If, at all, wouldn't this only work as long as variable generation in both questions is exactly identical? (That's a guess on my part, not verified.) - As far as caching is concerned, aren't you good to go as soon as variants are deployed? We always suggest adding at least basic test cases to cover answer testing, too. Seeds can be chosen manually, too... for a large number of variants / questions this will surely be impractical, but it might serve well for a proof of concept. Cheers Thorsten

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Deploying Stack-questions problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Does that mean that the use of entries in the field "Random group" is useless if deployed questions are used in a test?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Deploying Stack-questions problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Not entirely useless, but the requirement to deploy the same seeds for each question is a major pain. We ought to make a solution to that, once we can work out what a good solution looks like.

ResponsesInList.Title: Latex
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, A colleague of mine has the following question: Does anyone of you know whether it is possible to make
Moodle rendering also LaTeX stuff in answers of some question types like
"Ordering", "gapfill", "CLOZE Gapfill" and
the like? With MC questions it works, but not with the others. It
would be very helpful particularly to be able to display (small) LaTeX stuff in
dropdown and drag and drop elements in the answers. (I remember that it once
was possible to let Moodle render almost everything by the TeX filter. But that
might be a pre-historic feature.) Any ideas? Best, Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Latex
ResponsesInList.Text: As far as I know this only works with the Ordering and the Drag-and-Drop Matching question types.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Latex
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Paul, It is possible to have MathJax render \( \LaTeX \) in drag and drop elements. If you have the MathJax filter enabled, you can add filter_mathjaxloader_equation class to an html element containing \( \LaTeX \) . You may also have to include some delimiters elsewhere so that the filter loads MathJax. Drop down menus are specified by HTML standards to be text only. It is possible to configure MathJax to render that anyway, but it will only be visible in certain browser. This makes it a very bad idea to use. The TeX notation filter is not necessarily a bad solution if MathJax fails for some reason. It is just much more difficult to configure than MathJax which works out of the box.

ResponsesInList.Title: STACK: rand_with_prohib returns -1 even when it is prohobited
ResponsesInList.Text: The  example from Stack documentation `rand_with_prohib(-5,5,[-1,0,1,sqrt(pi)])` returns a random number from the set { − 5 , − 4 , − 3 , − 2 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 } {−5,−4,−3,−2,2,3,4,5} . returns -1 for me. This didn't happen before but now that our Moodle servers have been updated to version 4.1, the bug is annoying. Even as simple as rand_with_prohib(-3,3,[-1]) returns -1. The weird thing is that this doesn't happen to my co-worker. Any ideas?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: rand_with_prohib returns -1 even when it is prohobited
ResponsesInList.Text: Miika, Yes, this would be very annoying indeed. The function is defined in STACK , and the actual code is here https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/stack/maxima/stackmaxima.mac#L408 This code has not changed for 6 years! Are you using a strange unicode character for -1, which makes the "delete" not work? E.g. there are lots https://www.compart.com/en/unicode/category/Pd We recently added code to clean up student input. If this is the cause of your problems, then it's the first report from a teacher...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: rand_with_prohib returns -1 even when it is prohobited
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Christopher for your answer! Sometimes the unicode problem happens when a student has copied an expression form somewhere but I don't see how that could happen to me. The problem still exists and I have no idea how.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: rand_with_prohib returns -1 even when it is prohobited
ResponsesInList.Text: Found the solution! If the Question-level simplify is turned OFF in the Options, -1 has to be entered as simplify(-1) in rand_with_prohib. Actually every negative number has to entered using simplify(). Whether or not this behaviour is intentional, I cannot tell. I'm pretty sure that this wasn't the case before the Moodle update but I could be mistaken.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: rand_with_prohib returns -1 even when it is prohobited
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok, I should have suggested this.  Yes, there is a very subtle difference between "-"(1) which is the function "minus" applied to "1" and the honest negative integer "-1". Simplify sorts that out.  It is a bit hard to spot some times....

ResponsesInList.Title: MapleTA question import format
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm in the process of converting MapleTA questions into a format which can be run in native Moodle.  This will probably end up as a combination of Moodle multiple choice and STACK questions.  The import will only be partial, and the resulting questions will still need a lot of editing, but much of the tedious copy and paste will be eliminated.  E.g. question names, and question text will be imported and place in the right Moodle question fields, ready for a human author to edit. Would anyone else value this work?  If so, I'll consider working this up into a Moodle plugin (currently have only skeleton PHP scripts I'm planning to be a one off use!).  If someone else would like to collaborate and help develop this then so much the better.  Please feel free to message me off the list as you prefer. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MapleTA question import format
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you to all those people who replied directly by email. This is a very early prototype, but collaboration is welcome: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qformat_mapleta

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MapleTA question import format
ResponsesInList.Text: We have recently converted a very large number of MapleTA questions to STACK and in the process make significant improvements to the automatic converter. Complete conversion will be impossible, especially since questions authors write Maple code which takes advantage of lots of special functions etc.  So some hand-editing will always be needed to convert the questions.  However, this script has done a lot for us.  If anyone else has legacy materials to convert I'd be happy to help them do so, including extending the converter as needed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK - Update
ResponsesInList.Text: Steve, These plugins are integral to STACK.  I'm about to release a new version of STACK, and I'll update all the plugins as a set at that point.  We intend to support STACK on future Moodle versions, including these plugins as well. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK - Update

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK - Update [Solved]
ResponsesInList.Text: This prob is solved. It was a network prob. I included  the STACK - service to the docker compose - file and it works. Now I can call the service with "alias"-name I gave in the docker compose - file on the config - form of the STACK-Plugin in the Moodle-Webinterface.

ResponsesInList.Title: Backslash removed
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a new problem that never seamed to happen before. I am guessing it happened at an upgrade, but I'm not sure where. When I code a latex equation, the backslashes are removed from the code before it is passed to the tex filter, the result is that in stead of having $$x = \int x dx $$ I get $$x = int x dx$$ I am guessing this is a problem with php. I am using moodle 1.8.1+ on a debian system with php version 5.2.0-8+etch7 Thanx Lindsay

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Backslash removed
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm having the same problem after an upgrade.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Backslash removed
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tommaso So ... This is how I solved the problem I downloaded and installed the mathtran filter module I went to Admin->Modules->Filters->Manage Filters and deactivated the TeX filter and made sure the mathtran and Algebra Notation filters were activated You then need to go to the php.ini file on your moodle server , check that the magic_quotes_gpc in on and magic_quotes_runtime and magic_quotes_sybase are off. Restart your apache server This fixed my problems ... hope it works for you. Cheers Lindsay

ResponsesInList.Title: using the jsMath plugin of VideoTutor
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I just installed the VideoTutor activity module: http://moodle.mat.uam.es/moodle/course/view.php?id=9 which includes the jsMath filter. Since I read that jsMath can be installed as a Moodle filter to render mathematical expressions, I was wondering if the jsMath component of VideoTutor could also be made to work as the intended general filter. Any help would be greatly appreciated. From what I understand, I imagine that I would have to create the jsmath folder under the moodle filter folder and upload only modified versions of the javascript .php and filter.php files so they can locate and use the plugin under videotutor>software>jsMath. If this assumption is correct, what changes do I need to make to the aforementioned files? Thanks in advance!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: using the jsMath plugin of VideoTutor
ResponsesInList.Text:
I'm really sorry I overlooked this post! There is indeed a working jsmath filter. We bundle jsmath with videotutor for convenience. A jsmath filter must be really simple, though. You just need to add a line to the <head> tag: 
```text
<
script
 SRC
="
software/jsMath/easy/load.js
" 
type
=
"text/javascript"
/>
```
 because jsmath works as a javascript filter, so you don't have to do any filtering with php. 
```text
Regards
```
