ResponsesInList.Title: STACK plugin: How to rename inputs, validations, PRTs
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there an easy way to rename inputs, validations and PRTs in STACK question? Currently, if I change the input name in Question text , then a new input (or validation or PRT) appears and the old input seeks a deletion confirmation. So, I need to copy over all settings, which is time consuming. I noted that GitHub code has `rename_input()` and `rename_prt()` functions, but not sure how to execute these from STACK/Moodle interface.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK plugin: How to rename inputs, validations, PRTs
ResponsesInList.Text: In the question edit page, go to the preview (requires at least one successfull storage). There you find a link to "Tidy Stack question tool" in the top right corner. Note that you must not have intermediate states with identical names, otherwise storage to database might fail. Depending on your installation you may or may not rely on lowercase and uppercase characters being different in that sense.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: HOW TO TYPE For Display this @@1/2@@ forms.
ResponsesInList.Text: Use triple @, instead of double @, to enclose the expression. The triple @ enclosed expression will be displayed within double @: @@@@1/2@@@@ --> @@@1/2@@@

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiris plugin not working in Moodle 2.3
ResponsesInList.Text: I made a test and removed my old Wiris files from folder filter and lib/editor/tinymath/tiny_mce/3.4.9/plugins I downloaded the latest Wiris files from http://www.wiris.com/en/plugins/moodle/download and placed the files of Wiris filter to folder filter and plugin files to the place of old tinymath plugin files. I went to site administration and moodle upgraded the filter and plugin. Because there was no Wiris plugin in tinymce plugins folder Wiris gave a note that Wiris plugin might be missing - otherwise the Wiris plugins worked ok with tinymath editor ( I had enabled Wiris plugin from Math filter settings and enabled Wiris filter ) Next I copied the Wiris plugin to tinymce plugins folder and I did not get any errors - and no note about missing Wiris plugin. So according to my test you can use Wiris plugins both with core tinymce editor and with modified tinymath editor. I still suspect that there might be some "mixture" of old and new files on your site - there can't be two Wiris filters but there can be two plugins in different editors - maybe some old file is in cache, non upgraded or some new file is missing, corrupted or in a wrong folder (people sometimes unzip files to wrong subfolders like filter/filter... have you tried to purge all caches from administration menu? If some character is breaking php code it often comes from edited files when people use non suitable text editors that add extra characters or change file format when you save files - or sometimes some javascripts or server side scripts can break code but you should see some error messages in browser error console or site debugging then... and sometimes single files can get corrupted when you move them with ftp ... "Auto" vs "Binary" vs "ASCII" file transfer

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiris plugin not working in Moodle 2.3

ResponsesInList.Title: Creating Graphs in TeX
ResponsesInList.Text: I have been watching some of the discussions here with interest, but not a comprehensive understanding. I am very impressed and interested in the SVG graphs that I see produced with the ascii-SVG filter. Unfortunately the absence of SVG support in IE is a deal breaker for me. Is there a way to do something similar generating PNG or GIF's? A second possible solution for me would be to produce the graphics beforehand, rather than at run time, and load them into a course. That might mean generating the SVG files and converting them to PNG's or GIF's, and then uploading them. To give you and idea of my current work flow: I generate questions sets using a spreadsheet (for example, I might produce 10-20 versions of the same question, each with different parameters). I have added several functions to the sheets to translate and produce the TeX. If I want to include graphics, I generate them first using screen captures, encode the appropriate parameters in the file names, then have a filter generate the appropriate question. It is an arcane process. Being able to generate the questions and the graphics from the appropriate parameters would really streamline things.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating Graphs in TeX
ResponsesInList.Text: The simplest example would be a Cartesian plane with a parabola translated to some location. The context might be: Identify the appropriate equation (multiple choice or fill in the blank) The current work flow would involve: use Geogebra or Geometer' Sketchpad to generate graphs use Snagit to capture them, saving them with a file name that would encode the parameters putting the graphic file names onto a spreadsheet. writing a formula to extract the parameters from the file names. create the question template to use the parameters generate the questions in GIFT format upload the questions. upload the graphics. If the current ascii SVG were available to me the work flow would look more like: Generate the template and parameters Generate the questions Upload the questions. An alternative that would be favorable: Generate the question template and parameters generate the questions Capture the graphics generated by the questions (a possibility with ascii SVG) using snagit, or perhaps generating the SVG files and converting them to PNGs. upload the questions and graphics. The fewer steps, the fewer errors. Obviously STACK would be ideal but its a significant few steps away. I have contemplated trying to integrate with some of the CAS systems (maxima with GNU plot, but I'm not sure I can satisfy my needs without some significant development.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mathjax locally on Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Susana, I was just going to ask a similar question. We installed MathJax 3 on another server and inserted a script tag as "additional html": <script type="text/javascript" src="<path-to-mathjax>/tex-chtml.js?config=TeX-AMS_HTML"></script> Now everything inside 
```text
$$..$$
```
 is interpreted and formulas are displayed, but since it was necessary to deactivate the MathJax filter in moodle, there is not button to add a formula in the Atto editor. Did you find a better way to use new versions of MathJax with moodle? We will probably switch to MathJax 2.7.9. Best, Oliver

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mathjax locally on Moodle

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mathjax locally on Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, the source code (updated a few weeks ago) still contains references to the 2.7.9 version. Also, MathJax 3 is very different from MathJax 2. You could try what I described above, but in our case, the rendered formulas actually look better with v2.

ResponsesInList.Title: How to verify that the answer contains sum()
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there a way in STACK /Maxima types of questions to verify that the student's answer is expressed in a form of a `sum()` function? A toy example: instead of `((X[1]-3)^2+(X[2]-3)^2)/2` we want to require something like `sum(X[i]-3)^2, i, 1, 2)/2` . EqualComAss test is too restrictive and may disallow more complex solutions containing summation. Another purpose is to ensure that \(\prod_i e^{x_i}\) or \(e^{x_1}\cdots e^{x_n}\) is "simplified" to exponent of a sum .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to verify that the answer contains sum()
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, you can check the top operator in the expression is the "sum" function. Maxima's "op" operator throws an error if you ask for the operator of an atom (not a silly design choice), so STACK has "safe_op". This test is relatively new: https://docs.stack-assessment.org/en/Authoring/Answer_tests_rules_based/ I'm sure I haven't accommodated all the sensible use-cases yet. So please suggest some when you encounter a need. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to verify that the answer contains sum()
ResponsesInList.Text: For your second use case you could also use Maxima's function `freeof` to check if the student's answer is containing a sum at all. Stephan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to verify that the answer contains sum()
ResponsesInList.Text: Chris, Stephan, thank you for great suggestions. Maxima Discussion forum also mentioned `freeof` .

ResponsesInList.Title: STACK version 3.0 - sample materials
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear all, We've made substantial progress with STACK over the summer. In particular, yesterday, I added a "Demonstration" moodle course to our GIT repository. https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/samplequestions/STACK-demo.mbz This contains a number of STACK quizzes in basic mathematics, and once you have STACK 3 working restoring this should be a reasonably straightforward way of seeing the kinds of things STACK is designed to do.  It is distributed as part of the STACK GIT repro. (1) I'm using Moodle 2.4(dev), so the course may not import into a much earlier version.  If you have problems please let me know and I'll ponder what to do about it. (2) If you find some errors with the questions, (I have tried to test them throughly, but they won't be perfect) then please let me know. I'd particularly welcome an exported updated working version if you can manage it, otherwise I'll fix the reference copy myself. (3) I'd very much welcome any contributions in a similar direction if you have materials you are willing to release. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Equation not rendering properly
ResponsesInList.Text: If the basic plugins have not been activated then there will be nothing. Need Algebra Notation and Tex plugins at least. These can be activated via the Plugins > Plugins Overview. If you go to something like TexLive, which I think has TeXWorks as native, you can use Tex in any HTML document and create your own PDFs as well. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: jsMath only showing up on my browser?
ResponsesInList.Text: Did you download and install the jsMath-image-fonts.zip file? This is required for the image-mode fallback methods to work properly when the TeX fonts are not installed on the computer running the browser. It may be that you have the TeX fonts available on your computer, but not on the other ones you tested. In that case, jsMath would not be able to load the image font definitions, and would fail to run. That would account for the behavior you are seeing. If that's not it, would you be willing to set up a userid for me to try it out on your Moodle site? I can often figure out the problem more easily that way. You can send me the information via the Moodle message system rather than posting a URL publicly, if you wish.

ResponsesInList.Title: Notation to cross-out math
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi there, Does anyone know how to use Tex notation to cross-out parts of a expression? The idea is that I wil use moodle to teach logic to people who, most of the time, don´t understand math. So, if I have something like: $$  rac{20! 6!}{18! 5!} =  rac{20.19.18!.6.5!}{18! 5!} = 20.19.6 = 2280$$ It is obvious that 18! and 5! are both canceled out, but several people are not able to see that and I need to show on screen that the numerators and denominators are being crossed out. I tried doing that in different ways, but the only option that showed some promisse was using "
ot" before what I wanted to cross out. Like that: $$  rac{20! 6!}{18! 5!} =  rac{20.19.
ot18!.6.
ot5!}{
ot18! 
ot5!} = 20.19.6 = 2280$$ But, as you can see, for 18! and 5! just 1 and 5 are crossed out and I would like something like 18! and 5! . The crossing out of just the first element  would confuse the students, for sure. As it seems, 
ot would only work for unitary stuff, such as crossing out variables like on (and remember that my students are, mostly, completely dumb about math): $$  rac{2x}{x} =  rac{2
ot x}{
ot x}=2$$ Anyone know an alternative to cross out?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notation to cross-out math
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi André, What you need to do is put braces around the thing you want to cross out, i.e. Instead of 
ot 5! you would write 
ot{5!} $$ rac{20! 6!}{18! 5!} =  rac{20.19.
ot18!.6.
ot5!}{
ot18! 
ot5!} = 20.19.6 = 2280$$ becomes $$ rac{20! 6!}{18! 5!} =  rac{20.19.
ot{18!}.6.
ot{5!}}{
ot{18!} 
ot{5!}} = 20.19.6 = 2280$$ Hope this helps, Ian.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notation to cross-out math
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello Andre, Use "
ot" as you have, bust surround the expression you want to cross out with curly brackets: {...}. Also, to avoid confusion of multiplication "dots" with decimal "dots", use "\cdot" which gives a dot but not at the line base: $$ rac{20! 6!}{18! 5!} =  rac{20\cdot19\cdot
ot{18!}\cdot 6 \cdot 
ot{5!}}{18! 5!} = 20 \cdot 19 \cdot 6 = 2280$$

ResponsesInList.Title: Testing that student answer depends on given variables
ResponsesInList.Text: STACK does syntax checking of the student answer and also checks that the answer is of the correct type. Is it also possible to have STACK test that the student's answer depends on all the variables it should depend on?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Testing that student answer depends on given variables
ResponsesInList.Text: It is possible to check this and give specific feedback as part of the PRT, but it is not possible to do this as validation. Possibly intersting idea. I will let Chris comment further.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Testing that student answer depends on given variables
ResponsesInList.Text: Doing it as part of the potential response tree is of course quite adequate. However, how do I code the check. I know of the predicate function polynomialp(ans1,[p]) to check if the answer ans1 is a polynomial in the variable p, but I don't know how to check simply whether the variable p appears in the answer.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Testing that student answer depends on given variables
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there a method that extracts the set of variables from an expression? I don't know. You need Chris. If I really had to work this out, I would look to see how he implemented the check for a constant of integration in that answer test.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Testing that student answer depends on given variables
ResponsesInList.Text: Gustav, Good question. The general principal is that validation should not depend (too much) no the actual answer, and should mostly be about syntax issues.  That way validation doesn't vary (too much) from question to question.  In my view, interface & "validity" should be a reasonably stable concept from the student's point of view. There is a "same type" concept, which does of course depend on the actual answer, but this was mostly to ensure system stability.  If the PRT expects an *equation* y=m*x+c and the student gives an *expression* e.g. m*x=c, then when the PRT take the right hand side, you get an error.  Lots of assumptions about student's responses, and problems arrise from false assumptions, can be dealt with by having type at the validation level. Ideally, we'd have a more subtle and sophisticated concept of type, e.g. %poly(Z; x), or %poly(Q; x,a),  etc.  This could then be used selectively to reject some things which can't possibly be correct.  I think this might be difficult to author, and hard for students to understand. To actually answer your question, have a look at Maxima's listofvars() function. There are a couple of ways of using listofvars(ex).  If you'd just like to know if a single variable appears in an expression use member(p,listofvars(ans1)); To check if it depends on more than one variable in a single step, use sets.  I'd do AlgEquiv test on setify(listofvars(ans1))  with {x,a,b,c}. for example, where the set {x,a,b,c} is the set of variables you want. Chris

ResponsesInList.Text: Transforming Assessment web seminar Wednesday 7 Nov 2012 Title: Automatic assessment of mathematics Presenter: Dr Christopher Sangwin (University of Birmingham, UK) In this free session Chris will describe and demonstrate the STACK question type in Moodle which is designed to assess algebraic mathematics. The basic design requires students to respond with an algebraic expression, rather than using multiple choice questions and can randomly generate versions of problems, establish the properties of any answers and generate outcomes, such as feedback. ResponsesInList.Title: php files
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi I am new at this if I want to edit a php file can i use wordpad and then just save the it?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: php files
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, Jack, you can, but there is the strong possibility that when the file saves, it will save with a number of hidden characters that can be found in the Windows charset. This may have a number of unforeseen consequences that could wreck what it is that you are trying to do. You would be better off downloading and installing a text editor that allows you to save in a UTF-8 format, like TextPad or NotePad++ or Crimson Editor . TextPad is proprietal and the other two are Open Source or Freeware. A lot of people love their Crimson Editor, but I have never used it. I have used both the other two and I cannot pick the difference, except I think I prefer the less flashy TextPad to NotePad++ (but I am an unimaginative and dour type of person, you may like the pretty colours, I dunno). Best bet here, go and have a look at these pages . Oh, btw , the Moodle forums are set up for you to ask almost any question either in a general category, or specific categories like Installation or Forums, or HTML Editor. Think about your questions, where do you think they fit? You might get a lot of help from these forums, or you might not get any help if you put a question in the wrong forum, or someone may advise you to repost the question in another forum. Good luck and enjoy your Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: php files
ResponsesInList.Text: Wordpad? Oh that horrid little MS editor that corrupts everything one edits? Lol! Install netbeans or eclipse if you plan on doing a good deal of editing, and install plugins for php etc

ResponsesInList.Title: MathML in Moodle 2.7
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, MathML code bounded by \ ( and  \ ) show delimiters.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathML in Moodle 2.7
ResponsesInList.Text: Is this a question or a note? If you use the MathJax filter of  moodle 2.7 default configuration enables MathML but it does not check if the page has MathML and that way mathJax does not render MathML unless the page has some TeX with default TeX delimiters - see MDL-43856 and MDL-44989 If you want to use MathML with current MathJax filter you can add to Site administration > Plugins > Filters > MathJax > Additional equation delimiters <math and MathJax will check if pages of moodle have MathML (otherwise only Mozilla browsers render MathML natively on pages) Note also that moodle 2.7 is using HTML5 so you can use plain <math>...</math> tags for mathML: see https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/MathML/Element/math And finally because moodle does have a list of accepted html tags you can't use MathML tags everywhere in moodle - for example forum activity strips MathML tags (and other activities that students can edit... ) Delimiters \ ( ... \ ) are reserved for (La)TeX input in default MathJax configuration

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MathML in Moodle 2.7
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you. Everything is perfectly explained in MDL-44989 . I'm sorry.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DragMath not working.
ResponsesInList.Text: Sounds like you should upgrade your java files - http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=149977

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DragMath not working.
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks. I read this article to update java on my Ubuntu. And it is working. http://www.ehow.com/how_5233065_update-java-ubuntu.html Make sure the Universe package repository is enabled, since that is where Java is downloaded from. Open the Main Menu and go to "System" > "Administration" > "Synaptic Package Manager." Enter your password, and then, when the program comes up, open "Settings" > "Repositories" from the menu at the top of the window. Check the box next to "Community-maintained Open Source software (universe)" if it is not already. Close Synaptic when you're done. 2 Open the Terminal (Main Menu: "Accessories" > "Terminal") and enter the following: sudo apt-get install sun-java6-jre sun-java6-plugin Enter your password at the prompt, and wait while the Sun Java runtime environment and web-browser plugin are installed. You will then be shown the license agreement. Press "Tab" and "Enter" to select "OK" and then "Tab" and "Enter" again to select "Yes." 3 Set your default Java runtime to Sun's version by entering the following in the Terminal: sudo update-java-alternatives -s java-6-sun Now all Java programs will use the Sun Java 6 runtime. Read more: How to Update Java in Ubuntu | eHow.com http://www.ehow.com/how_5233065_update-java-ubuntu.html#ixzz1AoW2h4Nv

ResponsesInList.Title: adding zeros to empty matrix cells in Stack
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey all, we are currently making questions in Stack for students of mechanical engineering. We let the students type the system equations for static mechanical problems into matrix cells. (6x6 for 3D Problems). A lot of those cells need to be zero tho. to make it easyier to type, we’d like to fill all empty cells with zeros or at least fill all the cells with zeros from the beginning. i cant seem to find the answer for this problem. we tried to substitute the „empty“ cell with zeros. but we cannot get the variable of the empty cell to tell maxima to substitute it with zero. can anyone help with that? greetings Danny

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: adding zeros to empty matrix cells in Stack
ResponsesInList.Text: Danny, Yes, this is exactly what the "syntax hint" field in the input is for.  Fill it in with something like matrix([?,0,0],[0,0,0],[0,0,0]) (well, you have a 6*6 version) You might, as I have done, want to put in at least one ? to make this an "invalid" response, otherwise a student who navigates away might have their matrix marked as "wrong" (depending on your settings and penalty scheme).  It is generally sensible to make a syntax hint "invalid" as strange as this might sound at first reading... Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problems with rendering equations
ResponsesInList.Text: The file permissions are: 100644 (for file filter/tex/mimetex.linux) simply means that you have not given that file permission to execute - it is an executable file and needs permission to execute if you want to use it. Try to change the permissions of that one file to 755 (to render latex with mimetex)

ResponsesInList.Title: Answer tests
ResponsesInList.Text:
On https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/doc/en/Authoring/Answer_tests.md you can read about an answer test named "Sets": Sets This test deals with equality of sets. The algebraic equivalence
functions give very minimal feedback. This test is designed to give
much more detailed feedback on what is and is not included in
the student's answer. Hence, this essentially tells the student what is
missing. This is kind of feedback is tedious to generate without this
test. The test simplifies both sets, and does a comparison based on the simplified versions. The comparison relies on `ev(..., simp, nouns)` to undertake the simplification. If you need stronger simplification
(e.g. trig) then you will need to add this to the arguments of the
function first. But I can't find the entry "Sets" in my dropdown list in the prt. Can anybody help me? Regine

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Answer tests
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, we added this answer test on 15th July 2018, so it is quite possible your server does not yet have this! https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/commit/0a11cfb24e0b21f124a949c0d97bdadbb91d1c6a Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tex Filter difficulties in 2.6.2 / problem with convert
ResponsesInList.Text: As an addition to my previous message... In 2.6.2+ (in the stock distribution) mimetex.linux is not working properly in Ubuntu. I fixed this problem installing mimetex (sudo apt-get install mimetex) and replacing mimetex.linux by the new file /usr/bin/mimetex installed. Now the TeX filter fallback to mimetex works. However, I´m still with the problem with /usr/bin/convert execution by moodle, as described in the previous message. regards, Adriano

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tex Filter difficulties in 2.6.2 / problem with convert
ResponsesInList.Text: You might check whether convert is present on command line. This is part of the Imagemagick package (see TeX notation Filte r documentation). Normally, it would be required by the Gnome desktop, but it may need to be added in a server environment with 'apt-get install imagemagick'. When you migrated servers did you move from 32bit to 64bit instance? The binary for mimetex packaged with Linux is probably 32bit.  This should probably be updated or documented if it is the problem.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tex Filter difficulties in 2.6.2 / problem with convert
ResponsesInList.Text: Daniels, thanks for your comments. Convert is working fine as command line. ImageMagick is already installed. The problem appears when convert is called within Moodle. About mimetex.linux, I´m using a 64 bits instance (moving from a 64 bits) and it is indeed very likely that the executable in the stock 2.6.* distribution is Linux 32 bits and the documentation is not mentioning it or I failed to find it. After replacing the mimetex.linux by the /usr/bin/mimetex file installed with apt-get install mimetex, I could get the TeX Filter fallback to mimetex to work fine. The problem is still with convert to work in order to avoid the fallback and get nicer equations. As a sideline, I´ve tested  MathtML, which worked fine, totally avoiding the TeX filter, but because I have lots of quizzes using $$ to define inline Math expressions, I believe it is not a practical solution at this time.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tex Filter difficulties in 2.6.2 / problem with convert
ResponsesInList.Text: I believe that the standard error output is reported more explicitly in /var/log/apache2/error.log. Run texdebug and look at the last line of the file.  Return Code: 1 is probably a permission problem, but could be almost anything else. If that does not help try running on the command line: sudo -u www-data /usr/bin/convert -density 240 -trim /opt/bitnami/apps/moodle/moodledata/temp/latex/c4789a8ae55e12b03bc43ae790befb5e.ps /opt/bitnami/apps/moodle/moodledata/temp/latex/c4789a8ae55e12b03bc43ae790befb5e.png where the last part is copied from recent texdebug ourput. The files are normally kept in temp directory for some time. So this should execute successfully if binary and permissions are correct. Incidently if you have tried MathJax the delimiters can be customized to be to use double $. It just takes a little patience to figure out the syntax.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tex Filter difficulties in 2.6.2 / problem with convert
ResponsesInList.Text: Daniel, thanks again. It appears to me that the problem with convert started with the move from 2.6.1 to 2.6.2. I tested this in my old server, upgrading to 2.6.2.... there was a fallback to Mimetex in the Tex Filter. The full TeX convertion was taking place without problems in 2.6.1 and broke in 2.6.2. By the way, /usr/bin/convert run from command line, as you suggested, works fine, creating the png file. The problem is some place else. In any case, I invested some time in MathJax configuration and ended up disabling the TeX filter, moving to the MathJax alternative. So far I´m pleased with the results. I´m following the discussion on having MathJax already integrated in Moodle 2.7. I believe that is good move.

ResponsesInList.Title: Typesetting questions and feedback in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I am using STACK for very basic questions where I need to take a lot of care with the feedback, and the difficulty, as far as my students are concerned, depends on the presentation.  For instance the equation x^2 + 1 + 2x = 0 is a lot harder than the x^2 + 2x + 1 = 0, because many students will mix up the coefficients when they use the formula. The challenge, now, is to make the question as general as possible while presenting expressions (from maxima) exactly as I want them.  The problem comes up when coefficients may be negative.  When I display a sum defined as a maxima expression the result looks too good, because maxima sorts the terms. If I write a sum of maxima expressions, I need to use parentheses to allow for negative numbers, but ideally I only want necessary parentheses and not superfluous ones.  It would also be better to simplify to avoid unary signs without reorganising terms. Does this problem have a solution?  Is it possible to make inline TeX code conditional by using maxima logic?  Any other approaches? Obviously, I can restrict the range of parameters and create different questions for positive and negative ones, but I try to minimise the number of questions I have to maintain.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Typesetting questions and feedback in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm going to move this to the 'Mathematics tools' forum, since you are more likely to get an answer there.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Typesetting questions and feedback in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I am a bit late with my answer, because I just saw you question. I think in many cases, setting simp to false will solve your problem. So if you define the following in your question variables simp:false; eq1:x^2+1+2*x=0; then {@eq1@} will be displayed in the same order as defined above. Also negative and randomly generated coefficients should be fine. If you have somewhat longish coefficients like a+2*b you can still simplify these coefficients seperately. This solution comes to limits, because if you generate your coefficients randomly and do not forbid -1, 0 and 1 as values, then you might end up with an equation like -1x^2+1+0x=0, which does not look very nice. So I normally try to avoid these "critical" values with my randomization. Stephan.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Typesetting questions and feedback in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Stephen, I agree with your answer. The docs contain some more information on simplification: https://stack2.maths.ed.ac.uk/demo2018/question/type/stack/doc/doc.php/CAS/Simplification.md If you have good examples, please let me know and I'll add them to the docs. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Typesetting questions and feedback in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey Chris, thanks for the link. I'll have an open eye on good examples. Stephan

ResponsesInList.Title: MAXIMA Server
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, for our e-learning plattform we'd like to use the STACK -Plugin and therefore need to install a MAXIMA server . Can you give me recommendations concerned with MAXIMA? I have a virtual instance on our server, I can put any linux flavour on. I prefer debian ... is it advantegous to use CentOS ? Can I start with installing MAXIMA with my package manager (e.g. apt-get install maxima) or is it better to download maxima and compile it manually ? Are there installing manuals available ? What are common pit falls, things to consider with regard to STACK ? Looking forward for your answers! Greets &  Thanks, Matti

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MAXIMA Server
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Matti, I do not think that using the package manager to install is a problem as long as it is a  version of maxima supported by STACK. If you use use CENTOS, the only package in the repos is 5.23.2 which is maintained for legacy reasons and has some problems. You can compile from source, but you may be better off using a distribution with more recent support for maxima. Currently, STACK supports up to version 5.36.1. Daniel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MAXIMA Server
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Daniel, I recommend using Maxima 5.36.1.  Please don't use a more recent version.  Versions 5.37.x (x=0,1,2,3) have a change in behaviour which causes a (minor & isolated) bug in the STACK libraries.  The Maxima developers have very kindly reverted the behaviour to accommodate us, and when a new version is available I'll test this and update the docs accordingly. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: ambiguous validation 2
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, this is another validation issue which created frustration among the students: Both inputs x0 and x_0 are displayed the same in validation.  Once my teachers solution uses x0 any answer with x_0 is refused, athough the students are convinced they did it right. Is there an option to ignore underscores in answers? A workaraound for me is to use an extra PRT entry with SAns=ev(ans, x_0=x0). Now that I write this, it comes to my mind that I also probably could define x_0:x0 in the question variables, once I am aware of the problem. Yet I keep this post to ask for a generic recommendation to handle this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ambiguous validation 2
ResponsesInList.Text: There is, however, a problem with the solution x_0: x0; You have to add x_0 to the allowed words, otherwise it is refused because it is a question variable. This can be very annoying in a multipart question with ten parameters of this type.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ambiguous validation 2
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Martin, what I sometimes did to handle issues like this one is to modify the student answer in the feedback variables and then only check on this modified answer (lets say `mans1` ) in the prt: `mans1: subst(x0,x_0,ans1);` . Stephan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ambiguous validation 2
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, also ev(ans1, x0=x_0) should work. This way you shift the authoring work from the input (allowed words) to the feedback variables. So, still a generic solution just like a global or local (per PRT) would be nice.

ResponsesInList.Title: Simple Maxima Question - Turn x=number to just a number
ResponsesInList.Text: This is I'm sure a blindingly easy Maxima question that I've hunted for an answer for a while now but can't seem to fish it out... I have a quadratic that I've solved for x.  The solve function gives its output in the form of x= 0.6492374 and x= -0.3473.  I need to do something with those numbers afterwards which means I need them to just be numbers rather than x= a number. I'm sure there has to be a straightforward function for this I just can't seem to find it. Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Simple Maxima Question - Turn x=number to just a number
ResponsesInList.Text: Eventually answered my own question. There is a straightforward function for this.  They are rhs() and lhs() which are abbreviations of "right hand side" and "left hand side."

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Simple Maxima Question - Turn x=number to just a number
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, there are a number of tricks here, and some others are documented here: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/doc/en/CAS/Equations.md

ResponsesInList.Title: LTI embedded timed quizzes throws javascript error and breaks MathJax (impacts on STACK questions most)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Thought I would share details of a bug I've found when using moodle- STACK quizzes as a provider service to another VLE via LTI .  When using LTI to embed a moodle quiz, the side blocks (and headers and footers) are not displayed.  Unfortunately if the quiz timer is enabled, when the underlying javascript attempts to update the timer, it can't find it as the Quiz Navitation block has been removed as part of the LTI embedding.  This through a javascript error which stops any MathJax rendering in its tracks and leads to raw LaTeX being displayed.  This is obviously very problematic for any STACK based questions which depends heavily on MathJax.  Our only solution (unless anyone else can suggest anything) is to not use timers with quizzes if embedding the quiz via LTI. I've logged a bug about this issue here, including more detail, a screenshot and step-by-step instructions to reproduce the problem. https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-66544 Any advice/fixes really appreciated! Best wishes, Stuart.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LTI embedded timed quizzes throws javascript error and breaks MathJax (impacts on STACK questions most)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Stuart, It may help to enable the TeX notation filter in case MathJax filter fails. However, I am not sure that fixes the timer issue. If the timer js fails it will would not automatically redirect when the time has expired, nor would students no the time they have finish. They would work on a problem or page without knowing that it will not count. I would suspect that this is something that you may be able to fix in the theme renderer. Are you working with a standard theme?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LTI embedded timed quizzes throws javascript error and breaks MathJax (impacts on STACK questions most)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Daniel, Thanks for the reply. I have the Tex and MathJax filters both enabled, but the rendering fails regardless. The timer issue is a pain. The timer is still running, but the student has no indication of how much time remains. Once the student reaches the point where the time has expired (though they don't it) they can continue to work on the question, but as soon as they navigate away, say to the previous question, they get bounced to the attempt finished page. All in all it is unhelpful behaviour which basically means you can't use the timer functionality with embedded LTI quizzes. Regards, Stuart.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LTI embedded timed quizzes throws javascript error and breaks MathJax (impacts on STACK questions most)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Stuart, The TeX notation filter is failing for other reasons. There are probably missing executables on the server . You can check that on the filter configuration page. It is worth doing if you have a lot of mathematics in case MathJax fail like this or it you use the mobile app.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LTI embedded timed quizzes throws javascript error and breaks MathJax (impacts on STACK questions most)
ResponsesInList.Text: Wow! I did not know that they had hidden the Quiz navigation block as part of LTI embedding. That seems like a really bad idea for all sorts of reasons.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LTI embedded timed quizzes throws javascript error and breaks MathJax (impacts on STACK questions most)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LTI embedded timed quizzes throws javascript error and breaks MathJax (impacts on STACK questions most)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hmm. I suppose there is sort of logic to that (and its been there for 3 years). But in the case of the quiz, the side-effect of hiding the navigation block cripples the UI in my opinion. We really need something better.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LTI embedded timed quizzes throws javascript error and breaks MathJax (impacts on STACK questions most)
ResponsesInList.Text: I absolutely agree. I seem to remember that when the LTI functionally was confined to the installable plugin, rather than in the core product, you had the option to toggle which elements would be hidden in the embedded frame with a choice of header, footer, left side blocks, right side blocks. If that behaviour were restored, for my situation at least I would be able to get by. Alternatively simply allowing the navigation block for quizzes through in all cases would be best. Tim: Do you carry any weight with moodle on this? Is there anything I can do beyond what I already have (bug report) to get this fixed in a future release? Thanks, Stuart.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LTI embedded timed quizzes throws javascript error and breaks MathJax (impacts on STACK questions most)
ResponsesInList.Text: Tim, We could change quiz renderer to place navigation panel at top or bottom of page on embedded pages. I am not sure whether that makes sense as a design or how it would affect accessibility .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LTI embedded timed quizzes throws javascript error and breaks MathJax (impacts on STACK questions most)
ResponsesInList.Text: Just discovered this issue is more unhelpful than I initially thought. Even if the timer is not used, if the " Close the quiz " option is used instead, a timer will still automatically appear 1 hour before the date/time is reached and the use of the timer again triggers this bug which breaks any mathjax rendering. The right solution here is not to remove the navigation block at all. It's a really bad idea.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LTI embedded timed quizzes throws javascript error and breaks MathJax (impacts on STACK questions most)
ResponsesInList.Text: I thought I would follow up with one final post about this in case anyone in the future needs help resolving it. Because of the impact the issue was having, I decided to dive in and work out my own fix. I have essentially changed the theme files I was using (boost theme) to update the embedded layout rule to point to different versions of embedded.php and embedded.mustache which add in the blocks column.  I've carefully documented this process and included some sample files for an older and newer version of moodle.  See attached zip file. In the long term I would see the best fix in core to be either my fix, although I don't know all the contexts in which embedded layout is used and therefore cannot comment on undesirable side effects.  OR an additional layout is created for LTI specific embedded based on my fix. I checked the impact of not having the blocks show against a range of tools.  Quizzes are serious impacted.  The Book resource tool will not show the Chapter block.  I was unable to test the Workshop tool due to the amount of effort required to set it up.  All other tools/resources did not have any dependencies on the side blocks and therefore aren't impacted by this issue. I've also updated my bug report with the attached with the hope that a fix makes its way into the core code in the future. Thanks to Daniel for giving me the initial pointer in the code so I could start to unpick the problem. Regards, Stuart

ResponsesInList.Title: Is there a whiteboard feature of moodle ?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm interested in using a whiteboard to teach math courses interactively. Does moodle support such a features os is there a plugin that does that? Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a whiteboard feature of moodle ?
ResponsesInList.Text: AFAIK , no. Having said that, AIUI, and I have only used Promethean whiteboards, the whiteboard software actually takes care of the interactivity, which means, to me, that it may be a somewhat self defeating kind of exercise to be using an interactive whiteboard in a Moodle environment. These are two tools, one to set up the exercise, Moodle, the other to physically involve the students. For a start though, you may want to place this question into the General Developer's forum, and as a Moodle Tracker item, then send an email to your whiteboard provider asking them if they had considered such a move.

ResponsesInList.Title: Algebra filter and negative numbers
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi- I'm having trouble with inequalities that have negative numbers: @@@x<>-2@@@, @@@x<=-2@@@ and @@@x>=-2@@@ all give @@x-2@@. Any suggestions? Thanks. -Jennifer

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Algebra filter and negative numbers
ResponsesInList.Text: Sorry, it's a bug.  I'll try to fix it tomorrow.  In the meantime, a workaround would be to write the inequalities backwards: @@@-2<>x@@@ ==> @@-2<>x@@ etc.  Another workaround would be to use the debugging script http://yourmoodlesite/filter/algebra/algebradebug.php, enter the expression without the negative sign, click on "Second Stage Tex Translation", put the minus sign there, and then enter the resulting expression in TeX syntax: x<= 2   -----> x \leq 2  ----> x \leq -2 ----> $$$ x\leq -2 $$$ ----> $$x \leq -2$$

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Algebra filter and negative numbers
ResponsesInList.Text: I've put a bug fix for this problem in the cvs .  The files affected are filter/algebra/filter.php filter/algebra/AlgParser.pm filter/algebra/algebradebug.php You will need to use the algebradebug.php script to delete the cache database entries for any expressions which were processed by the previous buggy versions of the algebra filter.php

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Algebra filter and negative numbers
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks! All is well now.

ResponsesInList.Title: Odp: Re: Algebra filter and negative numbers
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a problem with negative numbers used in lim parameters. When for example variable in base (I'm not sure if i name this correctly in english) goes to negative number, the algebra filter display it incorrectly. Example: lim((x^3-3x^2+2)/(x^2-4),x,-7) displays as @@lim((x^3-3x^2+2)/(x^2-4),x,-7)@@ After removing minus sing from number "7" algebra filter display it correctly. Thanks in advance for response.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Odp: Re: Algebra filter and negative numbers
ResponsesInList.Text: Why not use Tex or Asciimathml instead of Algebra filter that has a very limited subset of commands you can use in Tex. For example \lim_{x\to{-7}}\frac{x^3-3x^2+2}{x^2-4} between double dollars gives $$\lim_{x\to{-7}}\frac{x^3-3x^2+2}{x^2-4}$$

ResponsesInList.Title: Odp: Re: Odp: Re: Algebra filter and negative numbers
ResponsesInList.Text: You're right. I forgot about Tex filter. Thank You

ResponsesInList.Title: Stack: removing brackets only!
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello,

How can I remove the brackets from the expression
%3x^2-(-5x^2-14x+2) without reducing it totaly.
I need to check that 3x^2+5x^2+14x-2 commutatively equal to the first student answer.

I tried to swith off simp and the do :
%3x^2+ev(factor(-(-5x^2-14x+2), simp:true);
it gives me
%3x^2+(5x^2+14x-2);
I still have brackets.!!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stack: removing brackets only!
ResponsesInList.Text: Firstly x^2-(-5x^2-14x+2) is not equal to x^2+5x^2+14x-2 up to "commutativity and associativity" because you are distributing -1 over addition!  I agree that the test you ask for is very useful (and something you'd want to test for).  But, I have not written a function to distribute "-" over a sum and "sort out any resulting --". Unary minus has been the the most difficult thing for me to deal with in STACK . I'm sure it would be possible to do so. For code which does similar things you might like to look between lines 266-336 of https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/stack/maxima/stackmaxima.mac The "Sandbox" will be invaluable if you write some Maxima code. https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/doc/en/CAS/STACK-Maxima_sandbox.md Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Stack: removing brackets only!
ResponsesInList.Text: I should also add that I made a start on this myself some time ago, and I have placed the code in GitHub, https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/stack/maxima/elementary.mac There is also a file of "experimental code". The point of this is to define "elementary rules" which will transform the expression repeatedly. Start in the Maxima sandbox and load("elementary"); As an example take your expression, simp:false; p:x^2-(-5*x^2-14*x+2) ; Now, we can apply "rules" such as "distribute unary minus over addition", this is called "negDistAdd" p:transr(p,"negDistAdd"); this gives x^2+(-(-5)*x^2-(-14*x)-2) Next, we need to use associativity of addition, "assAdd" p:transr(p,"assAdd"); x^2-(-5)*x^2-(-14*x)-2 We continue with a rule which removed "--", p:transr(p,"negNeg"); x^2-(-5)*x^2+14*x-2 Notice, this sorted out the "-(-14*x)", but not the "-(-5)*x^2", but as I said, this code is experimental and I never finished this off..... I hope this gives you some idea of the issues involved in making this work. I'm sure it is possible to do, however. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Asciisvg
ResponsesInList.Text: I think one problem is that there are some issues when it comes to using asciimathml and asciisvg via the php filter with various quiz modules. You may want to reference asciimathml via meta.php (Mauno posted the changes necessary) and turn off the filter. This results in asciimath working in the message block and in the quiz module and I think results in a bit quicker performance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Asciisvg
ResponsesInList.Text:
You will have a meta.php in your theme's directory and it will look something like the code below.... Note the inclusion of the two script stanzas. Just make sure the second points to the correct directory. 
```text
<script type="text/
javascript
">


 _editor_skin = "xp-blue"; // If you want use a skin, add the name (of the folder) here


 _editor_lang = "en"; // And the language we need to use in the editor.


 var mathcolor = "black"; // You may change the color the formulae are displayed (default: red)


 var mathfontfamily = "Arial"; //and the font (default: serif, which is good I think)


 </script>


<script type="text/javascript" src="<?php echo $CFG->httpswwwroot ?>/lib/editor/htmlarea/plugins/Equation/ASCIIMathML.js"></script>
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Asciisvg
ResponsesInList.Text: Hmm ... I'm using the Knowledge Library-theme from Themza, and there's no meta.php-file in the directory, so I first switched to the standard theme and edited meta.php and made sure the referenced directory was right, also disabled the filter in the Moodle admin section, but then I got a problem in IE7: when I open the question, the MathPlayer splash screen coms up, but nothing appeared, and when I tried to resize the window, IE7 froze, so I had to end it via the task manager. In Firefox 3, it worked fine though, and indeed faster. Since there's no meta.php-file in the Knowledge Library-directory, I suppose the theme refers to meta.php of the standard theme? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Asciisvg
ResponsesInList.Text: It depends on two settings in theme config.php: $THEME->metainclude = true; When this is enabled (or not set!) then Moodle will try to include a file meta.php from this theme into the <head></head> part of the page. $THEME->standardmetainclude = true; When this is enabled (or not set!) then Moodle will try to include a file meta.php from the standard theme into the <head></head> part of the page. So if you want to use extra meta tags for all themes place the tags to standard theme meta.php and make sure that standardmetainclude is true in theme config.php - otherwise place tags to custom theme meta.php and make sure that metainclude in custom theme config.php is not false...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Asciisvg
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, Mauno, but the problem persists. Here's what I did: - added $THEME->metainclude = true; to the config.php of the custom theme - created a meta.php file with the <script>- sections of the code posted by Marc (but with references to the correct asciimath-directory in my setup).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Asciisvg
ResponsesInList.Text: IE does not obviously understand some part of the 3rd example (sorry!) \begin{graph} xmin=-6.3; xmax=6.3; xscl=1; plot(x*sin(1/x),null,null,1000); width=200; height=200; border=25; xmin=-1; xmax=6; xscl=1; ymin=-1; plot(sin(x)+2.5); a = [0,0]; b = [5,5]; marker = "dot"; line(a,b); text(b,"b",aboveleft) ; stroke = "red"; path([a,[0,5],b,[5,0]]) ; stroke = "green"; marker = "none"; curve([a,[.25,0],[.5,.5],[1,1],[1.5,1.5]]) ; stroke = "blue"; circle([5,0],1); ellipse([0,5],1,2); stroke = "purple"; rect([0,0],[2,2],null,.5,1) ; marker = "arrowdot"; line(a,[5,0]);\end{graph} It also looks like IE can stop responding (it keeps sending the alert message) due this kind of unexpected error with the fallback version of asciimathml - the old non fallback version of asciimathml.js gave the same error but only once. Using only Firefox with asciisvg or asciimathml may be safer...IE has never had and probably will never have sufficient support for svg in any form even with SVG Viewer installed. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Asciisvg
ResponsesInList.Text: Indeed, the third example now works fine ... I wish I could say that all students at our school use Firefox, but ... alas! We did have a meeting today, and the possibilities of asciimath exceed the teachers' expectations!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Asciisvg
ResponsesInList.Text: Sorry I have not been more active but here in Anchorage it is the end of the quarter for a college I teach at, beginning of the semester at another college I teach at and the start of the tear for the local public school district for some of whose teachers I provide Moodle services... and it has been a bit hectic ;=} I am glad things are working! If you are using the fallback code that I have posted then yes there are some things that need to be fixed and I am going to have to work with Mauno to make sure I understand what may have happened to your usage. Yes, asciimath is wonderful and I encourage you, based on the sentiments you have expressed here to VOTE to include asciimath as a core Moodle 2 technology and a complement to DragMath. See this forum link for details! http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=102954&parent=455471 Firefox is SOOOOO simple because the fonts can easily be installed and you need nothing additional to do SVG but d.svg installed in the same directory. Additionally, if you have looked about you have noted that asciimath comes with a calculator and you can use that as a source to actually construct lots o stuff (one example is EqEd, the asciimathml equation editor, which is included with xinha in Mauno dropin xinharepla replacement for htmlarea (plug, plug, plug) However, because not everyone is using firefox (yet) I think it important that Moodle users have a simple solution that includes fallback when the browser is unable to do the MathML, for whatever reason. Its for that reason I am trying to find the time to finish the fiddling I am doing with David Lippman's fallback script so that a) users only get one warning per session, b) the warning simply indicates what needs to be installed (if the browser will support MathML/SVG with incremental installs) and advises that asciimathml will fall back to using mimetex or mathtran c) and admins have adequate details so that they can install via theme so as to avoid conflicts in other modules and speed processing s well as point the fallback at an appropriate mimetex or mathtran server . Frankly, I am disappointed that Moodle .org does not use it for Moodle (you can post a tracker request to that end) In any event, while some of the asciimath code can be quite confusing, you will see if you look that you can change the delimiter tokens (your versin should use <amath>...</endamath>, <agraph> and <endagraph>, as well as <`>...<`> and <$>...<$> (I am using "<" and ">" for illustration purposes only, asciimathml does not use this style of xml tag) the /$ not the same as /$/$ (the former used to tell asciimath to parse tex, the latter being ignored by asciimath) . SO, you can fiddle about with tokens and the symbol tables and just generally have a ball.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Asciisvg
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I came accross this thread while geting ready to write something about asciisvg and internet explorer. Anyway it got me thinking- mainly because like you I can't force my students to use Firefox. Yes IE is not great but it shouldn't be that bad. So having a closer look at that equation. \begin{graph} xmin=-6.3; xmax=6.3; xscl=1; plot(x*sin(1/x),null,null,1000); width=200; height=200; border=25; xmin=-1; xmax=6; xscl=1; ymin=-1; plot(sin(x)+2.5); a = [0,0]; b = [5,5]; marker = "dot"; line(a,b); text(b,"b",aboveleft) ; stroke = "red"; path([a,[0,5],b,[5,0]]) ; stroke = "green"; marker = "none"; curve([a,[.25,0],[.5,.5],[1,1],[1.5,1.5]]) ; stroke = "blue"; circle([5,0],1); ellipse([0,5],1,2); stroke = "purple"; rect([0,0],[2,2],null,.5,1) ; marker = "arrowdot"; line(a,[5,0]);\end{graph} I got that pop up error in IE but it still drew a graph. When compared to firefox's version they were exactly the same. But then I realised that neither had drawn the first plot. So is IE just being more correct by notifying that there is a problem where FF just ignores it and moves on. Anyway I believe that this graph statement should not have two versions of xmax and xmin, and I would think it is at least best practise to define the graph area before plotting anything. If you take out the first set as they are over-riddent by the second set, and move the first plot statement so it is after the scale statements i.e. \begin{graph} width=200; height=200; border=25; xmin=-1; xmax=6; xscl=1; ymin=-1; plot(x*sin(1/x),null,null,1000); plot(sin(x)+2.5); a = [0,0]; b = [5,5]; marker = "dot"; line(a,b); text(b,"b",aboveleft) ; stroke = "red"; path([a,[0,5],b,[5,0]]) ; stroke = "green"; marker = "none"; curve([a,[.25,0],[.5,.5],[1,1],[1.5,1.5]]) ; stroke = "blue"; circle([5,0],1); ellipse([0,5],1,2); stroke = "purple"; rect([0,0],[2,2],null,.5,1) ; marker = "arrowdot"; line(a,[5,0]);\end{graph} it now works in both IE and firefox. (although it did take about 40 seconds more to load in IE than firefox. regards Shaun ps - I too think asciimathml is a great little script. Been using it since moodle1.5. What I was going to write about was the difficulty I have in getting graphs to display at all from moodle to IE. Way back then it was a small bug in asciimathml if I remember. Anyway I upgrading to 1.9 and again could not get graphs to show in IE. I have finally got it to work but I had to actually set the full path to d.svg in asciimathml and voila graphs now work correctly. (don't reply to this problem here as I will now go back and start a new thread about it)

ResponsesInList.Title: STACK: caching behaviour since release 4.4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Unfortunately our moodle/ STACK service went off line this morning for a number of hours.  We run moodle on an Ubuntu based server setup (with separate servers for database and goemaxima/docker) and it exists solely to deliver STACK based quizzes. We've pinned down the problem to the number of inodes/files reaching the capacity of our moodle server.  This was preventing apache from reliably restarting and also blocking an integration to moodle.  After we diagnosed that the inode capacity was at maximum, we resolve the issue by removing a historical copy of the moodledata directory and also by clearning the STACK question cache which had 722,214 entries in it. I note that from the moodle 4.4.0 release notes, this is mentioned: The number of CAS-evaluation sessions has been cut down significantly. Conversely, the amount of things happening in a single CAS-session has grown significantly. This may affect your Maxima load and the size of the CAS-cache. You may need to retune your operation if you have fine tuned it based on those details. This will also affect cache keys and values so tuning caching may also matter if one tunes everything. Does this refer to the file caching that is done or database caching? We have built up 722,214 cache entries since August. Is this high or what you would expect under STACK 4.4.0+ ? (we are running 4.4.4). One of our actions is to increase the size of the /var directory where moodledata is stored which will in turn increase the inodefile number capacity. What other optimisations do you recommend to help our server cope better? Were there any signicant changes in moodle 4.0+ that resulted in the number of cached files increasing? Our server info says that these were also big users of files:

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: caching behaviour since release 4.4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: For Moodle application caching (moodledata/cache) it is worth looking at a real caching solution (e.g. Redis) rather than just the default cachestore_file. (But, I am quite impressed if mod_quiz_overrides cache can be that big!) To clear the STACK cache, you can go to Admin -> Plugins -> Question types -> STACK, then click the Healthcheck link, then click the Clear the cache button. You might need to introduce a process were you do that once per term, or something.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: caching behaviour since release 4.4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Tim. One of the steps to resolve our issue was indeed to clear the STACK cache. I was looking at Redis yesterday afternoon after I posted my message here and will dig further. Am I correct that STACK 4.4.x versions are caching a LOT more in moodledata/cache than previously? Thanks, Stuart

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: caching behaviour since release 4.4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't think so. If anything, I would expect there to be less caching, but I could be wrong.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: STACK: caching behaviour since release 4.4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks. In which case it makes me think that my stepped upgrade from moodle 3.11 to 4.1 resulted in a lot of extra initial caching for core_htmlpurifier and mod_quiz_overrides. I expect somewhere there is advice that I should clear caches after an upgrade. Purging all caches early this morning as reduced the inode usage from 96% to 6%, but I'll continue to monitor it and definitely test a Redis setup. Good to know that STACK caching is more or less the same. Thanks again.

ResponsesInList.Title: New version of algebra filter
ResponsesInList.Text: Enclosed is an update to the algebra filter, which converts calculator type algebraic expressions (aka TeX without backslashes) into gif images.  The main improvement is that one can enter these expressions delimited by @@ tags, i.e. @@some algebraic expression@@. This circumvents the current incompatibilities with the HTML Editor, which currently mangles the alternative <algebra>some algebraic expression</algebra> tags. (The <algebra> tags are still recognized by the filter.) If one wants to enter a single @ character, one can do so without the filter transforming it. If one wants to enter @@, @@@, @@@@, etc. without interpretation by the filter, one needs to enter an extra @. Thus @@@ comes out as @@, @@@@ as @@@, etc. and the filter will not try to interpret adjacent text as algebraic expressions. Some additional improvements are that the filter now recognizes a wider set of algebraic expressions than in its previous incarnation. For instance, it will now allow = signs, differentials, derivatives, and integrals. You can visit my site at the following url: https://webwork2.math.ohio-state.edu/moodle1_2d/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=12&username=guest , where some examples are shown. You will be automatically logged into a special guest account which allows posting to the forum, so you can experiment with entering expressions on my site, and I hope you will do so. The cvs has also been updated.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle not detecting MathML content, not loading MathJax
ResponsesInList.Text:
Moodle doesn't load MathJax.js on our pages with MathML. It doesn't show up in either the HTML or a script-loader script call. I think the mathjax-loader filter isn't detecting the content. It works on our pages with TeX content. We have tried the default MathJax.Hub.Config as well as several variations, most of which contained: 
```text
 jax: ["input/MathML", "input/TeX", "output/CommonHTML"],
```
 BTW , if we insert MathJax.js via Site Admin > Appearance > Additional HTML, the MathML displays correctly. So the issue appears to be in the filter. Is there some specific MathML string it's looking for? Suggestions appreciated.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle not detecting MathML content, not loading MathJax
ResponsesInList.Text: There is box in filter setting for addition delimiters. You need to enter a string there so that it knows you are looking for mathml.

ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks. For anyone else with this issue, see also https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=260070#p1127340

ResponsesInList.Title: Release of algebra questions in STACK format as open educational resources
ResponsesInList.Text: It gives me great pleasure to announce the further release of approximately 140 algebra questions in STACK format as open educational resources. Each of these questions should have randomly generated versions full worked solution You can see these questions directly without going through Moodle using the Direct interface . STACK is designed to integrate with the Moodle quiz module for use with students where identity management is important. As a catalogue of questions I have, with permission , used "A pocket map of algebraic manipulation" by Tony Barnard of Kings College London. See http://stack.bham.ac.uk/worksheets/pdf/AlgebraMap.pdf At the heart of the secondary school algebra curriculum lies the development of skills in algebraic manipulation. This little booklet collects together for reference some of the stepping stones of experiences in the development of these basic algebraic skills. The new version of Tony's Map has links to on-line exercises and worked solutions provided by the STACK system. The source code for the STACK questions has been released released under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ The source code has been placed in the STACK CVS under sample_questions/oer/AlgMap. xml .

ResponsesInList.Title: Weird STACK Behavior With Strict Syntax and units of "g"
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm having a little trouble getting the units to be recognized correctly on this STACK question that I've attached.  I'm wondering if this has to do with the fact that "g" is the only unit expected here because I haven't seen similar behavior on other questions. As an example, an answer might be 65.0g.  When that's entered, I get the following results: Input Insert Stars Strict Syntax Result Expected? 65.0g Yes Yes Invalid NO 65.0g Yes No Valid Yes 65.0g Yes, single character Yes Invalid NO 65.0g Yes, single character No Valid Yes If I edit the question to use "m" as the unit instead of "g" then 65.0m is valid Insert stars and strict syntax on. In a different question where the answer might be 1440000ng, I get the following: Input Insert Stars Strict Syntax Result Expected? 1440000ng Yes Yes Valid Yes 1440000ng Yes No Valid Yes 1440000ng Yes, single character Yes Valid (but splits n and g) Yes 1440000ng Yes, single character No Valid (but splits n and g) Yes Now you're probably saying, "well just turn off strict syntax. That will fix it."  And it will for the first one.  But a student who puts in scientific notation with strict syntax off will get the E treated as a unit.  And that doesn't really work well for things like 1440000ng. Thoughts?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Weird STACK Behavior With Strict Syntax and units of "g"
ResponsesInList.Text: Joshua, This behaviour was (globally) intended.  See the code: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/stack/cas/casstring.class.php#L833 The letters "f" and "g" are currently assumed to be function names. I'm open to suggestions for changes here.  But adding yet more options will complicate things! Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Weird STACK Behavior With Strict Syntax and units of "g"
ResponsesInList.Text: Oy... That makes STACK near unusable for units for me.  The number of times that we calculate the mass of something in chemistry is huge and its always in grams. Is this something that could be changed just in the Units input type?  I think that seems perfectly sensible everywhere else.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Weird STACK Behavior With Strict Syntax and units of "g"
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes Joshua, I'll change this in the STACK 3.5.5 release, due soon. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Weird STACK Behavior With Strict Syntax and units of "g"
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Chris!

ResponsesInList.Title: How to enforce Input from JSXGraph in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: In the attached question I use three input fields bound to three points in a JSXGraph sketch. As long as the points aren't touched, the input fields remain empty. How can I avoid this? A first idea would be to slightly modify the position of all points in the script and hope that this would trigger update of the input field. Empty input fields break the potential response tree, that's why I have to solve the problem.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to enforce Input from JSXGraph in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Martin, one possibility would be to store the coordinates of all three points in one single answer as a list. Then the list won't be empty if at least one point has been moved and you can read the coordinates from this list in your feedback variables. Stephan.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to enforce Input from JSXGraph in STACK
Re: How to enforce Input from JSXGraph in STACK
Re: How to enforce Input from JSXGraph in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Martin, this is an interesting workaround; good to know, because I have also had this problem. What I don't like so much about the workaround is that it would generate a specific feedback ("wrong answer ...") even if the question had not been answered by the student, right? (I used to either store all information in one list or I added a note, that all points had to be moved at least once for the question to be marked.) Stephan.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to enforce Input from JSXGraph in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Stephan, I had to poke around for hours to come to that solution. In my case there are variants where leaving the points where they are is actually the correct answer (if all strain components happen to be zero, which I didn't exclude in the randomization). The purpose of the workaround is actually to generate specific feedback even if nothing has been done except pressing "check". I'd expect some method like touch() to exist, which you can call in order to trigger an update. It is interesting that the offset must be big enough to actually shift the point to a different grid snap position. Otherwise the engine is smart enough to check that actually nothing has changed. Martin

ResponsesInList.Title: New TeX commands via packages?
ResponsesInList.Text: Some of my faculty members want to use commands available in packages that aren't available in the usual MathJax command set.  Is there any way to extend the command set via packages? Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: New TeX commands via packages?
ResponsesInList.Text: This might be in the wrong forum actually where someone else may be able to provide a better solution than this. The current setup uses the CDN version of MathJax, as you know but, you may not know that you can install a local version of MathJax and use that. When you have downloaded and installed a local version, you can then mod it by adding any packages you want. Obviously you will need Ghostscript or similar to convert the TeX, I don't think that comes as part of MathJax. One issue you may run into, (you shouldn't but..) Atto uses the CDN as native, but may not play nicely with a local version, so you may have to use TinyMCE as your editor. There are any number of TinyMCE plugins that will extend the user friendliness of TinyMCE that are just not yet available for Atto, including music notation, Poodll Anywhere and lots of other stuff. Another possible alternative is to download and install the entire texlive package to your server and add that to your Moodle. (Not difficult,, but can be tricky.) That way you can add anything you like without having to adapt or rewrite any of the MathJax custom code. I'm sure someone else will have a better approach than this, but it might help.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: New TeX commands via packages?
ResponsesInList.Text: Blair, Mathjax does have some additional packages that can be added to added by changing the configuration. You should check mathjax.org to see if the commands you want are available there. Extension to mathjax have to be added by implementing them in javascript so the commands available in MathJax more limited than what is available in a LaTeX distribution. The TeX notation filter can be configured to use almost any standard LaTeX package. Which TeX commands are you looking for?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: New TeX commands via packages?
ResponsesInList.Text: Aha! I didn't realize MathJax could load additional packages. The ams option gives them what they need. Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: New TeX commands via packages?
ResponsesInList.Text: I didn't realize either, thanks Daniel, but then I should have ask you to begin with. 😉

ResponsesInList.Title: Question variable randomisation behaviour in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, We have been using STACK for around 10 years at Manchester University.  One of my colleagues told me about a problem we used to(?) have with the use if randomised variables in questions.  I don't think this is the case anymore, but I wanted to confirm that it definitely isn't. The problem We sometimes allow students to take a practice version of a quiz many times and then afterwards, an assessment version which uses the same questions from the question bank. Unfortunately, we discovered that the randomisation
seed worked in such a way that the question in the assessment was EXACTLY the
same as the first practice attempt i.e. the same set of random numbers had been
generated by the same seed etc. At the time, there did not seem a proper
solution to this so we got round it by creating a duplicate of each question
and then applying a minor change (e.g. changing one of the randomisation
parameters). Can you confirm if this was a known issue some years back and is now no longer an issue? Recently we have re-tested this issue and can no longer reproduce the problem. but I want to be sure before I start inviting new users to use our STACK service. Thanks and best wishes, Stuart.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Question variable randomisation behaviour in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Good question Stuart, Tim and I have been emailing about this issue this morning. I am pretty sure that what you are seeing is a good side-effect of https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-6340 . That change went into Moodle 2.9. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Question variable randomisation behaviour in STACK
ResponsesInList.Text: Many thanks Chris.  And I see that Colin asked about this directly (he's forwarded the email conversation to me). Best wishes, Stuart

ResponsesInList.Title: which packages are supported?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everybody, where can I see which packages Maxima supports by Stack, where can I see which packages are optionally supported? I refer to " Not all Maxima functions are enabled by STACK , for obvious security reasons. It may be that your function belongs to a library which STACK does not load by default. Do you need to use Maxima's load command to use it? If so, you will need to ask your system administrator or the developers to add a load command so that this library becomes available. Some libraries are optional and may not be included by your local installation. You should also be aware that there are also a number of functions defined by STACK which are not standard Maxima functions. The command you need may well not be enabled since you should use one STACK provides instead." Lot of greetings Regine

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: which packages are supported?
ResponsesInList.Text: Regine, The answer to this is not entirely simple, because different versions of Maxima ship with different packages, and your system admin may have disabled some.  But, the packages which are optional at a site level are here: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/settings.php#L105 The Maxima code which loads packages on any system is here: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/blob/master/stack/maxima/stackmaxima.mac#L84 Please note this issue: https://github.com/maths/moodle-qtype_stack/issues/306 Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: which packages are supported?
ResponsesInList.Text: Chris, thanks a lot! Regine

ResponsesInList.Title: descartes
ResponsesInList.Text:
I have done a little reverse engineering and have descarte (see, http://descartes.cnice.mecd.es/ ) up and running for anyone interested. For those unaware of descartes, it looks quite a bit like Java Sketchpad in some respects. The website provides a rather extensive curriculum and info on using the applet . The download links were not working and there was no download option for *nix archives. The downloads are in self exploding exe files so the download links that do work can be a bit of a pain for non-Windows users. There were also some issues with name and location of class files. In any event, 9000 files later I have what I think is the complete curriculum in both English and Spanish running. I have also located a contact in Spain (José R. Galo, Coordinador Proyecto Descartes) who is willing to correspond about the work the Ministry has done (this is some very nice material) and I have asked him to subscribe to the forum. The course work is actually outside the moodle as the courses are not self contained as one would see in a SCORM and I would be happy to provide info to anyone wishing to look at ripping any of it pending the Ministry's resolution of the download issues. I did post previously about ways to identify a correct codebase from within a moodle resource or activity without requiring that the resource live in the same directory as the applet and in a directory that is exxposed to the external world (i.e. accessible without resort to the moodle) and have had no takers on that one. I have noticed code such as this: 
```text
codebase
="<?php echo $CFG->
wwwroot
.'/lib/editor/tinymce/jscripts/tiny_mce/plugins/dragmath/
applet
/classes' ?>"
```
 and while this does not use file.php to reference the applet, it would appear to be able to offer restrictions to access of the applet beyond that available at present (which makes the applet available to the whole world) and I will try tolook at converting some of the Ministry's lessons in at least moodle resources with such an internal php reference.
